In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: WHanne that Aueryll wyth hys schoures sote . /
The droghte of marche had ꝑperced vn to rote /
And bathed eủery veyne wyth such lycoure . /
Of whych vertu engendred is the floure .
Whan Zepherus eke with hys soote breth
Espyred haith in eủery holte and heth
The tendre croppys and the yong sōnne .
Hayth in the Rāmme hys half cours y rōnne .
And smale foules maken melodye .
That slepe al nyght wᵗith open eye .
So prykceth hem nature in her corage .
Thanne longen folke to goo on pylgrymage .
And Palmers to seke straunge loundes
To serue halowys couth in sundry londys
And specyally from euery schyrys end
Of Englond to caunterbury they wende
The holy blysfull martyr for to seke .
That hem haith holpen . whan they were syke
Byfell in that sesoun vp on a day
In southwerk atte the Taberde as y lay
Redy to wynde on my pilgmage
To Caunterbury with deuoute corage .
At nyght was cōmmyn in to that hostelerye .
Wele ix and twenty in a companye .
Of sondry folk . by auenture y falle
In the feloschyp . and pylgrymes were they alle
That toward caunterbury wolde y ryde .
The chambres and the stables were wyde
And wel werēn they eesyd atte the best
And schortely whan the sōnne was go to rest
So hadde y spoken with hem eủerychone .
That I was of her feloschyp anone .
And mayd forward erly / for to ryse .
To take oure wey þ̉er . as I ȝow deuyse .
But neủertheles whyle I haue tyme and space
Er that I ferther in thys tale pace .
Me thenketh hyt acordant to resoun
To telle yow all the condicyone .
Of eche of hem soo as hyt semyd me .
And whych thei were and of what degree .
And eke in what araye they weren in
And at a knyght thanne will I fyrst bigyn
A knyght þ̉er was and that a worthy man
That from the tyme that he first bygan
To ryden out . he louyd chyualrye
Trouth / honour / fredom / and Curtesye .
Full worthye was he in hys lordes werre .
And ther to had he ryden no man ferre .
As wele in crystendome as in hethenes
And eủer honoured for hys worthynes .
At Alysaundre he was whan hyt wonne .
Full ofte he had the borde bygonne .
Aboue all nacyons in pruce .
In lecto had he ryden and in Ruce .
No crysten man so oft in hys degree .
In Garnarde at the sege eke had he be .
At algazyr and ryden in belmarye .
At lyes was he and at Sattalie
Whan thei were wonne . and at the grece see
At many a noble Ryver had he be .
At mortale batailes had he ben xv .
And foghten for oure fayth intramieshen
In lystes thryes and alway slayn hys foo
Thys ylk worthy knyght had ben alsoo .
Sıı̄un tyme wyth the lord of palacie .
Aȝeinst a nother hethyn in Turkye .
And eủermore he had a souereyn prys
And thoghte that he was worthy . he was wyse .
And of porte as meke as is a mayde
He neủer ȝit no vylanye ne sayde
In alle hys lyfe vn to no maner wyght .
He was a verre gentyle ꝑperfyt knyght .
For to telle ȝow of hys array .
Hys hors was goode . but he was not gay .
Of fustian he wered a gyppioıı̄un .
Alle by smotred wyth his haburioıı̄un .
For he was late cōmmen from his vyage .
And went for to dōn hys pylgrymage .
Wyth hym ther was hys sōnne a yong squyer
A lover and a lusty bacheler
With lokkes crulled . as thei wer late īn pᵃsse .
Of . xx . ȝeer of age he was as I gesse .
Of hys stature he was of euen length
And wonderly delyủer and of grete strength .
And he had bene sıı̄un tyme in chyualrie
In Flaundres / in Artoys / and in pycardie .
And borne hym wele of so lytel space .
In hope to stonde in his lady grace .
Enbroudred was he as hyt were a meede .
Alle full of freshe floures whyte and reede .
Syngyng he was and floytyng all the day
He was as fresh as is the moneith of may .
Short was hys govne wyth slevys long and wyde .
Wele couthe he sytte on hors ⁊andfayr ryde .
He couthe songes make and wele endyte .
Iuste / daunce / wele portrey / and wryte
Soo hoote he lovyd that be nyght̉er tale .
He slepyd nomore than doith the nyghtygale .
Curteis he was lowely and ʆseruyciable .
And carfe before hys fadere at the table .
A Ȝōmman had he and ʆseruauntez no moo .
At that tyme for hym lyst to ryde soo .
He was clad in a coote and hoode of grene .
A shef / of pecokes arowes bryȝt and shene .
Vnder hys belt he bare full thryftyly
Wele couthe he dresse hys tacle ȝōmmanly .
Hys arowes drowpyd noȝt wᵗith fethers lowe .
And in hys myghty hand he bare a bowe .
A notted heede had he wyth broune vysage .
Of wodecraft wele couthe the vsage .
Vpon hys arme he bare a gay bracere .
And by hys syde / a swerde / and a bokelere .
And vn that oþir syde a gay dagger .
Harnesyd wele . ānd sharp as poynt of spere .
A cristofore on hys brest of syluyr schene .
An horne he bare the bawdryk was of grene .
A forster was he sothely as I gesse .
THer was also a nonne pryoresse .
That of her smylyng was symple ⁊and coy
Hyre grettest othe was by seint loy
And she was clepyd ma dame Eglentyne .
Full wele she song theʆseruyce dyuyne .
Entvned in her voys full semely
And frensch she spake full fayr and fetysly .
After the scole . of Stratford of the bowe .
For frensh of Parys was to her vnknowe .
At the mete wele itaught was she wᵗith all
She lete no morsell from her lyppes fall
Ne wette hir fyngres in her sauce depe
Wele couthe she carie a morsell . ⁊and wele kepe .
That no drope fill vp on her brest .
In curtesie was sette ful myche her lest
Hyr oủer lyppes wyped she so clene
That in her cuppe ther was no ferthyng sene .
Of grece whan she hadde drunke hyr draught
Full semely aftyr hyr meete she raught .
And sykerly sche was of grete disporte .
And full plesaunte . and amyable of porte .
And payned hyr to countyrfete chere
Of courte . to be stately of manere .
And to holdēn dygne of Reủerence .
But for to speke of hyr conscience .
She was so charytable and so pytous .
She wolde wepe . ȝif she saugh a mous
Caught in a trappe . ȝef hyt were dede or blede .
Of smale houndes had she that she fedde .
Wyth roste flessh mylk or wastell brede .
But soore she wept ȝif oone of hēm were dede .
Or ȝif men smote hyt with a ȝerde smert .
And all was conscience and tendre hert .
Full semely hyr wymple pynched was .
Hyr nose streight hir eyen grey as glas .
Hyr mouthe smale and ther to soft and rede .
But sekirly she had a faire forhede .
Hyt was almost a spanne brode Itrowe .
For hardely she was not vndirgrowe .
Full fetys was hyr cloke as I was ware .
Of smale coralle aboute hir necke she bare
A pair of bedes with gaudes all of grene .
Ther on hyng a broche of golde full shene .
On whyche was wryten a crouned A .
And after Amor vincit omnia .
A nother nonne with hyr had she
That was her chapelane . and p̉restes thre .
A Monke ther was a fair man for þe maistry
An out ryder that loued wele venery .
A manly man to be an abbot able .
Ful mony a deynty hors had he in stable .
And whan he rode . men myght hys bridel here .
Gynglyng and whistelyng wynde as clere .
And as lowde as doith þᵉ chapell belle .
Ther as the lord was keꝑper of the selle .
The Rule of seynt Maury or of seint Benet
By caus hit was olde and sudele streyt
This ilke monke let olde thynges passe .
And helde aftyr þe new worldys space
He yaffe noȝt of þᵗat text a pullyd hene .
That sayth that hunters ben noȝt holy men .
Ne that a monke . whan he is recheles
Ys likkenyd to a fyssh that is waterles .
Thys is to sey . a monk out of hys cloistr .
That ilke holde he noȝt worth an oistr .
And I seyd hys opynyon was goode .
What sholde he studie and make hym wode
Vpon a boke in Cloistr for to poore .
Or swynk with hys hondes or laboure .
As Austyn biddes how shall the worlde be seruyd .
Let Austyn haue hys swynk to hym reseruyd .
Therfore he was a prycasour a ryght
Grehoundes he had . as swyft as foule of flyȝt .
Of prykyng and huntyng for the hare
Was all his lust . for no cost wold he spare .
I saugh hys slevys purfilyd at the hand
Wyth gryse . the fyneste in a land .
And for to fastene hys hoode vndyr hys chyn
He had of gold wroȝt a curious pyn
A loue knot in the grett̉er ther was
His heed was balld and shone as any glas .
And eke his face as he had ben anoynt .
He was a lord full fat and īn good poynt .
Hys eyen stepe rollyng in hys heede
That stemed as doith a fournes of lede .
Hys bootes souple . hys hors in gret state .
Certenly he was a fair prelate .
He was noȝt pale lyke a forpyned goost .
A fat swanne loued he best of any roost .
Hys palfrey was as broune as is a bery .
x frere th̉er was a wantou and a mery
A lymytour and a full solempne man
In all þe ordres foure is non that can
So mych of daliaunce and fair langage
He had made many a fair mariage .
Of yong wymen at hys owen proper cost
To hys ordre he was a noble post .
Full wele beloued and familier was he
Wyth frankeleyns oủer all in hys contre
And eke with worthy wymen of þe toune
For he had power of confessioun
As he said hy self mor þen a curate
For of his order he was licēnciate
Full sweetly did he heer confession
And plesaunt was his absolucion
He was an esy man to ȝeve penaunce
Ther as he wyst to haue a good pytaunce .
For vn to poure ordre for to ȝiffe .
Ys a signe that a man is wele yschryffe .
For ȝif he ȝaf . he durst make hys avaunt .
He wyst that a man was repentaunt .
For many a man so herd is of hert
He may noȝt wepe thogh he soore smert .
Therfore in stede of wepyng and pᵃyers
Men most ȝif siluer to the pour Freres .
His typet was ay farced full of knyves .
And pynnes . to ȝif fayr wives
And certanly he had a mery note
Wele couthe he syng and play vpon a rote
Of ȝeddyng he bare vtterly the prys
Hys nekke was whyte as the flour delys .
Ther to strong as ony champyoun
He knew the tauerners wele in euery toun
And eủery hosteler and tapster
Welbet̉er than a begge or a lazar .
For vn to such a man as he .
Acordetth noȝt as by hys faculte .
To haue wᵗith such lazers aqueyntaunce .
Hit is noȝt honest hyt may noȝt auᵃunce
For to dele wyth suche pouerayle .
But all wyth ryche and sellers of vytayle .
And oủer all other as ꝓprofyt shuld aryse .
Curteys he was and lowely of seruyse .
There was no man nowhere so vertuous
He was the best begger in hys hous .
And ȝaf a certen ferme for the grᵃunnte
None of hys bretheryn cam þ̉ere in hys haunte .
For thogh a vydowe had but a sho
So plesaunt was hys in principio /
There wold he haue a ferthyng or he went
Hys purchas was bett̉er than hys Rent .
And rage he couthe as hyt wer a whelp
In louedaies he couthe full mykell help .
For he was not lyke a cloistrere
Wyth threedbare coope as is a pour scolere .
But he was lyke a maist̉er or a pope .
Of double worsted was hys semy cope .
That rounded was as a belle out of þe psse .
Sıı̄unwhat he lypsed for hys wantounesse .
To make hys englyssh swete vp on hys tonge .
And in hys herpyng whan he had song
Hys eyen twynkeled in hys heede a ryȝt .
As done sterres in the frosty nyȝt .
Thys worthy lymytour clepyd was huberd .
a merchant was there wᵗith a forked berd
In mottley on hie on hors he sat .
Vp on hys heed a flaundres beủer hat .
His botes clapsed fair and fetosly .
Hys resou he spak full solempnely .
Shewyng al way thencrece . of hys wynnyng .
He wold the see were kept for any thyng
Bytwyx Andelburgh and orwell
Wele couthe he in eschaunge scheldys sell .
Thys worthy man full wele hys wytte bysette .
Ther wyst no man that he was in dette .
So stately was he of goủernaunce .
Wyth hys bargeyns and his cheuyshaunce .
For soth he was a worthy man wyth all .
But soith to sey I not how men hym call
a Clerk ther was of Oxenford also

l.hi: That vn to logyke long had y go

div.l: And lene was he . not ryȝt fat I vndtake .
But loked holowe . and þ̉er to soburly
Full threede bar was hys ouerest courtby
For he getyn hym ȝit no benefice .
Uor he was noȝt worthy to haue an office .
For hym wer levir haue . at his beddys heede
XX . bokes cladde in blak and reede .
Of Arystotle and his philosophie
Than robes rych . or fidelle or savtrie
But all be hyt he was a phylosophr
Ȝit had he but lytell gold in coofr .
But all that he myȝt of hys frendes hent
On bokes and on lernyng he hit spent .
And besyly can he for the soules pre
Of hem that ȝaf hym wherwyth to scoley .
Of studie toke he most cure an hede .
Noȝt a word spake he moore than was neede .
And that was seyd in forme and reủerence .
And short and quyk and full of hyegh sentence .
Sounyng in morall vertu was hys spech .
Gladly wold he lerne . and gladly teche .
a Seriaunt of þe law war and wys .
That oft had bene at parvys .
Ther was also full ryche of excellence .
Discrete he was and of grete Reủerence .
He semyd such . hys wordes wer so wyse .
Iustice he was full oft in assise .
By patent and by plane . cōmmission .
For hys science and hys renoun .
Of fees and robes he had mony oone
So grete a purchasour was nowher noone .
All was fee symple to hym in effecte .
Hys purchasyng myȝt not be infecte .
Nowhere so besy a man ther nas
And ȝit he semed bysier than he was .
In termes had he cas and domes all
That from the tyme of kyng william was fall .
Therto he couth endite and mak a thyng .
Ther couth no wyȝt pynch at hys endityng
And eủery statute couth he pleyn by roote .
He roode but homely in a medley coote .
Gyrt wyth a seynt of sylk wyth barres smale .
Of hys araye telle I no lenger tale .
A Frankelene ther was in hys cıı̄unpany .
White was hys berd as is the daieseye .
Of hys complexciou he was sanguyne .
Wele loued in the morn a soppe in wyne .
To lyue in delyte was eủer hys wone
For he was Epicurius owne sone .
That held opiniou that verrey delyte .
Was verily felicite parfyte .
An housholder and that a grete was he .
Seint Iulian he was in hys contre .
Hys breede his ale was alway aft̉er one .
A bett̉er enuyned man was no wher none .
Wyth out bake mete was neủer hys hous .
Of fysh and flessh and that so plentivous .
Hyt snewed in hys hous of mete and drynk
Of all deintes that men couth on thynk .
After the sondry sesouns of the ȝer
So chaungeith he hys mete and hys soper .
Full many a fat ꝑpartryche had he in mewe .
And many a breme and many a luce īn stewe .
Woo was hys cooke . but ȝif hys sauce were .
Poynant and sharp and redy all hys gere .
Hys table dormaunt in hys all alwey
Stode redy couered all the long day .
At the sessions there was he lord and syr .
Full oft had he bene knyght of the schyr .
An anlas on a gypcer all of sylk .
Hyng vn hys gyrdell whyte as morowe mylke .
A shyreue had he bene and a countour .
Was nowhere suche a nother vauasour .
An haburdassher . and a carpent̉er .
A Webbe . a Dier . and Tapycer .
Thei were clothed all in oo lyuer .
Of a solempne and a grete fraternite .
Full fressh and newe her ger pyked was
Her knyves chaped wer noȝt of glas .
But wroȝt wyth sylủer al full clene and wele .
Her gyrdels and her pouches eủerydele
Wele semed ech of hem a fair burgeis
To sitte in þe ȝeld halle on a deis .
Eủeryche for the wysdom that he kan
Was shapely to be an alder man .
For catell had þei ynogh and Rent .
And eke her wyves wolde hit wele assent .
And elles certen thei weren to blame .
Hyt is full fair to be clepyd ma dame .
And go to vigiles all to forne
And haue a mantel ryale born .
a Cook thei had wᵗith hem for the nones
To boyle the chykens wᵗith the merybones .
And poudre / marchant tart / and galymgale
Wele couthe he know a draught of londou ale .
He couth rost ⁊and bole . seth and frie .
Make mortreux and wele bake a pye .
But grete harme was hit as hit thoght me .
That on his chynne a mormal had he .
For blankmanger maide he wᵗith the best .
a schypman was ther wonnyng th̉er by west .
For ought I woote he was of dertemouth .
He roode on a Rouncy as he couthe .
In a gowne of faldyng to the kne .
A dagger hangyng on a lace had he .
Aboute hys nekke vnd hys arme a done .
The hoote somer had made . his hew al brone .
And certanly he was a goode felaw
Full many a draugh of wyne had he draw .
From bordeux ward whilest the mchantez slepe .
Of nyce conscience toke he no kepe .
Ȝif that he fawght and had the herre hond
By water he sendt them home by eủery lond .
But of hys craft to rykene wele hys tyde
Hys stremys and hys daungers hym besydes
Hys herburgh and hys money and hys lodmanage .
Ther nas no man suche from Hull vn to Cartage .
Herdy he was and wyse to vndertake .
Wyth many a tempest had hys berd be shake .
He knew all the hauenes as thai ware
From scotland vn to the lond of fenestar
And eủery cryke in brytaigne and in spaigne .
Hys barge was clepyd þe maudeleyne .
wyth vs ther was a maister of fysyk
In all the world was non hym lyke .
To speke of fysyk and of Surgerye .
For he was grounded in astronomye .
He kept hys pacient a full grete dele
In houres by hys magyk naturele .
Wele couthe he fortune the ascendent .
Of hys ymage for hys pacient .
He knew the caus of eủery maladie .
Were hit hoote . colde . moist . or drye .
Where hit engendreth and of what humour .
He was a verrey parfyt practysour .
The cause he knew and of hys harme þᵉ rote .
Anon he ȝaf the seke man hys bote .
Full redy had he his apotecaries .
To send hym dragges . and his letuaries
For eche of hem maide oth̉er to wynne .
Here frendeschyp was noȝt new to bygynne .
Wele knew he the old Esculapius .
Dioscorides and eke Ruphus
Olde ypocᵃs . haly . and galien
Serapion . Razy . and Auicen
Aủeroys . damascien . and constantyn .
Bernard . Gatisden . and gilbertyn .
Of his diete mesurable was he
For hit was of no suꝑperfluyte .
But of grete noryshyng ⁊and digestible .
His studie was but lytell on the bible .
In sanguyne and in pers clad was he all
Lyned with taffata and wyth sendall .
And ȝit he nas but esy of dispence .
He kept that he wan in pestylence .
For gold in fysyk is a cordial .
Ther for he loued gold in specyal .
a good wyf th̉er was of besydes bathe .
Sche was su dele deffe . ⁊and þᵗat was scathe .
Of clothe makyng had she such haunt
She passed hem of ypres and of Gaunt
In all the parysh wyf was þ̉er none .
That to the offeryng before hyr shuld gone .
And ȝif þer dyd certen so wrothe was she .
That she was out of all charite .
Hyr keuerches full fyne were of grounde .

That ilke fruyt is euer lenger the wers
Till hit be roten in mullok or in stree
We olde men̄ I drede so faire we
Till we be roten kan we noght be rype
We hopen alwey while the worlde will pipe
For in oure will ther styketh euere a nayle
To haue an hoore hede ⁊and a grene taile
As haith a leke for þough oure myght be gone
Oure wille desireth eủer still in oone
For whan we may noȝt done than will we speke
Ȝet in oure asshen olde is fire yreke
Foure gledes han we whiche I shall deuyse
Auauntyng lying anger couetyse
This foure sperketh longth vn to elde
Oure olde lymes may wele ben̄ vn welde
But wille ne shall not fayle that is soth
And ȝet haue I all wey a coltes toth
As many a ȝeere as hit is passed henne
Syn that my tappe of lyf began to renne
For sikerly whan I was borne a none
Deth drough the tappe of lyf ⁊and lete hit gone
And euer sithen haith so the tappe yronne
Till that almost all empty is the tonne
The streme of lyf now droppeth on the chynne
The sely tonge may wele rynge ⁊and chymbe
Of wretchednesse that passyd is full ȝore
With olde folk saue dotage is the more
Whan that oure ooste had herd this ʆsermonyng
He gan to speken as lordely as a kyng
He seid what amonteth all this wytte
What shall we speke all day of holy wrytte
The deuell made a refe for to preche
Or of a souter a shipman or a leche
Sey forth thi tale and tarye not the tyme
Lo depford and hit is half wey pryme
Loo Grenewhich that many a shrew is In
Hit were al tyme thy tale for to gynne
Now sirs qᵈuod this Oswold Refe
I pᵃraye ȝow all that ȝe noȝt ȝoᵘ grefe
Þogh I ansuere and somdele sette his houwe
For leuefull hit is with force of shouwe
This dronken myller hath ytold vs here
How that begyled was a carpenter
ꝐParauenture in scorn for I am one
And by youre lefe I shall hym quyte anone
Right in his cherles termes will I speke
I pᵃray to god his nekke more to breke
He can wele in myn eye see a stalke
But īn īn his owne he can noȝt seen a balk
At Trumpyngton̄ noght fer fro cambryge
Ther gothe a broke and ouer that bryge
Vppon the whiche broke ther stant a mylle
And this is verray soth that I ȝow telle
A myller was ther duellyng many a day
As any pocok he was proude ⁊and gay
Pipen he couth and fisshēnnefisshēne fisshen and nettys kneilte knilteknete
And torne coppes and wele wrastell ⁊and shete
And by his belt he bare a long panade
And of a swerde full trenchant was the blade
A ioly popper bare he in his pouche
Ther was no man̄ for parell durst hym touche
A shefeld Twytell bare he in his hose
Rounde was his face and camys was his nose
As piled as an hape was his sculle
He was a market beter at the fulle
Ther was no wight that durst hand on hȳm legge
But if he swore he shuld anoone a begge
A Thef he was for sothe of corne ⁊and myle
And that a sleigh and vsant for to stele
His name was hoten deynous symken
A wyf he had cōmmen of a noble kyn
The ꝑperson of þe towne her fader was
With her he ȝaf full many a pānne of bras
For that symkyn shuld in his bloode allye
She was yfostered in a Nonnerye
For symkyn wold no wyf as he seide
But she were wele y norysshede ⁊and a mayde
To sauen his astate of ȝomanry
And she was proude ⁊and pert as is a pye
A full fair sight was hit vppon hem two
On haly daies a forne her wold he go
With his typet wonden about his heed
And she come after in a gyte of reede
And symkyen had hosen of the same
Ther durst no wight clepen hir but dame
Was noon so hardy that went by the wey
That with hir durst ones rage or pley
But ȝif he wolde ben slayn of Symkyn
With panade or with knyf or bodekyn
For ielous folk ben ꝑperelous euermo
Algate thei wolde ther wyfes wenden so
And ek for she was som dele smoterlich
She was a deigne as water in the dich
And full of hoker and of bysmare
Hir thoght that a lady shuld hir spare
What for her kynrede and hir nortelrye
That she had lernyd in nonnerye
A doghter had ther betwyx hem two
Of twenty ȝeer with outen ony moo
Sauyng a child that was of half ȝere age
In cradell hit lay and was a ꝓproper page
Thil wenche thikke and wele y grouen was
With camyse nose and eyen gray as glas
With buttokes brode and brestes rounde ⁊and hie
But right fair was hir here I will noȝt lye
The ꝑperson of the towntown for she was so faire
In purpose was to make hir his eire
Both of his catell and his messuage
And straunge he mayde hit of hir mariage
His purpose was to be stow hir hie
Vn to som worthy bloode of auncetrie
For holy chirche mote ben̄ dispended
Of holy chirche bloode that is descended
Therefore he wolde his hooly bloode honoure
Þoght that he holy chirche shulde deuoure
Grete sokyn hath this myller oute of doute
With s whete and malte of all the lond aboute
And namelych ther was a grete collage
Men clepith the soler hall at cambrige
Ther was hir whete and eke hir malt ygrounde
And on a day hit happynd in a stounde
Sheke lay the manciple on̄ a maladie
Men wende wysely that he shuld die
For whiche stale both this meller mele ⁊and corne
An hundred tyme more than byforne
For ther byforn he stale but curtesly
But now he was a thef outrageously
For whiche the warden chidde ⁊and made fare
But ther of sette the myller noȝt a tare
He craked bost ⁊and swore hit was not so
Than were there yonge scolers two
That dwelten in the hall of which I sey
Testy they were and lusty to pley
And only for ther myrthe and reuerie
Vpon the warden besyly thei crie
To ȝif hem lefe but a litell srounde
To go to the mylle ⁊and seen hir corn̄ ygronde
And herdely thei durst ley her nekke
The myller shuld not stele hem haf a pekke
Of corne ne be sleight ne by force hem reve
And at the last the warden̄ ȝaf hem leve
Iohn hight that one and Alen hight that other
Of oone towne were thei borne that hight strother
Fer in the north I can not telle where
This alen̄ maketh redy all hir gere
And on a hors the sakke he cast anone
Forth goth alen̄ the clerk and also Iohn
With goode swerd and with bokeler by hir syd
Iohn knew the wey hem nedith no gyde
And at the mylle the sakke a doune he lath
Alen spake fyrst all haile symon in faith
How fares thy fair doughter and thy wyf
Alen welcome qduod symkyn by my lyf
And Iohn also how now what do ȝe here
By god qᵈuod Iohn symond nede haith no pere
Hym byhoves serue hym self that hath no swayn
Or elles he is a fole as clerkes sayn
Oure manciple I hope he will be dede
Swa werkes hym ay the veyns of his hede
And therfore is I come and eke alen
To grynde oure corne and carye hit hame ageyn
I pray ȝow spede hus hethen that ȝe may
Hit shall be don̄ qᵈuod symkyn by my fay
What will ȝe done while that hit is in hande
But god ryght by the hoper will I stonde
Qduod Iohn and see how gates the corn̄ gas Inne
Ȝit saugh I neuer by my fader kynne
How that he hoper wagges til ⁊and fra
Alen̄ ansuerd Iohn wilt þow swa
Than will I be byneth be my croune
And see how gates the mele falles doune
In tille the trogh that shall be my desporte
Qᵈuod Iohn in fath I may be of youre sorte
I is als ille mylner as ar͗e ȝe
This myller smyled of her nycetye
And thoght all this is don̄ but for a while
Thei weyn that no man̄ may hem begile
But by my thryft ȝet shall I blere hir eye
For all her sleght in her philosophie
The more queynte crekes that thei mak
The more wille I stele whan I take
In stede of floure ȝit will I ȝif hem brenne
The grettest clerkes ben noȝt the wysest mēnne
As whilom to the wolf thus spake the mare
Of all her arte counte I noȝt a tare
Out of the dore he goth full priuely
Whan that he saugh hys tyme softly
He loketh vp ⁊and doune til he hath yfounde
The clerkes hors ther͗e as he stode ybounde
Behynd the mylle vnder a leuesele
And to this horse he goth hym fair ⁊and wele
He stripeth of the brydell right anone
And whan the hors was lavse he gynneth to gon̄
Toward the fenne there wilde mares renne
And forth with we he þurgh thik and thurgh thenne
This myller goth agayn no worde he seide
But doth his note and with the clerkes pleyde
Till that hir corne was fair ⁊and wele ygrounde
And whan the mele was sakked and ybounde
This Iohn goth oute ⁊and fynde his hors awey
And gan to crie harow and wele away
Oure hors is lost Alen for goddes banes
Steppe on thi fete come of man̄ al at anes
Alas oure warden̄ hath his palfrey lorne
This alen̄ all forgate both mele ⁊and corne
Alle was out of his mynde his housbondrie
What whilke way is he gane he gan to crie
The wyf come lepyng Inward at a renne
She seid alas ȝoure hors goth in the fenne
With wilde mares as fast as he may go
Vnthank come vn his hede that bounde hym soo
And he that shuld better haue knytte the reyne
Alas qᵈuod Iohn alen̄ for cristes peyn
Ley done thy swerd and I will myn̄ alswa
I is full swyft god wate as is raa
By goddes hert he shall not scape vs bath
Why ne had þow put the capil in the lath
Ilhale by god alen þow is a fonne
This sely clerkes haue full fast yronne
Toward the fenne both Alen ⁊and eke Iohn
And when the myller seith that thei wer͗e gone
He half a busshell of hir floure hath ytake
And bad his wyf go knede hit on a kake
And seyd I trow the clerkes were a ferde
Ȝet can a meller make a clerkes berde
For all his arte ȝet gon gon lat hem gon hir wey
Loo where he goth ȝei lat the children pley
Thei gete hym noght so lyghtily by my crowne
These sely clerkes renne vp ⁊and doune
With kepe kepe stand stand iossa warderere
Ga wightly þow and I shall kepe hym here
But shortely til hit was verrey nyght
Thei coude not þogh thei did all her myght
Her capell catche he ranne al wey so fast
Till in a diche thei caght hym at last
Wery ⁊and wete as best is in the rayn
Cometh sely Iohn ⁊and with hym cōmmeth Alen
Alas qᵈuod Iohn the day that I was borne
Now are we dryven til hething ⁊and til scorn
Oure corn is stole men will vs foooles calle
Bothe the warden and oure felaws alle
And namely the myller wele away
Thus pleyneth Iohn as goth by they wey
Toward the mylle and bayard in his honde
The myller sittyng by the fire he fonde
For hit was nyght and ferther myght he noȝ
But for the loue of god thei hym be souȝt
Of herber and of eese as for hyr peny
The myller seid ageyn yf ther be any
Suche as hit is ȝet shall ȝe haue ȝour part
My hous is streit but ȝe haue lerned art
Ȝe can be argument maken a place
A myle brood of twenty foote of space
Late se now yf that this place mow suffice
Or make hit rowmer with spech as is ȝoure gyse
Now symond seid this Iohn by seint Cuthberd
Ay is thow mery and that is fair answerd
I haue herd sey men̄ shall take of twa thinges
Swilke as he fyndes or swylk as he brynges
But specialy I pray the ooste dere
Gete vs som mete and drynk and make vs chere
And we will pay trewly at the full
With empty handes men may noon haukes tulle
Loo here oure syluer redy for to spende
This meller to the towne his doughter ysende
For ale ⁊and breed and rosted hem a goos
And bonde hir hors he shuld no more go loose
And in his owne chambre he made a bedde
With shetis ⁊and with chalons fair yspredde
Noȝt from his owne bedde ten fote or twefe
His doghter had a bed by hir selfe
Ryght in the same chambre by ⁊and by
Hit myght be not bette and caus why
Ther was no rowmer herbery in the place
Thei sopen and thei speken hom to solace
And drynken̄ euer strong ale at the best
Aboute mydnyght went thei to rest
Wele hath this myller vernysshed his heede
Full pale he was for dronken ⁊and noȝt reed
He yexeth and he speketh þurgh the nose
As he were in the quakke or in the pose
To bedde he goth and with hym goth his wyfe
As any Iay he lyght was and Iolyf
So was his iolyf whistell wele I wette
The cradell at hir beddes fete is y sette
To rokken ⁊and to ȝif the child souke
And whan that dronken was all in the crouke
To bedde went the doghter ryght anoone
To bedde goth Alen̄ and also Iohn
Ther was no more hem nedith no dwale
This myller haith so wysely bybbed the ale
That as an hors he snortyth in his slepe
Ne of his taile behynd he toke no kepe
His wyf bare hym a burdon̄ a full strong
Men myght hir rovtyng here a forlong
The wenche routeth eke ꝑpar companye
Alen̄ the clerk that herd this melodie
He powked Iohn and seyd slepest þow
Herde þow eủer swilke a sange or now
Loo swilke a coupleyng is betwyx hem alle
A wilde fire on ther bodies falle
Who herd euer swilk a ferly thynge
Ȝei thei shall haue the floure of euyll endyng
This lange nyght ther tydes me na rest
But ȝet na fors all shall be for the best
For Iohn seyd as euery mote I thryfe
Yf that I may yond wenche wyll I swyfe
Som esement hath lawe shapen vs
For Iohn ther is a lawe that seith thus
That yf a man̄ in oo poynt be a greved
That in an other he shall be releved
Oure corn is stollen̄ sothely hit is no na
And we haue had an ille fytte all this day
And syn I shall haue noon amendment
Agayn my losse I will haue esement
By goddes hit shall naan other be
This Iohn ansuerd alen avyse the
The myller is a ꝑperilous man̄ he seid
And yf þat he oute of his slepe abrayde
He myght done vs bothe a vylany
Alen ansuerd I doute hym noȝt a flie
And vp he ryst and by the wenche he crepte
This wenche lay vp right and fast slepte
Till he so nyghe was or she myghte spye
That hit hadde ben̄ to late for to crie
And shortly for to seyn thei weren̄ at oone
Now play alen for I will speke of Iohn
This Iohn lithe stylle a forlong wey or two
And to hym self he maketh reuthe ⁊and woo
Allas qᵈuod he this is a wykked Iape
Now may I seen that I is but an ape
Ȝit hath my felaw somwhat for his harme
He hath the myllers doghter in his arme
He auentred hym and haith his nedis spedde
And I lie as a draffe sakke in my bedde
And whan this Iape is tolde an other day
I shall be holde a daff a cokenay
I will aryse and auntre me by my faith
Vnhardy is vnsely thus men̄ saith
And vp he roose and softely he went
Vn to the cradell and in his hond it hent
And bare hir soft vn to his beddys fete
Sone after the wyf hir routyng lete
And gan to wake and went hir out to pysse
And come agayn and can̄ hir cradell myss
And groped here and there but she fond noone
Alas qᵈuod she I had almost mysgone
I had almost gon to the clerkes bedde
Ey bn̄enedicite þan haddde I foule y spedde
And forth she goth til she the cradell fonde
She gropeth alwey forther with her honde
And fonde the bedde and thoght noȝt but goode
Bycaus that the cradell by hyt stoode
And nyst where she was for hit was derk
But fair and wele she crepe to the clerk
And lith full stille ⁊and wolde haue caught a slepe
With in a while this Iohn the clerk vp lepe
And on this good wyfe he leith on sore
So mery fitte ne hadde she not full yore
He pryketh harde ⁊and depe as he were madde
This ioly lyf han these two clerkes ladde
Till that thridde cokke bygan to synge
Alen wexe wery in the dawenyng
For he hadde swonken̄ all the long nyght
And seid fare wele malyn swete wight
The day is cōmmyn I may no lenger byde
But euermore where so I go or ryde
I am thyn owne clerk so haue I hele
Now dere lēmman qᵈuod she go far͗e wele
But or thow go oone thyng I will the telle
Whan that þow wendest homeward by the melle
Ryght at the entre of the dore behynde
Thow shalt a cake of half a busshell fynde
That was ymaked of thyn owne mele
Whiche that I helpe my syre for to stele
And good lēmman god the save ⁊and kepe
And with that worde almost he gan to wepe
Alen vp ryst and thoght or hit were day Added to facilitate collatio
I wille go crepen in by my felawe
And fonde the cradell with his hand anoone
By god thoght he all wrang I haue mysgone
My hede is toty of my swynkyng to nyght
That maketh me that I go noght a ryght
I wote wele by the cradell I haue mysse go
Here lyght the myller and his wyf also
And forth he goth on twenty deuell wey
Vn to the bedde there as the myller ley
He wende haue cropen by his felaw Iohn
And in by the myller in crepte anoone
And caught hym by the nekke ⁊and softe he spake
He seid þow Iohn þow swyneshede awake
For cristes soule and here a noble game
For by that lord that called is seynt Iame
As I haue thries in thes shorte nyght
Swyued the mellers doughter bolt vp ryght
While thow has as a coward ben agast
Ȝei fals harlot qᵈuod the myller hast
A fals traytour fals clerk qᵈuod he
Þow shalt be dede by goddes dignite
Who durst be so bolde to dysparage
My doughter is cōmmyn of suche lynage
And by the throte bolle he caught Alen̄
And he hent hym dispitously agayn
And on the nose he smote hym with his fyste
Doun̄ ranne the blody streme vpon his bryst
And in the floore with nose ⁊and mouth to broke
The wallow as doth two pygges in a poke
And vp thei gone and doıı̄un agayn anoon̄
Till that meller spurned at a stoon̄
And down̄ he fell bakward vppon̄ his wyfe
That wyst no thyng of this nyce stryf
For she was falle on slepe a lytil wight
With Iohn the clerk that waked hadde all nyght
And with that falle oute of hir slepe she brayde
Help holy crosse of bromholme she seyd
In manus tuas lord to the I calle
Awake symond the fend is on me falle
Myn hert is broken help I nam but dede
There lyght oone vp my wombe and vp myn hede
Help symkyn for the fals clerkes fighte
This Iohn starte vp as fast as eủer he myght
And grasped by the walles to and froo
To fynden a staffe and she stert vp also
And knew the hirnes better than did Iohn
And by the walle a staff she fond anoon
And sagh a littell glymering of a light
For at an hole in shone the mone lyght
And by that lyght she sagh hem both two
But sykerly she nyst who was whoo
But as she sagh a whyte thyng in hir eye
And whan she gan this white thyng aspye
She wende the clerk had wered a volypere
And with the staff she drough ay nere and nere
And wend han hit this Alen atte the fulle
And smote the meller on the pelyd sculle
That down̄ he goth and cried harow I dye
This clerkes bette hym wele ⁊and lete hym lye
And gerden̄ hem and token hir hors anoon
And eke hir mele and on hir wey thei goon
And at the mylle ȝet thei toke her cake
Of half a busshell floure full wele ybake
Thus is the proude myller wele ybette
And haith ylost the gryndyng of the whete
And payde for the soper euery del
div.fw: The Reues tale · And þᵉ Cookꝭes prologe
div.l: Of Alen ⁊and of Iohn that bette hym wele
His wyf is swyued and his doughter als
Loo such it is a meller to be fals
And þerfore this ꝓprouerbe is seyd full sothe
Hym dar noȝt wyf weene wele · that yuell doth
A gylour shall hym self begyled be
And god that sitteth highe in mageste
Saue all this cumpany grete ⁊and smale
Thus haue I quyt the myller my tale
The cok of london̄ while the Refe spake
For ioy hym þoght he clawed hym on the bake
Ha ha qᵈuod he for cristes passion
This meller hath a sharp conclusion
Vppon his argument of herbigage
Wele seid salamon in his langage
Ne bryng not eủery man̄ in to thyn hous
For herberyng by nyght is ꝑperylous
Wele aught a man̄ avysed for to be
Whom that he brought in to his priuety
I pray to god so ȝif me sorw ⁊and care
Yf euer syn I hight hogge of ware
Herd y a meller better y sette on werk
He had a iape of malice in the derk
And therfore yf ȝe vochesaue to here
But god forbede that we stynt here
A tale of me that am a poure man̄
I will ȝow telle as wele as eủery I can̄
A litell Iape that fille in oure Cite
Oure ost ansuerd and seyd I gᵃraunte hit the
Now telle on Roger loke that hit be goode
For many a past hast þow leten̄ blode
And mony a Iakke at Douer hast þow solde
That hath twyes and twyes col
Of mony pylgryms hast þow cristes curs
For of thei ꝑpersely ȝet fare thei the wors
That thei hetyn with thi stopill goos
For in thi shope is mony a flie loos
Now tell on Roger gentil by thi name
But ȝit I pᵃray ȝe be not wroth for game
A man may say full soth in game and pley
Thow seist full soth qᵈuod Roger by my fey
Bot soth play quade pley as the flēmmyng seith
And therfore for euery baillyf by thi feith
Be þow not wroth or we deꝑparten here
Thogh my tale be of an ostelere
But natheles I will not tellen hit ȝet
But or we ꝑparte ywys þow shalt be quytte
And therwith loughe and made gode chere
And seyd his tale as ȝe shall after here
A Prentys whilom dwellyd in oure cite
And of a craft of vytalers was he
Gallant he was as goldfynche in the shawe
Broun̄ as a bery a ꝓpropre short felawe
With lokkes blake ykempt full fetisly
Daunce he couthe so wele and iolily
That he was clepyd ꝑperkyn reuelour
He was as full of loue and ꝑparamour
As is the hyve full of hony swete
Wele was the wenche with hym myght mete
At euery bridale wolde he syng ⁊and hoppe
He loued bet the tauerne than the shoppe
For whan ther any thyng was in chepe
Out of the shoppe thider wold he lepe
Till that he had all the sight yseyn
A daunced wele wold he noȝt come aȝen
And gedred hym a meneȝe of his sorte
To hoppe ⁊and syng ⁊and make suche disport
And there thei setten steuen to mete
To pleyen at the dies in suche a strete
For in the towne was ther noon̄ prentys
That fayrer coude cast a peyr of dys
Than ꝑperkyn couth and þ̉erto he was free
Of his dispence in place of priuete
That fonde his maister wele in his chaffare
For oft tyme he fonde his box full bare
For sekerly a prentys reuelour
That haunteth dis or riot or ꝑparamour
His maist̉er shuld hit in his shope abye
All haue no part of the mynstralsie
For theft and ryot thei ben̄ conuertible
All con he pley on gyttern or rybible
Reuell and trewth as in lowe degree
Thei ben̄ full wroth all day as men̄ may see
This ioly prentys with his maister bode
Til he were nere out of his prentyshode
All were he snybbed erly and late
And som tyme lad with reuell to newgate
But at the last his maister hym bythoght
Vpon a day whan he his paper soght
Of a prouerbe that seith this same worde
Wele better is the roten appyll out of horde
Than that hit rote all the remanaunt
So farith hit by a riotous ʆseruaunt
Hit is full lasse harme to late hym passe
Than he shent all the ʆseruauntez in the place
Therfore his maister ȝaf hym a quytaunce
And bad hym go with sorow and myschaunce
And thus this ioly prentys had his leue
Now lete hym go riot all the nyght or leve
And for ther is no theef with oute a louk
That helpeth hym towasten and to sowke
Of that he brybe may can or borow may
Anoon he send his bedde and his array
Vnto a conꝑper of his owne sorte
That loued dys reuell and disport
And had a wyf that held fortħ contynaunce
A shoppe and swyfed for hir sustenaunce
But here of I will passe as now
Of ȝong Gamelyn I will telle ꝫow .
Lythen and lightenyth ⁊and herkenygħ aryꝫt
And ȝe shuƚƚ here of a doughty knyght
Sir Iohn̄ of Bondeux was his name
He coude of norture and of mycħ game .
Thre sōnnes the knyght had ⁊and with his body hēm wan͒
The eldest was a moche shrew ⁊and sone he bygan
His bretheren loued wele hir fader ⁊and were of hȳm agast
The eldest deseruyd his fader curs ⁊and he hit had at last
The goode knyght his fader lyued so ȝore
That deth was cōmmyn hym to ⁊and handelyd hym ful sore
The goode knyght cared sore syke ther he lay
How his children shuld lyven after his day
He had ben̄ wyde where but housbond non̄ he was
Aƚƚ the land that he had hit was purchas
Fayn he wold hit were dressyd among hem aƚƚ
That iche of hem had his ꝑparte as hit might falle
Tho send he in to the contre after wise knyghtes
To help to delen̄ his landes ⁊and dressen̄ hēm to rightes
He send hem word by l͒letres ther shuld hie blyve
Ȝif thei wold speke with hym while he was o lyve
Tho the knyghtes herden̄ sike that he lay
Hadde thei no rest nother nyght than day
Tiƚƚ ther come to hym ther he lay still

div.l: On his deth bedde to abide goddes wille
Than seid the good knyght sike ther he lay
Lordes I warne soth with outen nay
I may no lenger lyven here in this stonde
For thurgh goddis wille deth drawyth me to grounde
Ther nas noon̄ of hem that herd hym aright
That thei ne had reutħ of that ilke knyght
And seiden syr for goddis loue ne dysmay ȝoᵘ noght
God may done bote of bale that is now ywroght
Than spake the goode knyght syke ther he lay
Bote of bale god may send I wote hit is no nay
But I beseke ȝow knyghtes for the loue of me
Gothe and dresseth my londes among my sōnnes thre
And for the loue delitħ noȝt hem amysse
And forȝeteth not gamelyn my ȝong that is
Taketh hede to that one as wele as to that other
Selden ȝe seen helpeth wele his brother
Tho lete thei the knyght lye that was not in hele
And wenten̄ in to councele his londes for to dele
For to delen hem aƚƚ to oon̄ that was hir thoght
And For Gamelyn was yongest he shuld haue noght
Alle the londe that ther was thei dalten hit in two
And lete Gamelyn the yong witħ outen̄ lond go
And yche of hem seid to other fuƚƚ lowde
His bretheren myght ȝif hym londe whan he goode cowde
Whan thei hadde delyd the londe at hir wylle
Thei comyn to the knyght ther he lay stylle
And tolde hym anoone how thei had wroght
And the knyght ther he lay lykyd hit right noght
Than seyd the knyght by seynt Martyn
For aƚƚ that ȝe haue ȝet done ȝet is the lond myn
For goddis loue neighbours stondeth aƚƚ stiƚƚ
And I wiƚƚ delyn my lond ryȝt after my wiƚƚ
Iohn̄ my eldest sone shaƚƚ haue ploghes fyve
That was my fader heritage while he was alyve
And my mydlest sone v ploghes of lond
That I helpe for to gete wight my ryȝt hond
And aƚƚ myn other purchas of londes ⁊and ledes
That I quethe Gamelyn ⁊and aƚƚ my goode stedes
And I beseke ȝow good men̄ that law con̄ of lond
For Gamelyns loue that my quest stond
Thus dalte the knyght his lond by his day
Ryght on his deth bedde syke ther he lay
And son̄ afterward he ley stone stille
And deid whan tyme come as was cristes wille
Anoon̄ as he was deid ⁊and vnder gras grave
Sone this elder brother gyled the yong knaue
He toke in to his honde his londe ⁊and his lede
And gamelyn hym self to clothen ⁊and to fede
He clothed hym and fedde hym yuel ⁊and eke wrothe
And lete his londes for fare ⁊and his houses bothe
His parkes ⁊and his woddes ⁊and did no thyng wele
And sythen he hit aboght on his owne felle
So long was gamelyn in his brothers halle
For the strengest of goode wille thei dovten hym aƚƚlle
Ther was non̄ ther in nother yong ne olde
That wolde wrathe gamelyn were he neủer so bolde
Gamelyn stode on a day in his brothers ȝerde
And bygan with his hand to handele his berde
He thoght on his londes that lay vnsawe
And his faire okes that doun̄ were drawe
His parkes were broken̄ and his dere reved
Of aƚƚ his good stedes noon̄ was hym leved
His houses were vnhiled and fuƚƚ yveƚƚ dygh
Tho thoght Gamelyn hit went noȝt a ryght
Afterward come his brother walkyng there
And seid to Gamelyn is oure mete ȝare
Tho wrathed hym gamelyn ⁊and swore by goddes booke
Yow shalt go bake thy self I wiƚƚ not be thy cooke
Now Gamelyn brother how ansuers yow now
Yow spakest neuer suche worde as yow dost now
By my feith seid gamelyn now me thynke nede
Of aƚƚ the harmes that I haue Itoke neuer ȝet hede
My parkes ben̄ broken̄ and my dere be reved
Of myn harneis ⁊and my stedis noȝt is me beleved
Alle that my fader me bequatħ aƚƚ gotħ to shame
And therfore haue yow goddes curs brother by the name
Than̄ spake his brother that rape was of rees
Stond stille gadlyng ⁊and hold thy pees
Yow shalt be fayn to haue thy mete ⁊and þi wede
What spekes yow gadlyng of lond or of lede
Than seid gamelyn that was ying
Cristes curse mote he haue that clepetħ me gadlyng
I am no wors gadlyng ne no worse wyght
But borne of a lady ⁊and geten̄ of a knyght
Ne durst he not to gamelyn neủer fote go
But clepyd to hym his men̄ ⁊and seyd to hym tho
Goth ⁊and beteth this boy and reveth hym his wette
And lete hym lerne an other tyme ansuer͗ me bette
Than seid the yong child Gamelyn
Cristes curse mote yow haue brother ert yᵘou myne
And ȝif I shaƚƚ algate be beten anoone
Cristes curse mote yow haue but yᵘou be that oon͗e
And anone his brother in that grete hete
Made his men̄ staffes fette gamelyn to bete
Whan euer of hem hadde a staffe yno͒mmen
Gamelyn was ware tho he seigħ hem cōmme
Tho gamelyn sigħ hem cōmmen he loked oủer aƚƚlle
And was ware a pesteƚƚ stoode vnder the walle
Gamelyn was lyght and thider gon he lepe
And droffe aƚƚ his brothers men̄ ryȝt sone on hepe
And loked as a wild lyon ⁊and layd on goode wone
Tho his brother sey that he bygan to gone
He fleygħ vp in to alofte ⁊and shette the dore fast
This gamelyn with his pesteƚƚ made hem al agast
Some for gamelyns loue and some for eye
Alle þei drowen̄ hem to halkes þo he gan to pleye
What now seyd gamelyn yueƚƚ mote ȝe the
While ȝe begynne cokkyng and so sone flee
Gamelyn sagħ his brother wheder he was flowe
And sagħ where he lokyd oute at a wyndowe
Brother seid Gamelyn come aliteƚƚ nere
And I wiƚƚ teche the a play at the bokelere
His brother hym ansuerd and seyd by seint Richere
While that pesteƚƚ is in thy hond I wiƚƚ come no nere
Brother I wiƚƚ make thy pees and swer͗ by cⁱristes ore
Cast awey thi pesteƚƚ and wrathe the no more
I most nede seyd Gamelyn wrathe me at ones
For yow wolde make thy men̄ to breke my bones
Ne hadde I mayn ⁊and myght in my armes
To hold hem from me thei wold do me harmes
Gamelyn seid his brother be yow noȝt wrogħhe
For to see the haue harme me wer͗ fuƚƚ lothe
I ne did hit noght but for a fondyng
For to loken or yow be stronge ⁊and ert so ȝoing
Come a doıı̄un þan to me ⁊and graunt me my bone
Of a thyng I wiƚƚ the axe ⁊and we shuƚƚ saughtel sone
Downe than come his brother that fekiƚƚ was ⁊and feƚƚlle
And was ryȝt sore aferd of the pestelle
He seid brother Gamelyn axe me thy bon
And loke yow me blame but I hit gᵃraunt the
Than seid Gamelyn brother ywysse
And we shuƚƚ be at one yow most gᵃraunte me this
Alle that my fader me byquatħ while that he was alyve
Thow most do me hit haue ȝif we shuƚƚ not stryve
That shalt haue gamelyn Iswere by cⁱristes ore
Alle that thi fader the bequatħ þogħ yow wolde haue more
Thy londe that lythe leye wele hit shaƚƚ be sowe
And thyn houses reysed vp that ben̄ leide fuƚƚ lowe
Thus seid the knyght to gamelyn wᵗith mouthe
And thoght on falsnesse as he wele couthe
The knyght thoght on treson ⁊and gamelyn on none
And went ⁊and kyssed his brother ⁊and whan þei wer͗ at one
Alas ȝong Gamelyn no thyng he ne wyst
With suche fals treson̄ his brother hym kyst
Lythen ⁊and lysteneth and hold youre tong
And ȝe shuƚƚ here talkyng of gamelyn the ȝong
There was ther besyden cried awrastelyng
And therfore ther was sette a Rame ⁊and arynge
And gamelyn was in wille to wende þ̉erto
For to preuyn his myght what he coude do
Brother seid Gamelyn by seint Richere
Thow most lene me to nyght a liteƚƚ coursere
That is fresshe for the sporres on̄ for to ryde
I most on a erand a liteƚƚ her͗ bysyde
By god seid his brother of stedes in my stalle
Go ⁊and chese the best spare non̄ of hem alle
Of stedes ⁊and coursers that stonden̄ hem besyde
And telle me good brother wheder yoᵘ wilt ryde
Here besyde brother is cried a wrastelyng
And ther shaƚƚ be sette a Ram ⁊and a ryng
Miche worschyppe hit were brother to vs alle
Might I the Ram ⁊and þe ryng bryng home to þⁱˢ hall
A stede ther was sadeled smertily and skete
Gamelyn did a pair of spores fast on his fete
He set his fote in the stirop the stede he bystrode
And toward the wrastlyng the yong child rode
Tho Gamelyn the yong was ryden out at gate
The fals knyȝt his brother lokked hit after thate
And besought IħuIhesu crist that is heuen kyng
He myght breke his nekke in that wrastelyng
As sone as gamelyn come ther the place was
He light doun̄ of his stede ⁊and stode on the gras
And there he herd a frankelen wele away syng
And bigan bitterly his handes for to wryng
Good man̄ seid Gamelyn why makest yᵘou this far͗e
Is there no man̄ that may ȝow helpe out of care
Alas seid this frankelen that euer was ybore
For two stalworth sones I wene that I haue lore
A champion is in the place that hath wroght me sorwe
For he hath slayn my two sōnnes but ȝit god hem borwe
I wiƚƚ ȝif x līpound by IħuIhesu crist and moore
Wᵗith the nones that I fond a man̄ to handel hȳm sore
Good man̄ seid Gamelyn wilt yᵘou wele done
Hold myn hors while my man̄ drawe of my shone
And help my man̄ to kepe my clothes ⁊and my stede
And I wiƚƚ in to the place to loke ȝif I may spede
By god seyd the frankelen̄ hit shaƚƚ be done
I wiƚƚ my self be thy man̄ to draw of thy shone
And wende yᵘou in to the place IħuIhesu cⁱriste the spede
And drede the not of thi clothes ne of thi goode stede
Barefoot ⁊and vngird Gamelyn in cōmme
Alle that were in the place hede of hy nōmme
How he durst auntre hym to done his myght
That was so doghty a champyon īn wrastlyng ⁊and īn fight
Vp sterte the champioıı̄un raply anoone
Toward yong Gamelyn he bigan to gon
And seid who is thy fader ⁊and what is thy sir
Forsoth yow ert a foole that yoᵘ come here
Gamelyn ansuerd the champion tho
Yow knew wele my fader while he coude go
While he was alyve by seynt martyn
Sir Iohn̄ of Bondeux was his name ⁊and I gamelyn
Felaw seyd the champion so mote I thryf
I knew wele thi fader whilest he was a lyf
And thy self gamelyn I wiƚƚ that yᵘou hit here
While yow were a yong boy a miche shrew yᵘou were
Than seid Gamelyn and swore by cristes ore
Now am I elder waxe yow shalt fynd me more
By god seid the champion welcome mote yᵘou be
Come yow ones in my honde yᵘou shalt neuer the
Hit was wele with in nyght ⁊and þe mone shone
Whan Gamelyn ⁊and the champion to gedr͗e can gone
The champion cast tornes to Gamelyn that was prest
And Gamelyn stode ⁊and badde hym done hys best
Than seid Gamelyn to the champion
Thow art fast aboute to bryng me adoun̄
Now I haue proued mony turnes of thyn
Thow most he seid proue on or two of myn
Gamelyn to the champion ȝede smertly anone
Of aƚƚ the turnes that he coutħ he shewyd but one
And kast hym on the left syde that the rybbes brake
And ther to his oone arme that ȝaf a grete crake
Than seid gamelyn smertly anoone
Shaƚƚ hit behold for a cast or ellys for none
By god seid the champion whethir hit be
He that cometh in thi hond shaƚƚ he neủer the
Than seid the Frankelen that had his sōnnes thre
Blessed be yow gamelyn that euer thow bore wer
The Frankelen seyd to the champioıı̄un of hȳm stode hȳm no ey
This yong Gamelyn that taght the this pley
Aȝen ansuerd the champion þᵗat likyd no thyng wele
He is a lither maist̉er ⁊and his pley is ryȝt felle
Sithen I wrastled first hit is gone ȝore
But I was neủer in my lyf handeled so sore
Gamelyn stode in the place anon̄ wᵗith out serk
And seyd ȝif þ̉er be mo lete hem come to werk
The champion that payned hym to wirk sore
Hit semyth by his continaunce þᵗat he wil no more
Gamelyn in the place stode stiƚƚ as a ston̄
For to byde wrastlyng but ther come non̄
Ther was wᵗith gamelyn þᵗat wold wrastle more
For he handeled the champion so wonderly sore
Two gentil men̄ that ȝemed the place
Come to gamelyn god ȝif hym good grace
And seid to hym do on thi hosen ⁊and thi shone
For soth at this tyme this faire is don̄e
And than seyd Gamelyn so mote I wele fare
I haue not ȝet halfendele sold my ware
Tho seyd the champioıı̄un so brooke I my swere
He is a foole that ther of bietħ yᵘou sellest hit so dere
Tho seid the Frankelen þᵗat was in moche care
Felaw he seid whi lakkest yow this ware
By seint Iame in Galeys þᵗat mony a man̄ hath soght
Ȝet is hit to goode chepe þᵗat yow hast ybought
Tho þᵗat wardens were of that wrastlyng
Come ⁊and broȝt gamelyn þe Ram ⁊and þe ringe
And went with myche ioy home in þe mornyng
His brother sey where he come wᵗith the grete route
And badde shitt þe ȝate ⁊and holde hym with oute
The porter of his lord was sore agast
And stert anon̄ to the gate ⁊and lokked hit fas
Now Lythen ⁊and lyghten̄ bothe yong ⁊and olde
And ȝe shuƚƚ game of gamelyn the bold
Gamelyn come þ̉erto to haue cōmmen in
Than was hit shet fast with a pyn
Than seyd Gamelyn perter vndo þe ȝate
For a goode mānnes sone stond ther ate
Than ansuerd the porter ⁊and swere by goddes berd
Thow ne shalt gamelyn come in to this ȝerd
Thow lyxt gamelyn so brooke I my chynne
He smote the wigat with his fote ⁊and brake awey the pyn̄ne
Tho porter sey tho hit might no better be
He sette fote on herth and began̄ to fle
By my fay seid gamelyn that trauail is lore
For I am on fote as light as yᵘou haddest hit swore
Gamelyn ouer toke the porter ⁊and his tene wrake
And girt hym in the nekke that the bone brake
And toke hym by þat one arme ⁊and threw hȳm in a welle
Vij C Fadam hit was depe as I haue herd telle
Whan Gamelyn the yong þus had plaied his play
Alle that in the ȝerd were drownen hem awey
Thei dreden hym fuƚƚ sore for werke that he wroght
And for the fair company that he thider broght
Gamelyn ȝode to the ȝate ⁊and lete hit vp wyde
He lete in aƚƚ that gone wolde or ryde
And seid ȝe be welcome wᵗith outen ony greue
For we wiƚƚ be maistres here ⁊and axe no man̄ leve
Ȝosterday I left seyd yong Gamelyn
In my brother selar v tonne of wyne
I wiƚƚ not this company parten or twyne
And ȝe don̄ after me while any sope is þ̉erin
And ȝif my brother grutche or make foule chere
Other for spence of mete or drynk þᵗat we spend her
I am oure cator ⁊and bere oure alder purse

Vij ⁊and vij nyght gamelyn held his fest

Lordes seid Gamelyn wiƚƚ ȝe so hye
Alle the wyne is not ȝet dronke so brooke I mȳn ey
Gamelyn in his hert was fuƚƚ woo
Whan his Gestes toke hir leue from hym for to go

But bytaught god Gamelyn ⁊and good day
Thus maid Gamelyn his fest ⁊and broght hit wel to ende
And after his gestes toke leue to wende
Lithen ⁊and lighten ⁊and holdeth youre tong

Whan aƚƚ gestes wer͗e gon̄ how gamelyn was dight
Alle the while that Gamelyn held his mangery
His brother thoght on hym be wreke with his trechery
Tho Gamelynes gestes were ryden̄ ⁊and gone
Gamelyn stode at home allone frend had he none
Tho after feƚƚ sone with in a liteƚƚ stonde
Gamelyn was taken̄ ⁊and fuƚƚ herd ybounde
