div.l: Who occupieth the fyne of oure gladnesse
Herk this councele for thi sekernesse
Vppon̄ thi gladde day haue in mynde
The vnware woo or harme that cōmetħ behynde
For shortely to tellen̄ at oo worde
The sowndan̄ and the christen christen euerychone
Ben aƚƚ to hewe and stiked at borde
But hit were onely dame custance allone
This olde sowdonesse cursed krone
Hath with hir frendes don̄ this cursid dede
For she hir self wolde aƚƚ the cuntre lede
Ne ther was surrian̄ non̄ that was con̄nuertid
That of the councele of the sowndan̄ woot
That he nas aƚƚ to hewe or he astertid
And custance han thei take anoon̄ fote hoote
And in a shippe aƚƚ stereles god woote
Thei han hir sette and bidden̄ hir lerne sayle
Oute of surrie agaynwarde to ytale
A certen̄ tresour that she thider ladde
And soith to sayn vitaille grete plente
Thei han hir ȝeffen̄ and clothes eke she hadde
And forth she sayletħ in the salt see
O my custance fuƚƚ of benignite
O emꝑperours ȝong doghter dere
He þᵗat þᵗat is lorde oủer fortune be thy ster
She blissith hir hir and with fuƚƚ pitous voys
Vn to the crosse of crist thus seid she
O clere o welfuƚƚ auter . holy croys
Rede of the lambes bloode fuƚƚ of pite
That wesshe the worlde fro the olde iniquite
Me fro the fende and from his clawes kepe
That day that I shaƚƚ drenche in the depe
Victorious tree ꝓproteccion̄ of trew
That onely worthy were for to bere
The kyng of heuen with his wondes newe
The white lambe that hurte was with a spere
Flemer of fendes out of hym ⁊and here
On whiche thi lyues feithfully extenden̄
Me kepe and ȝif me might my lyf to amenden̄
Ȝeres ⁊and daies fleet this creature
Thorgħ out þe see of grece vn to þe strayte
Marrok as hit was hir auenture
O many a sory mele may she bayte
After hir deth fuƚƚ ofte may she wayte
Or that the wilde wawes wiƚƚ hir dryve
Vn to the place ther she shaƚƚ arryve
Men mighten̄ axen whi she was not slayn
Eke at fest who mighte hir body safe
I ansuere to that demaunde agayn
Who saued danyel in the horrible cave
Ther euery wight . save he . maister or knawe
Was with the leon̄ fret or he sterte
No wight but god . that he bare in his hert
God lyst to shewe his wonderfuƚƚ myracle
In her for she shuld seen̄ his mighty werkes
Crist whiche that is to eủery harme triacle
By certen menes oft as knowe clerkes
Dothe thyngꝭes for certen̄ ende that fuƚƚ derk i
To mannes wytte that for ignoraunce
Ne can̄ noght knowe his prudent purueance
Now syn she was noght at the fest y slawe
Who kept hir fro the drenchyng in þe see
Who kept Ionas in the fisshes mawe
Tiƚƚ he was spowted vp at Nyniue
Wele may men̄ know hit was no wight but he
That kepte þᵉ þᵉ pepuƚƚ ebrayk from drenchyng
With drie feet thurgħ oute the see passyng
Who bad the foure spiritez of tempest
That pouer han̄ bothe to annoyen̄ lond ⁊and see
Bothe nortħ and soutħ and also west ⁊and est
Anoieth neither see land þan̄ house . ne þan̄ house . ne tree
Sothely the co͒mmaundᵘure of that . was he .
That fro the tempest ay this wo͒mman̄ kept
As wele whan̄ she woke as whan̄ she slept
Where might this wo͒mman̄ mete or drynk haue
Thre ȝeere and more how lastitħ here vitaile
Who fedde the marie egipcian̄ in the caue ?
Or in deserte none no none but crist sanz faile
V thousand folk hit was as grete m̉ervaile
With loves v and fisshes two to fede
God send his foyson̄ at hir grete nede
She driuetħ fortħ in to oure occian̄
Thorugħ oute oᵘur oᵘur wilde see tiƚƚ at the last
Vnder an holde that nempnen̄ nemene nempnen̄ nemene I ne can̄
For in Northumberlond the wawes wawe wawes hir caste
And in the sand hir shippe stiked so so fast
That thens wolde hit noȝt of aƚƚ a tyde
The wille of crist was ther she shuld abyde
The constable of the casteƚƚ down̄ is fare
To seen̄ this werk and aƚƚ the shippe he souȝt
And fond this wery wōmman̄ fuƚƚ of car
He fonde also the tresoure that she brought
In hire langage mercy she be sought
The lyf oute of hir body for to wynne
Hir to delyuer of woo that she was In
A maner a latyn corupt was hir speche
But algates therby was she vnderstounde
The constable whan̄ hym lyst no lenger seche
This wofuƚƚ wōmman̄ brought he to the londe
She knelith doun̄ and thanketħ goddes sonde
But what she was . she wold no man̄ say
For foule ne fair þougħ that she shuld deye
She seid she was so mased in the see
That she forgate hir mynd be hir treutħhe
The constable of hir hath grete pyte
And eke his wyf that thei wepen̄ for reuthe
She was so diligent with outen̄ sleuthe
To serue ⁊and plese euericħ in the place
That aƚƚ hir louen̄ that loken̄ on hir face
The constable and dame Ermengeld his wyf
Were paynems and that contrey euery where
But Ermengeld loued hir right as hir lyf
And custance hath so longe soiorned there
In orisons with many a bitter tere
Tiƚƚ IħuIhesu hatħ conuertid thurgħ his gᵃrace
Dame Ermegeld constaublese wyfe wyfe of thilk place
In aƚƚ that lond dorste no cristen̄ rowte
Alle cristen̄ folk ben̄ fled fro that contre
Thurgh paynems that conquerde all all abowte
The plages of the Northe by land ⁊and by see
To wales fledde the cristianite
Of olde bretons duellyng in this Ile
Ther was hir refuyt for the meyne while
But was neuer cristen̄ bretons so exile
That there was was some in hir priuete
Honoured crist and hethen̄ folk begiled
And neigħ the casteƚƚ suche ther duellyd thre
That on of hem was blynde ⁊and myght not see
But hit were with thilk eyen of his mynde
With whiche men̄ seyn after þat ben̄ blynde
Bright was the sonne as in that a that a somers day
For whiche the constable ⁊and his wyf also
And custance han I take the righte wey
Toward the see a forlong wey or two
To pleyn and to romen̄ to and fro
And in her walk thre blynde men̄ thei mette
Croked ⁊and old with face and eyen y shette
In the name of crist cried this blynd bretoıı̄un
Dame Ermegeld ȝif me my my sight agayn
This lady wax affraied of the sown̄
Lest that hir housbond shortly to seyn
Wolde hir for cristes lovre love lore haue slayn
Tiƚƚ custance made hir bolde ⁊and bad hir werche
The wiƚƚ of crist as doughter of his chirche
The constable wax abasshed of that sight
And seid what amontetħ aƚƚ this fare
Custance ansuerd sir hit is cristes myght
That helpes folk oute of the fendes snare
And so ferfortħ she can̄ oure la dy we lady lawe declare
That she the constable or that hit was Eue
Conủerted and on̄ crist made hym byleve
This constable was no thing lord of this place
Of whiche I speke ther he custance fonde
But kept hit strongly mony a wynter space
Vnder alla kyng of aƚƚ Northūmberlande
That was fuƚƚ wyse and worthy of his hand
Agayn the scottes as men̄ may wele her
But turne I wiƚƚ agayn to my mater
Sathan that vs weytetħ euermore to begile
Saugħ of custance aƚƚ hir ꝑperfeccioıı̄un
And cast anon̄ how he myghte quyte hir while
And made a yong knyght that dwelte in þe toun̄
Loue hir so hoote of foule affeccioıı̄un
That verrely hym thought he shuld spille
But he of hir mighte ones haue his wille
He woweth hir but hit availeth noght
She wold do no synne by no wey
And for despit he compassed compasse compassed in his thought
To make hir on̄ shamefuƚƚ deith to deye
He waiteth whan̄ the constable was awey
And pⁱriuely vpon̄ a nyght he crept
In Ermengildes chambre while she slept
Wery for waked in hir orisons
Slepith custance and Ermengeld also
This knyght thurgħ sathanas temptacions
Alle softely is in to the bedde y go
And cut the throte of Ermengild a two
And leyd the blody knyf by dame custance
And went his wey . ther god ȝif hem myschance
Sone after cometħ this constable home agayn
And eke alla that kyng was of that londe
And saugħ his wyf dispitously y slayn
For whiche fuƚƚ oft he wept ⁊and wrong his honde
And in the bedde the blody knyf he fonde
By dame custaunce alas what myght she sey
For verrey woo hir wytte was aƚƚ awey
To kyng alla was tolde aƚƚ this meschaunce
And eke the tyme . ⁊and where . and in what wyse
That in a shippe was founden̄ this custaunce
As here byforne ȝe han herd hir deuis
The kynges herte of pite can̄ agrise agrise a rise
Whan̄ he see so benigne a creature
Falle in this caas and in mysauenture
For as the lombe toward his deith is broght
So stond this innocent byfore the kyng
This fals knyght that hath this tresoıı̄un wroght
Beritħ hir on hond that she hath do this thyng
But natheles ther was grete mornyng
Among the peple and sey þei can̄ not gesse
That she hadde don̄ so grete a wykkednesse
For thei han seyn her so vertuous
And louyng Ermengeld right as hir lyf
Of this bare wyttenesse euericħ in that hous
Saf he that Ermengeld slow wᵗith his knyf
This gentiƚƚ kyng hatħ caght a grete motyf
Of this wyttenesse and thoght he wold enquere
Depper in this caas and trewtħ for to lere
Alas custance yow hast no champioıı̄un
Ne fighte can you naught . so welewey
But he that for oure redempcioıı̄un
And bonde sathan̄ and leyde hym there he lay
So be thi strong champioıı̄un this day
For but ȝif criste vppon̄ the myracle kythe
With outen gilte yow shalt be slayn as swythe
She sitte her doun̄ on knees ⁊and thus she seide
Immortale god that sauest susanne
For fals blame and yoᵘ mercifuƚƚ maide
Marie I mene doughter of seint Anne
Byforne whose child angels song Osanne
Ȝif I be giltles of this felonye
My socour be for elles shaƚƚ I deye
Haue I not seen̄ som tyme a pale face
Among a prees of hym that hath be lad
Toward his deitħ where as hym gete no gᵃrac
div.fw: The Man of lawes tale .The nan of lawes tale
div.l: And suche a colour in his face he had
Men myght knowe his face that was bystad
Among aƚƚ the faces in that route
So stand custance and loketh hir aboute
O quenez lyvyng in ꝓprosꝑperytee
Duchessez and ȝe ladies euerychon̄e
Haue some reuth on hir aduersite
An Emꝑperours Emꝑperour Emꝑperours doughter standeth stand standeth allone
She hath no wight to whome to make hir mone
O bloode roiale that stondetħ in this drede
Fer ben̄ thi frendes at thy grete nede
This alla kyng hath such such compassioıı̄un
As gentiƚƚ herte is fulfylled of pyte
That frome his eyen ranne the water doun̄
Now hastiliche do fetche a book qᵈuod he
And ȝif this knyght wiƚƚ swere . how that she
This wōmman̄ slow ȝit wiƚƚ we we vs avise
Whome that we wold that shaƚƚ be our͗e Iustice
A breton̄ book wryten̄ with euᵃaungelies
Was fet . and on this book he swore anone
She giltyf was in the mene whiles
An hand hym smote vppon the nekke bone
That doun̄ he felle at ones as a ston̄e
And bothe his eyen brust oute of his face
In sight of euery body in that place
A voys was herd in generale audience
And seid you hast dysclandred giltles
The doughter of holy chirche in higħ p̉resence
Thow hast y don̄ ⁊and ȝet I moste holde my pees
Of this merveile agast was aƚƚ the prees
As mased folke þei stoden̄ euerichone
For drede of wreche saue custance allone
Grete was the drede and eke the repentaunce
Of hem that hadden wrong suspicion
Vppon̄ this sely Innocent custance
And for this myracle in conclusione
And by custance medicacione
The kyng and mony a nother in that place
Conuerted was thanked be goddes grace
This fals knyght was slayn for his vntrewthe
By iuggement of kynge kynge alla hastely
And ȝit custance hath of his deth grete reuthe
And after this IħsIhesu of his mercy
Made alla to to wedde fuƚƚ solempnely
This holy maiden̄ that is so bryght and shene
And thus hatħ criste made custance a quene
But who was wofuƚƚ . yf I shaƚƚ not lye
Of this weddyng . but donegelde ⁊and no mo ?
The kynges moder of tirannye
Hir thoghte hir cursed hert brast a two
She wolde noght hir son̄ hadde don̄ soo
Hir thoght a despyte that he shuld take
So straunge a creature vn to his make
Me lyst noght of the chaffe ne of the stre
Make so long a tale . as of the corne
What shulde I tellen of the roialte
Of þⁱˢ þⁱˢ mariage or whicħ cours gotħ beforne
Who blowetħ in trompe or in an horne
The fruyt of euery tale is for to sey
Thei ete and drynke daunce syng ⁊and pley
Thei gon to bedde as hit was skille ⁊and right
For þogħ that wyfes ben̄ fuƚƚ holy thinges .
Thei most take in in pacience a nyght
Suche maner necessaries as ben̄ plesynges
To folk that han weddyd hem with rynges .
And leye a lyte hir holynesse a syde
As for the tyme hit may non̄ other betyd
On hir he gate a knaue man knaue man child anone
And to a bisshop ⁊and his constable eke
He tok his wyffe to kepe . whan̄ he is gon̄
To scotland ward his foo men̄ for to sek
Now fair custance that is so humble ⁊and so so meke
So long is gon̄ with child til þat stile
She halt hir chambre abidyng at cristes wille
The tyme is cōmmen a knaue man knaue man child she bere
Mauricius at the font ston̄ thei hym calle
This constable doth fortħ come a messanger
And wrote to his kyng that clepid was alle
How that blysfuƚƚ tydengs is befalle
And other spedefuƚƚ tydings for to sey
He taketh the łletre ⁊and fortħ he gotħ his wey
This messanger to don̄ his auantage
Vn to the kynges moder rideth swythe
And salueth hir fuƚƚ fair in his langage
Madame qduod he ȝe may be glad ⁊and blithe
And thonketh god an hundreth thousand sithe
My lady þᵉ þᵉ quene hath childe with oute doute
To ioy ⁊and blisse of aƚƚ þⁱˢ þⁱˢ regne aboute
Loo here the łletres selyd of this thyng
That I mote bere with aƚƚ the hast I may
Ȝif ye wiƚƚ oght to youre to youre vn to youre son̄ þe kyng
I am youre ʆseruaunt boght nyght ⁊and day
Dame Dame Donegeld ansuerd as now at þis tyme nay
But here aƚƚ nyght I wiƚƚ þat you take þi rest
To morwe wiƚƚ I sey the the what me lest
This messanger dranke sadly ale ⁊and wyne
And stollen̄ weren̄ his łletres pryuely
Oute of his box . while he slept as a swyn̄e
And conterfetyd was fuƚƚ subtilly
And other letters wroght fuƚƚ synfull
Vn to the kyng directed directe directed of this mater
For his custaunce as ȝe shaƚƚ here
The łletre spak the quene delyuerd was
Of so orrible a fendlycħ creature
That in the casteƚƚ non̄ so hardy was
That ony while durste ther in endure
The moder was an Elf by auenture
Ycome by charmes or by sorcerie
And euery wight hateth hir companye
Woo was this kyng whan̄ he this łletre hadde seyn
But to no wight he tolde his sorwes sore
But of his owne hand he wrote agayn
Welcome the sonde of crist for euer more
To me that am now lerned in his lore
Lorde welcome be thi lust ⁊and þi plesaunce
Mi lust is put aƚƚ in thy ordinaunce
Kepith this child al be hit foule or fair͗e
And eke my wyf vn to myn home cōmmyng
Crist whan̄ hym lust may send me an eyre
More agreable than this is to my likenge
This łletre he seletħ priuely wepynge
Whiche to the messanger was take sone
And forth he gotħ þer is no more to done
O messanger fulfilled of dronkennesse
Strong is thi bretħ thi lymes faltren ay
And you bewreyest alle sekernesse
Thi mynde is lorne you iangelyst as a iay
Thi face is turned as as in a newe array
Ther dronkennesse regnetħ in ony rowte
Ther nys no councele hid with oute doute
O Donegeld I haue no englyssħ digne
Vn to thy malice and thy tyrannye
And þerfore to the fende I the resign
Late hym endyten of thy traytorye
Fy mansshyppe maniyshe mansshyppe maniyshe fy o nay by god I lye
Fy fendliche spiritte for I dar wele telle
Thogħ yow here walke . thi spirit is in helle
This messanger cōmmeth fro the kyng agayn
And at the kynges moders courte he lighte
And she was of this messanger fuƚƚ fayn
And plesed hym in aƚƚ that euer she myghte
He drank and wele his gerdeƚƚ vnder pighte
He slepitħ and he fnortetħ in his gyse
Aƚƚ nyght til the sōnne gan aryse ryse aryse
Eft were his łletres stollen̄ euerichon̄
And conterfetid łletres in this wyse
The kyng cōmmaundeth his constable anon̄
Vp peyne of hangyng on an higħ Iwyse
That he ne shuld suffer in no wyse
Custance witħ in in his regne for to abyde
Thre daies and a quarter of a tyde
But in the same shippe as he hir fonde
Hir and hir yong sone and aƚƚ hir gere
He shuld put ⁊and croude fro the londe
And charge hir þat she neuer eft come here
O my custaunce wele may thi gost haue fere
And slepyng in thi dreme ben in penaunce
Whan̄ donegeld cast al this ordinaunce
This messanger on̄ morwe whan̄ he wooke
Vn to the casteƚƚ halte þe nexte wey
And to the constable he the łletre tooke
And whan̄ that he this pytous łletre say
Fuƚƚ ofte he seide alas and weleawey
Lord crist qᵈuod he how may this łletre worlde łletre worlde endure .
So fuƚƚ of syn is mony a creature
O myghty god yf þat hit be thy wille
Sytħ yow art rightfully Iuge how may hit be
That yow wolt suffren Innocens to spylle
And wikked folk regnen in ꝓprosperite
O good custance alas so wo is me
That I mote be thy tourmentour or dey
On shames dethe ther is non̄ other wey remedye wey remedye
Wepen̄ botħ yong and olde in aƚƚ that place
Whan that the kyng this cursed łletre sente
And custance with a dedly pale face
The fertħ day toward hir shippe she wente
But natheles she taketh it it in goode entent
The wille of crist and knelyng in the stronde
Sche sayd welcome ay lorde be thy sonde
He that me kept fro the fals blame
While I was on̄ the londe amonges yow
He kan̄ me kepe frome harme ⁊and eke from shame
In þᵉ þᵉ salt see aƚƚ þoght I see not how
As strong as euer he was . he is right now
In hym trust I and in his moder dere
That is to me my sayle ⁊and eke my stere
Hir liteƚƚ child lay wepyng in hir arme
And knelyng . pytously to hym she seide
Pees litel so͒nne I wiƚƚ do the no harme
With that hir kerchef of hir hede she brayde
And ouer h iris is hir his liteƚƚ eyen she hit leyed
And in hir arme she lullitħ hit fuƚƚ fast
And in to heuen̄ hir eyen vp she cast
Moder (qᵈuod she) and mayde bright marie
Soth is hit that thurgħ wōmmānnes eggement
Mankynd was lorne and dampned ay to deye
For whiche thy child was on̄ croys y rent
Thy blysfuƚƚ eyen saugħ aƚƚ his tourment
Then is þᵉʳ þᵉʳ no comparisoıı̄un betwen
Thy woo and any woo man̄ may sustene
Thou saugħ thy sone y slayn beforn thy eyen
And ȝet ȝow lyueth my litel child ꝑparfay
Now lady bright to whome aƚƚ wofuƚƚ crien
Thow glorie of wōmmanhede . yow fair may .
Thow hauen̄ of refute bright sterre of day .
Rewe on my childe that of thy gentilnesse
Rewest on euery rewfuƚƚ in destresse
O liteƚƚ child allas what is thy gilte .
That neuer wroghtest synne as as ȝit ꝑparde
Why wiƚƚ thyn harde fader haue the spylt ?
O mercy dere . constable qᵈuod she
As lat my liteƚƚ child dwelle her͗e wᵗith the
And ȝif yow darst noght saven̄ hym for blame
So kisse hym ones in his faders name
Ther witħ she loketħ bakwarde to the londe
And seid fare wele housbond rewthles
And vp she ryste and walketħ down̄ the stronde
Toward the shyppe hir foloweth aƚƚ the prees
And euer she preietħ hir child to holde his pees
And taketh hir leve and with an holy entent
She blyssetħ hir and in to the shyppe she went
Vitayled was the shippe hit is no drede
Habundantly for hir fuƚƚ long space
And other necessaries that shuld nede
She had y nowe heried by goddes gᵃrace
For wynde ⁊and wedir almyȝty god purchace
And bryng her home I can no better say
But in the see she dryueth forth hir way
Alla the kyng cometh sone after this
Vn to his casteƚƚ of the whiche I tolde
And axed wher his wyf and his child is
The constable gan̄ aboute his hert cold
And pleynly al the maner he hym tolde
As ȝe han herd . y kan̄ telle hit no better
And sheweth the kyng his seal ⁊and his łletre
And seyd lorde as ȝe cōmmaunded me
Vppon̄ peyne of detħ so haue I don̄ certeyn
This messanger tourmentid was til he
Moost by knowen̄ and tellen̄ platte ⁊and playne
Frome nyght to nyght in what place he had leyn
And thus bi with and subtil enqueryng
Ymagyned was by whome this harme gan̄ spryng
The hond was knowen̄ that the łletre wroote
And aƚƚ the venym of this cursid dede
But in what wyse certenly I noote
The effecte is this that alla oute of drede
His moder slow that may men̄ planely rede
For that she traytour was to hir legeaunce
Thus endeth olde donegeld with a a meschaunce
The sorwe that this alla nyght and day
Maketh for his wyf and for his child also
Ther is no tonge that hit telle may
But now I wille vn to custance go
That fletetħ in þe see in peyne and woo
V ȝeere and more as likede cristes sonde
Or that hir shippe apꝓprochede vn to londe
Vnder an hethen̄ casteƚƚ at laste
Of whiche the name in my text noȝt I fynde
Custance and eke hir child the see vp cast
Almyghty god that saueth aƚƚ mankynde
Haue on custance ⁊and hir child some mynde
That fallen̄ is in hethen̄ hond eft sone
In poynt to spille . as I shaƚƚ telle ȝow sone
Doun̄ from the casteƚƚ cometh ther mony a wight
To gawren̄ on this shippe and on̄ custanc
But shortely fro the casteƚƚ on a nyght
The lordes styward . god ȝif hym meschaunce .
A theef that had renyed oure creance .
Come in to the shippe allone . and seyd he sholde
Hir lēmman be . wher so she wolde or nolde
Woo was this wretched wo͒mman̄ tho bigon̄
Hir childe cried and she cried pytously .
But blisfuƚƚ marie help hir right anone
For with hir strogelyng wele and myghtely
The theef feƚƚ ouer borde aƚƚ sodanly
And in the see he dreynt for vengeaunce
And thus hath crist vnwe͒mmed kept custance
O foule lust of licherie loo thyn ende
Nat onely that yow fayntest mānnes mynde
But verrely yow wolte his body body shende
The ende of thi werk or of thi lustes blynde
Is complenyng . how many oon may men̄ fynde
That nought for wreek som tyme but for thentent
To don̄ his synne . ben̄ either slayn or shent ?
How may this wikked wo͒mman̄ han̄ the strengħ
Hir to defende agayne this renegat ?
O golias vn mensurable on̄ lenghe
How myght Dauid make the so matte
So yong and of armure so desolate
How durste he loke vppon̄ thi dredfuƚƚ face
Wele may men̄ seen hit was but goddes gᵃrace
Who ȝaf Iudith corage or hardinesse
To slen̄ hym hym Olefernes in his tente
And do delyuer oute of wretchidnesse
The peple of god I sey for this entent
That right as god spirit and vigor sent
To hem . and saued hem out of meschance
So sent he myght and vigor to custanc
Forth gotħ hir shyppe thorw on̄ the narwe moutħ
Of Iubaltar and septe dryuyng ay
Som tyme west and som tyme nortħ ⁊and soutħ
And som tyme est fuƚƚ many a wery day .
Tiƚƚ cristes moder . blessid be she ay .
Hath shapen̄ thorugħ hir endeles godenesse

l.hi: To make an ende of aƚƚ hir hevynesse

div.l: Now late vs stynt of custance but a throwe
And speken̄ we of the Romeyn Emꝑperour
That oute of surrie hatħ by łletres knowe
The slaughtre of crysten folk and dishonoure
Done to his doughtir by a fals traytoure
I mene the cursede wikked sowdonesse
That at the fest lete slen̄ botħ more and lesse
For whiche this Emperour hatħ sent anone
His senatour with roiale ordinaunce
And other lordes god woote mony oon͗e
On surriens to taken̄ higħ vengeaunce
To brenne slen̄ ⁊and bryng hem to meschaunce
Fuƚƚ mony a day but shortly this is þe ende
Homeward to Rome þei shapen̄ hem̄ to wende
This senatour repayretħ with victorie
To Rome warde saylyng fuƚƚ rially .
And mete the shippe dryuyng as seitħ the story .
In whiche custaunce sitteth fuƚƚ pitously
No thing ne knew he what she was ne why
She was in sucħ array . ne she nyl sey
Of hir estate þogħ she shuld dey
He bryngeth hir to Rome ⁊and to his wyfe
He ȝaf hir and hir yong sone also
And with the senatour she lad hir lyfe
Thus can̄ oure lady brynge oute of woo
Wofuƚƚ custance and mony other mo
And long tyme duelletħ she in þᵗat place
In holy werkes euere as was hir grace
The senatours wyf hir awnte was
But for aƚƚ that she knew hir neủer þe more
I wiƚƚ no lenger tarien̄ in this caas
But to kyng Alla whiche I spake of yore .

l.seg: That hade such sorowe . as I said be fore .

div.l: I wiƚƚ retorne and lene I wiƚƚ custaunce
Vnder the senatour gouernaunce
Kyng alla whiche that hadde his moder slayn
Vppon̄ a day felle in suche repentaunce
That ȝif I shortely tellen̄ shaƚƚ and playn
To Rome he cometħ to receyue his penaunce
And put him in the popes ordinance
In hie ⁊and lowe . and IħuIhesu criste be soughte
For in his wikked werkes that he wroughte
The fame anoon̄ thurgħ Rome town̄ is born̄
How alla kyng shaƚƚ comen̄ on̄ pilgrimage
By herberiours that wenten̄ hym byforn̄
For whiche the senatour as was vsage
Rode hym ageyn and mony of his lynage
As wele to shewen̄ his hie magnificence
As to don̄ any kyng a reuerence
Grete chere dotħ this noble senatour
To kyng alla and he to hym also
Eueriche of hem dotħ other grete honoure
And so byfeƚƚ that in a day or twoo
This senatour is to kyng alla goo
To fest and shortely ȝif I shaƚƚ not lye
Custance sōnne went went in his cumpanye
Som men̄ wolde seyn at requeste of custance
This senatour hatħ ladde þis child to feste
I may not tellen̄ euericħ circumstance
Be as be may ther was he at the the leste
But sothe is this that at his moders hest
div.note:
A Cader va Che troppo salle Roger le satraungi
quel Che sara sara
div.l: Beforn̄ alla duryng the metes space
div.note:
Peter lowthes yt is not true that you haue said
nor honest in my symple Demaund
But turne youʳ game that you haue plaid
and the wynder shalbe the owner
This note is written vertically in the outer margin.
div.l: The child stode . lokyng in the kynges face
This kyng alla hath of the child grete wonder
And to the senatour he seid anon̄
Whoos is that fair child that stondetħ yonder
I note . qᵈuod he . by god and by seint Iohn̄
A moder he hatħ but fader hatħ he non̄ .
That I of woote and shortely in a stounde
He tolde alla how that this child was founde
But god woote qᵈuod this senatour also
So vertuous a lyvere in my lyfe
Ne sawe I neuer as she . ne herde of moo
Of wordely wōmman̄ mayden̄ . wydowe wydowe ne of wyfe
I dar wele seyn she had lever a knyfe
Thorw oute hir brest . than̄ ben̄ a wōmman̄ wykke
Ther is no man̄ couthe bryng hir to that prykke
Now was thes child as lyke to custaunce .
As possible as is a creature to be
This alla hatħ the face in remembᵃraunce
Of dame Custaunce and ther on̄ mused he
Ȝif that the childes moder were augħ she
That is his wyf and pⁱriuely he sighte
And spedde hym fro the table that he myghte
ꝐParfay he thoght the fantome is in my hede
I ought demen̄ of skilfuƚƚ Iuggement
That in the salt see my wyf is dede
And afterward his his he made his argument .
What woote I . ȝif that crist hath hider sent
My wyf by see . as wele as he hir sent
To my countre fro thens that she was went
And after anon̄ home with the senatour
Gothe alla for to seen̄ this wonder chance
This senatour dotħ alla grete honoure
And hastily he sente after Custance
But truste wele hir lust not to daunce
Whan̄ that she wyst wherfore was that sonde
Vnnetħ vpon her feete she myght stonde
Whan̄ alla saugħ his wyf faire he hir grete
And wept that hit was reutħ for to see
For at the ferst loke he on̄ hir sette .
He knew wele verrely that hit was she
And for sorwe as dombe standeth stand standeth as a tre
So was hir herte shet in hir distresse
Whan̄ she remembred his vnkyndnesse
Twyes she swoned in his owne sight
He wepetħ and hym excusede pitously
Now god qᵈuod he and his halwes bright
So wysly on̄ my soule as haue mercy
That of youre harme as giltles am I
As is Maurice my son̄ so lyk ȝoure face
Elles the fende me fetche oute of this place
Long was the sobbyng and the bitter peyne
Or that his wofuƚƚ herte mighte cesse
Grete was the pyte for to here hem pleyne
Thurgħ whiche pleyntes gan̄ hir wo encrese
I pᵃray ȝow aƚƚ my laboure to relesse
I may not tellen̄ hir woo vn tiƚƚ to morwe
I am so wery for to speke of hir sorwe
But finally whan̄ the sothe is wyste
That alla giltles was of hir woo
I trowe an hundretħ tymes ben̄ thei kyste
And suche a blisse is ther bytuyx hem two
That save the Ioy . that lastethe euer moo
Ther is non̄ like . þat ony creature
Hatħ seen̄ or shaƚƚ while the worlde may dure
Tho preyd she hir housbonde meekly
In relefe of hir long pytous peyne
That he wolde pᵃray hir fader specyally
That of his maieste he wolde encline
To vochesaue some day with hym to dyne
She preide him eke he shold be no weye
Vn to hir fader no worde of hir seye
Som men̄ wold seyn how that the child maurice
Doth this message vn to this Emꝑperour
But as I gesse alla was noȝt so nyce
To hym that was of so souereigne honoure
As he that is of cristen̄ folke the floure
Sent ony child but hit is bett̉er to deme
He went hym self ⁊and so hit may wele seme
This emꝑperour hatħ gᵃraunted gentilly
To come to dyner as he hym bysought
And wele rede he loked besyly
Vppon̄ this child and on̄ his doughter thoghte
Alla gothe to his In and as hym oghte
Arraied for this feste in euery wyse
As ferforthe as hys cōmmynge may suffice
The morwe come and alla can̄ hym dresse
And eke his wyfe this Emꝑperour for to mete
And forthe thei ride in ioy ⁊and in gladdenesse
And whan̄ she sawe hir fader in he strete
She light adoun̄ and fallitħ hym to feete
Fader qᵈuod she youre yong child Custance
Is now fuƚƚ clene oute of youre reme͒mbrance
I am ȝoure doghter custance qduod she
That whilom ȝe haue haue send vn to surrie
Hit am I fader that in salt see
Was put allone and dampned for to deye
Now goode fader now I ȝow mercy crie
Send me no more vn to none hethyness
But thonk my lorde here of his kyndenesse
Who can̄ the pytous Ioy tellen̄ alle
Bytwyx hem thre syn thei ben̄ thus ymette ?
But of my tale make an ende I shaƚƚlle
The day gost fast I wiƚƚ no lenger lette
This gladde folk to dyner thei hem sette
In ioy and blysse at mete I lete hem dwelle
A thousand folk more than̄ I can̄ telle
This childe Maurice was sithen̄ Emꝑperour
Made bi the pope ⁊and lyuede cristienly
To cristes chirche he ded grete honour
But I lete his story aƚƚ passen̄ by
Of custance is my tale specyaly
In olde Romen̄ gestes men̄ may fynde
Maurices lyfe I bere hit not in mynde
This kyng alla whan̄ he his tyme sawe
With his custance his holy wyf so swete
To Englond be þei co͒mmen̄ the right way
Where as the lyve in ioy and in quyete
But liteƚƚ while hit lastetħ I ȝow hete
Ioy of this worlde for tyme wiƚƚ noȝt abide
Fro day to nyght hit chaungeth as the tyde
Who lyued euer in suche delyte a day
That ne moved is is either conscience
Or ire . or talent of som kyn̄ affray
Ennevy or pride or passioıı̄un or offence
I ne say but for this ende this sentence
That lyteƚƚ while in ioy or in plesaunce
Lasteth the blysse of Alla with custaunce
For detħ that taketħ of hie ⁊and lowe his rent
Whan̄ passed was a ȝeer͗ euyn̄ as I gess
Oute of this worlde this kyng he hent
For whome custance hath fuƚƚ grete heuynesse
Now late vs preyen god his soule blysse
And dame custance finally to sey
Toward the toun̄ of Rome goth hir weye
To Rome is co͒mmen this holy creature
And fyndeth hir frendes hole ⁊and sounde
Now is she scaped aƚƚ hir auenture
And whan she hir fader hatħ yfounde
Down̄ on her knees falleth she to grounde
Wepyng for tendernesse in hert blithe
She herietħ god an C thousand sithe
In vertu ⁊and in holynesse ⁊and almesdede
Thei lyuen̄ aƚƚ and neuer a sondre wende
Tiƚƚ detħ deꝑparted hem this lyf thei lede
And faretħ now wele . my tale is at an ende
Now IħuIhesu crist that of his might may send
Ioye after woo . gouerne vs in his grace

l.hi: And kepe vs alle that ben̄ in this place

div.l: Owre oost vppon̄ his stiropes stoode anon̄
And seid goode men̄ herkenetħ eủerychon̄
This was a thrifty tale for the nones
Sir parissħ prest qᵈuod he for goddes bones
Telle vs a tale as was thi forward yore
I see wele that ȝe lerned men̄ in lore
Can moche goode by goddes dignite
The ꝑpersoıı̄un hym ansuerde bn̄enedicite
What eileth the man̄ so synfully to swere
Oure ooste ansuerd O Iankyn be ȝe there
I smelle a lollard in the wynde qᵈuod he
How goode men̄ qᵈuod oure ooste herkenetħ me
Abideth for goddes digne passion
For we shaƚƚ hane a p̉redicacione
This loller here wiƚƚ prechen̄ vs some what
Nay by my fader soule that shaƚƚ he nat
Seid the squier here shaƚƚ he not preche
He shaƚƚ no gospeƚƚ glosen̄ here ne teche
He leved aƚƚ in the grete god he
He wolde sowen̄ some difficulte
Or spryngen̄ cokkel in oure clene corne
And therfore oost I werne the beforn̄e
My ioly body shaƚƚ a tale telle
And I shaƚƚ clenken̄ ȝow so mery a belle
That I shaƚƚ waken̄ aƚƚ this companye
But hit shaƚƚ not ben̄ of philophie
Ne phislays ne termes queynte of lawe
Ther is but litel latyn in my mawe
At surray in the land of tartary
Ther duellyd a kyng that werriede Russie
Thorgħ whiche ther deid many a doghty man̄
This noble kyng was clepid cambiskan̄
Whiche in his tyme was of so grete he he renoun̄
That ther nas nowhere in no regioun̄
So excellent a lord in aƚƚ thyng
Hym lakkede noght that longed to a kyng
As of the secte of whiche that he was borne
He kept his lawe to whiche that he was sworne
And therto he was hardy wyse and riche
And pitous and Iust alwey yliche
Sothe of his word benigne ⁊and honorable
Of his corage as any centre stable
Yong fresshe and strong in armes desirous
As any bacheler of aƚƚ his hous
A fair ꝑperson̄ he was and fortunat
And kept alwey so roiaƚƚ estate
That ther was no where suche a noþ̉er man̄
This noble kyng this tartre Camkiskan̄
Hadde two sones on̄ Elcheca his wyf
Of whiche the eldest highte algarsyf
That other was clepyd camballo
A doughter had this worthy kyng also
That yongest was and highte canace
But for to telle yow aƚƚ hir beaute
Hit litħ not in my tong ne in my konnyng
I dar not vndertake so higħ a thing
Myn̄ englyssħ eke is insufficient
Hit most ben̄ a Rethor excellent
That coutħ his colours longyng for þᵗat arte
Yf he shuld hir discrie any parte
I am no suche I mote speke as I can̄
And so bifeƚƚ that this Cambyskan̄
Hatħ twenty wynter born̄ his diademe
As he was wonte fro ȝere to ȝere to deme
He lete the feste of his natyuyte
Doon̄ crien̄ thorugħ sarray his citee
The last Idus of marche after the ȝeere
Phebus the sonne fuƚƚ iolyf was ⁊and clere
For he was nye his exaltacioıı̄un
In Marces face and his Mansioıı̄un
In Aries the Colerik þe hote signe
Fuƚƚ lusty was the wedir and benigne
For whiche þe foules ayeins the sonne shene
What for the sesoıı̄un and the yong grene
Fuƚƚ lowde songe hir affeccions
Hem semed han̄ geten̄ hem ꝓproteccions
Ayein the swerde of wynter kene ⁊and cold
This cambiskan̄ of whiche I haue yow tolde
In roiale vestiment sittetħ vppon̄ his deys
With diademe fuƚƚ higħ in his palys
And halt his fest solempne and so riche
That in this worlde ne was there non̄ liche
Of whiche ȝif I shaƚƚ telle aƚƚ the array
Than̄ wolde hit occupie a someres day
And eke hit neditħ not to deuyse
At euery course the ordre of hir ʆseruice
I wiƚƚ not telle of hir stᵃraunge sewes
Ne of hir swannes ne of hir heron̄ sewes
Eke in the londe as tellen̄ knyghtes olde
There is som mete that is fuƚƚ deynte holde
That in this lond men̄ retche but smale
Ther nys no man̄ that may reporten̄ aƚƚlle
I wiƚƚ not tarien̄ yow for hit is pryme
And for hit no fruyt but losse of tyme
Vn to my first purpose I wiƚƚ haue my recorus
And so bifeƚƚ that after the thred cours
While that this kyng satte thus in his nobleye
Herkennyng his mynstralles hir thinges pleye
Beforn̄ hym at borde deliciously
In at the halle dore aƚƚ sodenly
Ther come a knyght vpon̄ a stede of bras
And in his hand a broode myrour of glas
Vppon̄ his thombe he hadde of gold a ryng
And by his side a naked swerd hangyng
And vp he ridetħ to the hie borde
In alle the halle ne was ther spoke a worde
For merveiƚƚ of this knyght hym to beholde
Fuƚƚ besily thei wayten̄ yong ⁊and olde
This stronge knyght that come thus sodenly
Aƚƚ armed saue his heed fuƚƚ richel
Salwed the kyng and quene ⁊and lordes alle
By ordre as thei seten̄ in the halle
With so higħ reuerence and obeisaunces
And wele in speche as in contenuances
That gaweyn with his olde curtesie
Thogħ he come agayne out of fayreye
Ne coude hym noȝt amende with no worde
And after this before the higħ borde
He with a manly voys seid his message
After the forme vsed in his langage
With oute vice of sillable or of łletre
And for his tale shuld seme the better
Accordant to his wordes was his chere
As techetħ arte of speche hem that hit lere
Aƚƚ be hit that I can̄ not sowne his stile
Ne can̄ not clymben̄ ouer so hye a stile
Ȝet sey I this that as to co͒mmne entent
Thus moche amountetħ aƚƚ that eủer he mente
Yf hit so be þat I haue it in my mynde
He seid the kyng of Arabie and of Inde
Mi lege lorde on̄ this solempne day
Salweth yow as he best can̄ or may
And sendetħ yow in honour of youre feste
By me that am redy aƚƚ at youre heste
This stede of bras that esily and wele
Can̄ in the space of a day naturele
This is to sey in xxiiij houres
Where so ȝow lust in drought or in shoures
Beren youre body in to euery place
To whiche youre herte wilneth for to pace
With outen̄ wem of yow thorugħ fowle ⁊and fayre
Or ȝif yow luste to fle as hie in the eyr
As dothe an egle whan̄ hym lust to sore
This same stede shaƚƚ bere yow euermore
With outen̄ harme tiƚƚ ȝe be there yow luste
Yogħ that ȝe slepen̄ on his bake or rest
And torne ayein with wrythyng of a pyn
He ȝat hit wroght coude fuƚƚ mony a gyn
He wated mony a constellacioıı̄un
Or he had don̄ this oꝑperacioıı̄un
And knew fuƚƚ mony a seel ⁊and mony a bonde
This myrour eke that I haue in my honde
Hatħ suche a myght þᵗat men̄ may in hit see
Whan̄ ther shaƚƚ falle any aduersite
Vn to youre regne or to youre self also
And openly who is youre frend or fo
And ouer aƚƚ this ȝif ony lady bright
Hath sette hir herte on̄ ony maner wight
Ȝif he be fals she shaƚƚ his treyson̄ se
His newe loue and aƚƚ his subtilite
So openly that ther shaƚƚ no thing hide
Wherfore ageyn this lusty somer tyde
This myrour and this ryng þᵗat ȝe may se
He hatħ sent to my lady canace
Yowre excellent doghter that is here
The vertu of this rynge yf ȝe wiƚƚ here
Is this that yf hir list hit for to were
Vpon̄ hir thombe or in hir purse hit bere
There is no foule that fletħ vnder the heuene
That she ne shaƚƚ vnderstounde his steuene
And knowe his menyng openly and pleyn
And ansuere hym in his langage ageyn
And euery gras that groueth vppon̄ roote
She shaƚƚ wele knowen̄ and whome hit wiƚƚ do bot
Aƚƚ be his woundes neủer so depe and wyde
This naked suerde that hongetħ by my side
Suche vertu hath that what man̄ so the smyte
Thurgh oute his armer hit wiƚƚ kerve ⁊and byte
Were hit as thikke as is a braunched oke
And what man̄ þat is woundyd with the stroke
Shaƚƚ neủer be hoole tiƚƚ that list of grace
To stroke hym with the platte in thilke place
There he is hurt this is a moche to seyn
Ȝe mote witħ the platte swerd agayn
Stroke hym in the wounde and hit wole close
This is a verrey sothe witħ outen̄ glose
Hit failetħ noght whiles hit is in youre holde
And whan̄ this knyght hath thus his tale ytolde
He ridetħ oute of the halle and doıı̄un he light
His stede whicħ that shone as sonne bryght
Stant in the courte stille as any stone
The knyght is to his chambre lad anone
And is vnarmed and to the mete ysette
This is to seyn the swerd ⁊and the myrour
And born̄ anone vn to hie toure
With certen̄ officers yordened þ̉erfore
And vn to canace this ryng is bore
Solempnely there she sitte at table
But sikerly with outen̄ any fable
The hors of bras that may not be remeved
He stonde as he were to the gronde yglewed
There may no man̄ oute of the place hit dryve
For non̄ engyn̄ of wyndas or poleue
And caus why for thei can̄ not the crafte
And therfore in the place thei han̄ hym lafte
Tiƚƚ that the knyght haue taght hem the Mane
To voyden̄ hym as ȝe shaƚƚ after here
Grete was the prees that swarmed to ⁊and fro
To gavren̄ on̄ this hors that stondeth so
For hit so hie was ⁊and so brode and longe
So wele ꝓproporciounde for to be stronge
Right as hit were a stede of lombardie
Ther with so horslyke and so quyke of eye
As hit a gentiƚƚ poleys courser were
For certes fro his taille vn to his eyre
Nature ne arte ne coude hym noȝt amende
In no degree as alle the peple wende
But euermore her most wonder was
How that hit coude gone and was of bras
Hit was of faireye as the peple semed
Diuerse folk diuersly demede
As many hedes as many wyttes þ̉er bene
Thei mormered as downe as swarme of bene
And made skilles after hir fantasies
Rehersyng of the olde poetries
And seid hit was lyke the pegasee
The horse that had wynges for to flee
Or elles hit was the grekes hors synoıı̄un
That broght troye to destruccioıı̄un
As men̄ in these olde gestes rede
Myn̄ herte qᵈuod oone is euer more in drede
I trowe som men̄ of armes ben̄ ther In
That shapen̄ hem this cite for to wynne
Hit were right goode that aƚƚ suche thing were knowe
An other rowned to his felaw lowe
And seid he lietħ for hit is rather like
An apparence ymade by some Magike
As iogelours pleyn at these festes gret
Of sondry thoghtes thus thei iangle ⁊and trete
As lewde peple demetħ co͒mmunely
Of thinges that ben̄ more made subtilly
Than thei kan̄ in here lewdenesse comp̉rehende
Thei demen̄ gladly to the baddere ende
And som of hem wondren̄ on the myrour
That born̄ was vp vn to the maist̉er toure
How men̄ mighte in hit sucħ thinges se
An other ansuer and seid hit myght wele be
Naturally by composicioıı̄uns
Of angels and of sley refleccioıı̄uns
And seid that in Rome was sucħ oone
Thei spake of Alicen̄ and Vitulon̄e
And of Aristotle that writeth in hir lyues
Of queynte myrours and of ꝑperspectyues
As knowen̄ thei that han hir bokes herde
And other folke han̄ wondrede on̄ the swerde
That wold ꝑparte thurgħ euery thing
And fiƚƚ in speche of thelophus the kyng
And of Achilles for his queynte spere
For he couthe with hit bothe hele ⁊and dere
Right in suche wise as men̄ may with the swerd
Of whiche ryȝt now ȝe haue youre seluen here
Thei speken of sundry hardyng of metaƚƚ
And speke of medicynes ther witħ aƚƚ
And how ⁊and whan̄ hit shuld harded be
Whiche is vnknowen̄ algate vn to me
Tho spake thei of canaces ryng
And seiden̄ aƚƚ that suche a wonder thing
Of crafte of rynges herd þei neủer noon̄
Saue that he Moises and kyng salamon̄
Hadde a name of connyng in sicħ art
Thus seyn thei peple and drawen̄ hem a parte
But natheles some seid þat hit was
Wonder to maken̄ of fern asshen̄ glas
And hit is glas noȝt alike asshen̄ of fern
Therfore cesseth her Iangelyng and hir wonder
As sore wonder some on̄ caus of thonder
On ebbe ⁊and floode on̄ gossomer and on̄ myst
And alle thing til the caus is wist
Thus iangelyn thei and demen̄ and deuyse
Tiƚƚ that the kyng gan̄ fro his borde arise
Phebus hast laft the angle m̉erydionale
And ȝet ascendyng was the best roiale
The gentil leon̄ with his aldrian
Whan̄ that this kyng cambuskan̄
Roose fro his bord ther as he sat ful hie
Byforne hym gothe the lowde mynstralcye
Tiƚƚ he come tiƚƚ his chambre of paramentis
There as thei sownen̄ diuerse instrume͒ntis
That is lyke an̄ heuen̄ for to here
Now dauncen lusty venus children̄ dere
For in the fisshe hir lady sat fuƚƚ hie
And loketh on̄ hem with an frendly eye
This noble kyng is sette vppon̄ his trone
This straunge knyght is set to hym fuƚƚ sone
And on̄ the daunce he gotħ with Canace
Here is the reveƚƚ and the iolyte
That is not a duƚƚ man̄ to deuyse
He moste can̄ knowe loue and his ʆseruice
And ben̄ a festlicħ man̄ as fressħe as May
That shulden̄ to ȝow deuysen̄ sucħ array
Who coutħ tellen̄ yow the forme of daunces
So vncoutħ and sucħ fresshe continaunce
Suche subtil lokynges and dissymilynges
For drede of iolosie mennes aꝑperceyuynges
No man̄ but launcelot and he is dede
Therfore I passe ouer aƚƚ this lustyhede
I sey nomore but in this iolinesse
I lete hem til men̄ to soꝑper hem dresse
The stuarde bid spices for to hye
And eke the wyn̄ in alle this melodie
The vssheres and the squyers ben̄ Igon̄e
The spices ⁊and the wyn̄ is comen̄ anone
The ete ⁊and dranke ⁊and whan̄ this had an ende
Vn to the temple as reson̄ was thei wende
Thei seruise doon thei soupen̄ aƚƚ by day
What nedeth yow rehersen̄ hir array
Eche man̄ wote wele þᵗat at a kynges feste
Hatħ plente to the most ⁊and to the leste
And deyntes moo than̄ be in my co͒nnyng
And after soꝑper gothe this noble kyng
To seen̄ this hors of bras with aƚƚ the route
Of lordes ⁊and ladies hym aboute
Suche wonderyng was ther on̄ this hors of bras
That sithen the grete sege of troy was
Ther as men̄ wondred on̄ an hors also
Ne was ther suche a wondering as was tho
But finally the kyng asketħ the knyght
The vertu of this courser ⁊and the might
And preide hym to telle his gouernaunce
The hors anone gan̄ to trippe ⁊and daunce
Whan̄ that this knyght layde honde vpon̄ his reyne
And seide sir ther is nomore to seyn
But whan̄ thou list to riden̄ any where
ve mote thrille a pyn stant in his eire
Whiche I shaƚƚ telle yow betwene vs tw
Ȝe mote nempne hym to what place also
Or to what cuntre that ȝow list to ride
And whan̄ ȝe come there as you list to abide
Bid hym to descende and trille an other pyn
For ther In lietħ theffecte of aƚƚ þᵗat gyn
And he wole descende ⁊and don̄ youre wille
And in that place he wole abide stille
Þogħ aƚƚ the worlde hadde þe contrary yswore
He shaƚƚ not thens be throwe ne ybore
Or ȝit yow list bidde hym thens gon̄
Thrille þis pyn and he wiƚƚ vanysshe anon̄
Out of the sight of euery maner wight
And come aȝein be hit day or nyght
Whan̄ than̄ you list to clepen̄ him agayn
In whiche agyse as I shaƚƚ to yow sayn
Betuyxen yow ⁊and me ⁊and that fuƚƚ sone
Ride whan̄ yow list ther is nomore to don̄e
Enformed whan̄ the kyng was of the knyght
And hath conceyued in his wytte a right
The maner and the forme of aƚƚ thing
Fuƚƚ glad ⁊and blithe the noble dogthty kyng
Repeyring to his reueƚƚ as biforn̄e
The brideƚƚ is in to the tour yborne
And kept among his Iuelles lief ⁊and dere
The hors vanysshed I note in what manere
Oute of hir sight ȝe gete nomore of me
But thus I lete in luste ⁊and iolyte
This Cambuskan̄ his lordes festeyng
Tiƚƚ wele nye the day bygan̄ to spryng
The norice of digestion the slepe
Gan̄ on̄ hem wynke ⁊and bad hem take kepe
That moche mete and labour wole haue rest
And with a galpyng mouthe hem alle he keste
And seid that hit was tyme to lye a doun̄
For bloode was in his dn͒ominacioıı̄un
Cherysshes blode natures frend qᵈuod he
Thei thanken̄ hym galpyng by two by thre
And euery wight gan̄ drawen̄ hym to his rest
As slepe hem bad thei take hit for the best
Hir dremes shulde not nowe be tolde for me
Fuƚƚ were hir hedes of fumosite
That causetħ dreme of whiche ther is no charge
Thei slepen̄ til hit was pryme large
The most ꝑparte but hit were Canace
She was mensurable as wy͒mmen̄ be
For of hir fader had she take hir leve
To go to reste sone after it was Eue
Hir list not appalled for to be
Nor on̄ the morwe vnfestlicħ for to se
And slepe hir first slepe ⁊and afterward awoke
For suche a ioy she īn her herte toke
Bothe of hir queynt ryng ⁊and of hir Myrour
That twenty tyme she changed hir colour
And in hir slepe right for imp̉ression̄
Of hir Myrour she had a vision
Wherfore ar that the so͒nne vp gan̄ glide
She clepid vp on̄ hir maistresse hir beside
And seid that hir list for to arise
These olde men̄ that ben̄ gladly wise
As is hir maistresse ansuerd hir anoon̄
And seid ma dame whider wolde ȝe be gon̄
Thus erly for folk ben̄ aƚƚ in reste
I wiƚƚ qᵈuod she arise for me leste
No lenger slepen̄ but walken̄ abowt
Hir maistresse clepeth wȳmen̄ a grete rowte
And vp the risen̄ wele ten or twelfe
Vp riseth fressħ Canace hir selfe
As rody and brighte as thei the yonge sonne
That in the Rame is x degres vp ronne
Noon̄ heigher was he whan̄ she redy was
And forth she walketħ esily a paas
Arraied after the lusty seson̄ sote
Lightly for to pley and walke on̄ fote
Not but v or vj of hir menȝe
And in a trencħ fer in the parke gotħ she
The vapour whiche that fro erthe glode
Maketh the sonne to seme rody ⁊and brode
But natheles hit was so fair a sighte
That hit made aƚƚ hir hertes to lighte
What for the seson̄ and the morwenyng
And for the foules that she herd syng
For ryȝt anoon̄ she wiste what that thei mente
Right by hir song and knewe aƚƚ hir entente
The knotte whi that euery tale is tolde
Ȝif hit be taried til lust be colde
Of hem that han̄ after herkened ȝore
The fauour passeth euer lenger more
For fuƚƚsūmnesse of ꝓprolixite
And bi this same reson̄ thanketħ me
I shulde vn to the knotte condescende
And maken̄ of hir walkyng sone an ende
A mydde a tree for dry as white as chalk
As canace was pleynge in hir walke
Ther set a faucone ouer hir heede fuƚƚ hie
That with a pitous voys so gan̄ to crie
That alle the wodde resede of hir cri
And beten had hir self so pitously
With bothen̄ hir wynges til the rede bloode
Ran̄ endlong the tre there as she stode
And in euer in oone she criede alwey ⁊and sight
And with hir beke hir selfen̄ so she pight
That ther was no tigre ne cruel best
That duelleth either in wodde or in forest
That nolde han wept ȝif he wepe couth̄e
For sorwe of hir she shrighte alwey so louthe
For ther nas neuer ȝit man̄ on̄ lyve
If that I coude a Favcon̄ wele discryve
That herde of suche an other of fairnesse
As wele of plumage as of gentilnesse
Of shappe of aƚƚ that myght rekened be
A Favcon̄ ꝑperegryne than semed she
Of fremde londe and euer more as she stoode
She swonede now ⁊and now for lake of bloode
Tiƚƚ wele neigħ is she fallen̄ fro þe tree
This faire kynges doughter canacee
That on̄ hir fynger bare the queynte rynge
Thurgh whecħ she vnderstoode wele euery thing
That ony foule may in his ledne sayn
And coude ansuere hym in his ledne agayn
Hath vnderstond that this favcon̄ seyde
And wele neigħ for reuthe almost she deyde
And to the tree she gotħ fuƚƚ hastily
And on̄ this favcon̄ loketħ fuƚƚ pitously
And helde hir lappe abroode for wele she wist
The faucon̄ most falle from the twyste
Whan̄ that hit swownede nexte for lakke of blode
A longe while to wayte hir she stoode
Tiƚƚ at the last she spake in this manere
Vn to the hawke as ȝe shaƚƚ after her
div.note: Vnge Beƚƚ mo
div.l: What is the caus yf hit be for to telle
That ȝe bene in this furiale peyn̄ of helle
Quod canace vn to this hawke aboue
Is this for sorowe of deitħ or los of love
For as I trowe this bene causes two
That causetħ most a gentil hert woo
Or other harme hit nedetħ not to speke
For thei your selfe vppon̄ youre self yow wreke
Whiche that prouetħ wele that either Ire or drede
Moot ben̄ encheson̄ of youre crueƚƚ dede
Syn that I see noon̄ other wight yow chace
For love of god so dotħ youre self grace
Or what may be youre help for west nore est
Ne saugħ I neuer ar now no bryd ne best
That ferde with hym self so pitously
Ȝe slee me with youre sorwe verraly
I haue of yow so grete compassione
For goddes loue come from the tree adoun̄e
And as I am kynges doughter trewe
Yf that I verrely the causes knewe
Of youre disease yf hit lay in my myght
I wolde amende hit or that hit wer͗e nyght
As wysely help me grete god of kynde
And erbes shaƚƚ I right ynow fynde
To hele with youre hurtes hastily
Tho shrighte this faucon̄ ȝet more pitously
Than euer she dide and fille to grounde anon̄e
And lithe on̄ swone dede as any stone
Til canace hath in hir lappe hir take
Vn to that tyme she gan̄ of swowne awake
And after that she of swowne gan̄ abreide
Right in hir hawkes leodene thus she seid
That pitee rennetħ sone in gentil hert
Felyng his similitude in peynes smert
Is proued al day as men̄ may it see
As wele by werk as by auctoritee
For gentiƚƚ herte kepetħ gentilnesse
I se wele þat ȝe haue of my distresse
Compassioıı̄un my fair Canacee
Of verray wōmmanly benignite
That nature in youre principles hath sette
But for non̄ hope for to fare the bette
But for to obeie vn to youre hert fre
And for to maken̄ other be ware by me
As by the whelp chastised is the lyon
Right for that caus ⁊and for that conclusione
While that I haue a leyser and a space
Myn harme I wiƚƚ confessen̄ or I pace
And euery while þᵗat favcon̄ hir sorwe tolde
That other wept as she to water wolde
Tiƚƚ that the faucon̄ bad hir to be stille
And with a syke thus she seid hir tille
There as I was bredde allas that ilke day
And fostred in a roche of marbuƚƚ gray
So tenderly that no thing eyled me
I ne wist not what was aduersite
Til I coude flee fuƚƚ hie vnder the skye
Tho duelte a tercelet me fast by
That semed wele of aƚƚ gentilnesse
Al wer͗e fuƚƚ of treson̄ and falsenesse
Hit is wrapped vnder humble chere
And vnder hiew of troutħ ⁊and in sucħ maner
Vnder plesaunce and vnder besy peyne
That no wighte couthe han wende he coude feyn
So depe in grene he dyed his colour
Right as a serpent hide hym vnder flours
Tiƚƚ he may see his tyme for to bite
Right so this god of loues ypocrite
Doth so his cerimonies and obeisaunces
And kept in semblant al his obseruaunces
That sownetħ in to gentilnesse of loue
As in a tombe is aƚƚ the fair aboue
And vnder is the coors sucħ as ȝe wote
Suche was this ypocrite bothe colde ⁊and hoote
And in this wyse he serued his entent
That saue the fende no man̄ wist what he ment
Tiƚƚ he so long hadde wopen and compleyned
And meny a ȝeer his ʆseruice to me feyned
Til þat myn hert to pitous ⁊and to nyce
Aƚƚ Innocent of his crowned malice
For ferde of his detħ as thoght me
Vppon̄ his othes and his surete
Graunted hym loue vpon̄ this condicione
That eủermore my honour ⁊and my renon̄e
Were saued botħ pⁱriuey and aperte
This is to seyn that after his dissert
I ȝaf hym aƚƚ myn hert and myn thought
God wote and he that other wise nought
And toke his hert in chaunge of myn̄ for ay
But sotħ is seid go sithen mony a day
A trewe wight and a theef thinketħ not oone
And whan̄ he saw the thing so fer ygon̄e
That I gᵃraunted hym fully my love
In suche a gise as I haue seid aboue
And ȝiffen̄ hym myn trewe hert as fre
As he swore he ȝaf his herte to me
Anoon̄ this tigre fuƚƚ of dovblenesse
Fille on̄ his knees with so deuoute humbless
With hie reuerence and by his chere
So like a gentil louer of manere
So rauysshed as hit semed for þe ioy
That neuer Iason̄ ne paris of troy
Iason certes ne non̄ other man̄
Syn lameth was that alder first bigan̄
To louen two as writen folk byforn
Ne neuer sithe þe first man̄ was borne
Ne couthe man̄ be twenty thousand ꝑparte
Counterfete the sophymes of his arte
Ne were worthy to vnbocle his galoche
Ther dowblenesse or feynyng sholde apꝓproche
Ne so couthe thanke a wight as he did me
His manere was an heuene for to see
Til any wōmman̄ were she neủer so wise
So peynted he and kembetħ at poynt deuyse
As wele his wordes as his continaunce
And I so loued hir for his obeisaunce
And for the trougħ I demed in his herte
That yf so were that any thing hym smerte
Alle were hit neuer so lite and I hit wyste
Me thoght I felte dethe at myn̄ hert twyste
And shortely so ferfortħ this thing went
That my wille hath his willes Instument
This is to seyn my wille obeiede his wille
In alle thing as ferre as reson̄ fille
Kepyng the boundes of my worschippe eủermore
Ne neuer had I thing so lief ne leuere
As hym god wote ne neuer shaƚƚ no mo
This last lenger than̄ a ȝeere or two
That I supposed of hym no thing but goode
But finally thus at the last hit stood
That fortune wolde that he moste twynne
Oute of that place whiche that I was Inne
Where me was woo it is non̄ question̄e
I kan̄ not make of hit discripcione
For o thing dar I telle boldely
I knewe what is the peyn of deitħ therby
Suche harme I felte for he ne might beleue
So on̄ a day of me he toke his leue
So sorwfully eke that I wende werrely
That he had feled as moche harme as I
Whan̄ that I herde him speke ⁊and saw his hiewe
But natheles I thoght that he was so trewe
And eke that he repaiere shuld agayn
With in a liteƚƚ while sotħ to seyn
And reson̄ wolde eke that he most go
For his honour as oft happeth so
That I made vertu of necessite
And toke hit wele syn that hit most be
And I best mighte I hidde from hym my sorwe
And toke hym by the hond seint Iohn̄ to borwe
And seid thus lo I am yowres alle
Both suche as I haue be to yoᵘ ⁊and shaƚƚlle
What he ansuerd hit nedeth not reherse
Who can̄ seyn bet than̄ he who can̄ do werse
Whan̄ he hath aƚƚ wele seid than̄ hath he don̄e
Therforth behouetħ him a fuƚƚ long spone
That shaƚƚ eten with an fende thus herde I sey
So at the last he mote fortħ his wey
And fortħ he flietħ til he come there him liste
Whan̄ hit come him to pᵘurpose for to reste
I hadde he hadde thilke texte in his mynde
That alle thing repeyryng to his kynd
div.note:
I say wᵗith In ij yers owt clene
Yow say wᵗith In ij yers vs mai łlet more In
div.l: Gladeth hym self thus seyn men as I gesse
Men loued of kynde ꝓpropre newfangelnesse
As briddes done that men̄ in cage fede
For thoghe thei nyght and day take of hem hede
And strawe hir cage faire ⁊and softe as silke
div.note: Gladeth
div.l: And ȝeve hem sugre hony brede and mylke
Ȝet right anone as that is dore is vppe
He with his feete wiƚƚ sporne doun̄ his cuppe
And to the wodde he wole and wormes ete
So newfangele ben thei of her mete
And louen noueleries of ꝓpropre kynde
No gentilnesse of bloode may hem bynde
So ferde this tercelet alas the day
Þogh he were gentil borne fresshe ⁊and gay
And goodely for to seyn and humble ⁊and free
He sawe vppon̄ a tyme a kyte flee
And sodanly he louede this kyte so
Thus alle his loue is clene fro me go
And hatħ his trowthe falsed in this wyse
Thus hatħ the kite my loue in hir seruyse
And I am lorne witħ outen remedie
And witħ that worde this favcon gan to crie
And swowned eft in Canaces barme
Grete was the sorwe for that hawkes harme
That Canacee ⁊and alle hir wȳmmen made
They nyst how that thei myght þe favcon̄ glade
But canacee home beritħ hir in hir lappe
And softely in plastres gan̄ hir wrappe
There as she with hir beeke hadde hurte hir selfe
Now can̄ not Canace but herbes delve
Out of the grounde and maken̄ salves newe
Of herbes precious and fyne of hiewe
To helen with the hawke fro day to nyght
She dotħ hir besinesse and alle hir might
And by hir beddes hede she made a Meve
And couered hit with velowettes blewe
In signe of trewtħ that is in wōmen̄ sene
In whiche were peynted aƚƚ thes fals foules
As bene these tidifs tercelets ⁊and owles
Right for the despite were peynted hem byside
Pies on̄ hem for to crie and chide
Thus lete I Canace hir hawke kepyng
I wiƚƚ nomore as now speke of ryng
Tiƚƚ hit come eft to pᵘurpose for to seyn
How that this favcon̄ gate hir loue agayn
Repentaunte as the story telleth vs
By mediacion̄ of Camballus
The kynges sone of whiche I ȝoᵘ tolde
But hennes fortħ I wiƚƚ ꝓprocesse holde
To speken̄ of auentures and of batailes
That ȝet was neuer herd so grete mervailes
First wiƚƚ I telle ȝow of Cambuskan̄
That in his tyme many a cite wan̄
And after I wiƚƚ speke of Algarsyf
How that he wan̄ Theodora to his wyfe
For whome so ofte in grete ꝑperiƚƚ he was
Ne had he ben̄ holpen by the hors of bras
And after wiƚƚ I speke of Camballo
That faughte in listes with the bretheren̄ two
For Canace or þat he myght hir wynne
And there I left I wiƚƚ agayn begynne
Apollo whirletħ vp his chare so hie
Tiƚƚ that the god mercurius hows the slie
Explicit 2ᵃsecunda ꝑpar

div.l: IN feith squier þᵘ hast the wele yquytte
And gentilly . I prayse wele thi wytte .
Qd the merchaunte . consideryng thy ȝouthe .
So felyngly thow spekest sir I the allouthe
As to my dome there is non that is here .
Of eloquence that shall be thy pere .
For of thy speche I haue grete deynte
I haue a sone and by the trinite
I hadde leuer þan xxᵗⁱ pond worth of lond
Þogh hit right now were fallen in my hond .
He were a man of suche discrecion

I am a kyng hit sitte me noȝt to lye
