Hir ansuere she shal haue I vndertake
Lete vs nomore wordes make
For soth I wole no lenger ȝow contᵃrie
Now lete vs turne aȝayn to Ianuarie
That in this gardyn with this fair may
Syngeth full meryer than the popen Iay
Ȝow loue I best and shul and oþ̉er none
So longe aboute the Ales is he gone
Til he come agaynes thilk pirie
Where as this damyan sitteth ful merye
Onhighe amonge þe fressh leves grene
This fressh may that is so bright ⁊and shene
Gan for to sike and sayd alas my syde
Now ʆsir qd she for oght that may be tyde
I moste haue of the peres that I see
Or I mote deye for sore longeth me
To eten of the smale peres grene
Helpe for hir loue that is of heuen quene
I telle ȝoᵘ wele a wōmman in my plite
May haue to some fruyt so grete an appetite
That she may deien but she it haue
Allas qd he that I ne had here a knaue
That couth clymbe allas allas qd he
For I am blynde ȝe ʆsir no fors qd she
But wolde ȝe voche saue for goddes sake
The piry in with youre armes for to take
For wele I wote that ȝe mystruste me
Than shulde I clymbe wele ynogh qd she
Soo I my foote myght sette vppon youre bake
For soth seid he in me shal be no lake
Might I ȝoᵘ help wᵗith my hert bloode
He stoupeth doun and on his bakke she stoode
And caught hir by a twyst and vp she goth
Ladyes I pᵃy ȝow be not wrothe
I can noght glose I am a rude man
And sodanly anon this Damyan
Gan pullen vp the smoke ⁊andhe in he throng
And whan that pluto saugh this grete wrong
To Ianuarie he ȝaf his sight agayn
Ne was ther neuer man of thing so fayn
But on his wyffe his thoght was eủermoo
Vp to the tre he kest his eyen two
And see that Damyan his wyffe had dressed
In whiche man it may not bene expssed
But ȝif I wolde speke vncurtesly
And vp he ȝaffe a roryng and a cry
As doth the moder whan the child shal deye
Oute help alas harow he gan to crie
O strong lady stoure what dotth thow
And she ansuerid ʆsir what eilith ȝow
Haue pacience and reson in ȝoure mynde
I haue ȝow holpen on bothe youre eyen blynde
Vp ꝑperil of my soule I shal not lien
As me was taught to hele with youre n
Was no thing bett̉er for to make ȝow see
Than strogle with a man vpon a tree
God wote I dede it in ful goode entent
Strogle qd he ȝei algate in hit went
God ȝif yow both on shames deth to deien
He swyued the I saugh hit wᵗith myn eyen
And elles be I hanged by the hals
Than is qd she the medicyne fals
For certanly if þat ȝe myghten see
Ȝe wolde not say þo wordes to me
Ȝe haue some glymsyng ⁊and no ꝑperfite sight
I see qd he as wele as euer I myght
Thanked be god with both myn eyen two
And by my trouth me thoght he did the soo
Ȝe mase mase goode sir qd she
This thank haue I for I haue made ȝoᵘ see
Alas qd she þᵗat eủer I was so kynde
Now dame qd he let al passe out of mynde
Come doun my leef ⁊and ȝif I haue myssaide
God help me so as I am euel a paide
But by my fader soule I wende haue seyn
How that this Damyan had by the leyn
And that thi smoke had lyen vpon thi brest
Ȝei ʆsir qd she ȝe may wene as yow lest
But ʆsir a man þᵗat waketh oute of his slepe
He may not sodanly wele take kepe
Vpon a thing ne seen it ꝑperfitely
Til that he be adawed verrely
Right so a man that longe hath blynd be
Ne may not sodanly so wele y see
First whan the sight is newe cōmmyn agayn
As he that hath a day or two I sayn
Til that youre sight ystabled be awhile
Ther may ful many a sight yow begile
Beith ware I pᵃy ȝow for by heuen kyng
Ful many a man wenyth for to see a þing
And hit is al other than it semeth
He that mys conceyueth mysdemyth
And with that worde she lepe doun fro þe tree
This Ianuarie who is glad but he
He kisseth her ⁊and clippeth her ful ofte
And on hir wombe he stroketh hir ful softe
And to his Paleis home he hath hir ladde
Now good men I pᵃy ȝow to be gladde
Thus endith here my tale of Ianuarie
God blisse vs and his moder seint marie
Oure oost gan tho to loke vp anone .
Goode men qd he . herkeneth eủerychou
As eủer mote I drinke wyne or ale .
This merchaunt hath ytolde a mery tale
How Ianuarie . hadde a lither Iape .
His wiffe put in his hoode an . ape .
But here of will I leve of as . now
Dame wyfe of bath qd he I þᵃray ȝow
Telle vs a tale now next after this
Sir oost qd she . so god my soule blisse
As I fully þ̉erto will consente .
And also it is myn hole entente
To done ȝow all disporte . as þᵗat I kan
But holde me excusid I am a woman
I can not reherse as these clerkis kun

body.fw: The wyffe of Baathes tale/ or prologe .

div.l: And right anone she hath hir tale bygune .
Exꝑperience . thogh noone auctorite .
Were in this worlde . is right ynogh for me .
To speke of woo . that is in mariage .
For lordinges syn I . twelue . ȝeer had of age .
Thanked be god that is eterne alyve .
Housbondes at the chirch dore I haue hadde fyve .
Ȝif I so ofte myght haue weddid be .
And al wer worthy men in hir degre
But me was tolde . certan . not long agon is
That crist went neủer but ones
To weddyng in the cane . of galilee
That by the same ensample . he taght me .
That I ne shuld wedded be but onys
Herken eke . what a sharpe . worde for þe nonys
Bysydes a welle Ihs god and man
Spake in reprofe . to þe Samaritan
Þoᵘ hast yhad fyve . housbondes . qd he .
And that thilke man that now . hath the .
Is not thyn . housbond thus seid he certayn .
But that I axe . why the fifte man
Was noȝt housbond to the samaritan
How mony myȝt she haue in mariage .
Ȝet herde I . neủer tellen . in my age .
Vppon this nombr . diffinicion
Men may deuyne . ⁊and glosen vp ⁊and doun
But wele I wote . expsse . with outen lye .
God bad vs to wexen ⁊and multiplie .
That gentil texte . can I wele . vnderstonde
Wele I wote that myn housbonde .
Shulle lefe fader ⁊and moder ⁊and take me .
But of no nombre mencion made he .
Of bigamie or of octogamye
Whi shulde men than speke . of hit vilaynye .
Loo here . the wise kyng Dau salamon
I trowe that he had wyfes moo þan oone .
As wolde god it leful were to me .
To be refresshed half so wele as he .
Which ȝifte of god had he . for al his wyfes
No man hath such that in the worlde alyve is
God wote this noble . kyng as to my wytte .
The first nyȝt had mony a mery fitte .
Whit iche of hem so wele . was hym on lyve .
Blessid be god that I haue . weddid fyve .
Welcome the sext whan that eủer he shal
For soth I . wil not kepe me . chast in al
When my housbond is fro the worlde ygone .
Som cristen mānn shal wedde me . anone .
For than the Apostle . seith that I . am free .
To weddyn a goddeshalf where it liketh me .
He seith that be . weddyd is no synne .
Bett̉er is to be weddyd . than to brenne .
What rekketh me þogh folk sey vilainye .
Of shrewyd lamech and of his bigamye .
I wote wele . Abraham was an holy man
And Iacob . eke . as ferre as I here can
And ech of hem . had wyffes mo þan two
And mony an other holy man also .
Where can ȝe sey in any man age .
That hie god defendid any mariage .
By expsse worde . I pᵃy ȝoᵘ telle it me .
Or where cōmmᵃunde he virginite .
. I . wote . as wele . as ȝe it is no drede .
Thapostle . whan he . speketh of maidenhede .
He seid that here of pcepte . had he none .
Men may concele a wōmman to be . one
But concelyng is no cōmmaundement
He put it in oure owne Iuggement
For had he cōmmaundement maydenhede .
Than had he dampned weddyng wᵗith outen drede
And certis ȝif there no . sede were . sowe .
Virginite than wher of shuld growe .
Poule durst not cōmmaunde at the lest
That thing that his maist̉er . ȝaf nōn hest
The spere . is sette . vppon virginite .
That who may who renneth best late see .
But this worlde is noȝt ytake . of eủery wight
But ther that god wole ȝef hit of hit myght
I wote wele . that thapostle . was a maide .
But neủertheles þogh he wrote . or saide .
He wolde that euery were such as he .
Al nys but concele . to virginite .
And for to bene a wiffe . he ȝaf me leve
Of indulgence so is it no repreve .
To wedde me . if that my make dye .
With outen excepciou of bigamye .
And al hit is good no wōmman for to touch
He mente . as in his bed or in my couch
For ꝑperil is both fire . and tow to assemble .
Ȝe knowe . what this . ensample . may resemble .
This is al and so . he helde . virginite .
More . ꝑparfite . than weddyng in freelte .
Freelte clepe . I but that I am she .
Wolde leden al hir lyfe . in chastite .
I graunt hit wele . I ne haue no enuye .
Thogh maidenhede . preferre . bigamye .
Hit liketh hem to be clene . in body ⁊and gost
Of myn estate . I wil not make my boste .
Full wele ȝe knowe alorde in his housholde
Hath noȝt eueri vessel of gold
Some bene . of tree . ⁊and don hir lorde . ʆseruise
God clepith to hym . folke in sundry wyse .
And either haith of god a ꝓproper ȝifte .
Some this some that as hym liketh shifte
Virginite is grete ꝑperfeccione .
And continence eke with deuociou
But crist that of ꝑperfecciou is welle .
Badde noȝt eủery wight he shulde selle .
Alle that he hadde and ȝif it to the pore .
And in such wise folowe hym and his lore .
He spake to hem that wolde . lyven ꝑparfitely
Lordes by youre leve that am not I .
I wil bistowe . alle my age .
In the actis . and fruyt of mariage .
Telle me also . to what conclusion
Wer menbres . made of gnacion
And so ꝑparfite wise . a wriȝt ywroȝt
Trusteth riȝt wele thei were not made for noȝt
Glose who so wole . ⁊and sey both up ⁊and doun
That thei wer makid for purgacioun
Of vryne and oth̉er thinges smale .
Was eke to knowe a female from a male .
And for non other caus . say ȝe no
The exꝑperience wote it is noȝt so .
So that the clerkes be wᵗith me wrothe .
I sey thus thei maked bene for both
That is to seyn for office ⁊and for eese .
Of engendur derwe noȝt god displese
Whi shuld men ellis in hir bokes sette .
That men shuld ȝelde to his wiffe his dette .
Now wherwith shulde he payen his paymen
Ȝiffe that he . ne vsed his sely Instrument
Than were . thei made . vppon a creature .
To purge vryne . and eke . for engendur
But I sey not that euery wight is holde .
That haith suche . harneys as I of tolde .
To gone and vsen hem in engendur
Than shulde men taken of chastite no cure .
Crist was a maide . and shapen as a man
And many aseint syn the . worlde bigan
Ȝet lyved thei eủer in ꝑparfite . chastite .
I nyl envye . no virginite .
Lete hem be brede of pure . whete seede .
And lete vs wyffes ete barly brede .
And ȝit with barly brede . marke telle can
Oure lord refresshid many a man
In such astate . as god haith clepid vs
I wil preserue I am noȝt precious
In wifhode wole I . vsen my instrument
As frely as my maker hath it sent
Ȝif . I . dangerous be god ȝif me sorow
Myn . housbond shal it haue . both eue ⁊and morowe .
Whan that hym luste . come . forth ⁊and pay his dette .
An housbond wole I haue . I wole not lette
Which shal be bothe . my dettoure . ⁊and my thralle .
And haue his tribulacion with alle .
Vppon his flessh while that I . am his wyffe
I haue the pouere . duryng al my lyffe
Vppon his ꝓproper body and noȝt he .
Right thus theapostle . tolde hit vn to me .
And bad oure . housbond . to loue . vs wele .
Al this sentence me . liketh euerydele
Vp starte the ꝑpardonere and that anone .
Now dame qd he by god and by seint Ioh
Ȝe been a noble . pchoure in this caas
I was abouten to wedden a wiffe alas
What shuld I by it on my flessh so dere .
Ȝit had I leuer wedde no wiffe . to ȝeere .
Abide qd she . my tale is noȝt begonne .
Nay þᵘ shal drynk of a noþ̉er tonne
Or that I go . shal sauer worse than ale .
And whan I haue . ytolde the forth my tale .
Of tribulacion in mariage .
Of which I am expert in al my age .
This is to sayn my self hath bethe . whippe .
Than maiste þᵘ chese . whether þᵘ wilt skippe .
Of thilke tonn that I shal a broche .
Beware . of it or þou to nye aproche
For I shal telle ensamples mo þan ten
Who so wil not be ware . by other men
By hym shul other men correctid be .
This same . wordes . wrote ꝓprotholome .
Rede in his almageste . and take hit there .
Dame I wolde pᵃy ȝow . ȝif youre wille were .
Said this ꝑpardoner as ȝe bigan
Telle forth youre tale sparith for non man
And telle vs ȝong men the pᵃctike .
Gladly qd she . syn hit may ȝow lyke .
But that I . pᵃy ȝow al this . compagnye .
As take noȝt a griffe . of that I saye .
For myn entent is noȝt but for to pleye .
I . ȝow pᵃy sirs greueth not ȝoᵘ what I seye .
Now ʆsir than shal I telle forth my tale .
As euer mote I drynk wyne . or ale .
I . shal sey sothe . tho housbondes þᵗat I hadde .
As thre of hem were goode and two . were . badde
The thre men weren gode . ⁊and riche . and olde .
Vnnetthes myght thei the statutes holde .
In whiche thei were ybounden to me .
Ȝe wote wele . what I mene . of this ꝑparde .
As helpe me god . I laughe whan I . thynke .
How pitously a nyght I made hem swynke .
But by my fay I tolde it for no stoure .
Thei hadden . me ȝiffen . hirland ⁊and eke hir tᵉsoure .
Me nedith noȝt to . don lenger diligence .
To wynnen . hir loue . or don hem reuerence .
Thei loued me so wele . bi god aboue .
That I ne tolde . no dente . of hir loue .
Awyse . wōmman wil besy hir eủer in oone .
To gete hir loue . ȝei there she haith none .
But sith I hadde hem holy in to myn honde .
And sithen that thei hadden y ȝiffen me alhir londe
What shuld I take . kepe hem for to plese .
But hit were . for my profet or for my eese .
I set hem so on werke . by my fey
That many a nyght thei song weylawey
The bakou was not fet for hem I trowe .
That som men han in Essex at Donmowe .
I gouerned hem . so wele . after my lawe .
That eche of hem ful blisful was and fawe .
To brynge me . gay thinges fro the feire
Thei were gladde . whan I spake . to hem faire
For god it wote . I chidde hem spitously
Now herkeneth how I bare me ꝓproporly
Ȝe wiffes than kan vnderstounde
Thus shal ȝe speke ⁊and bere wrong anhonde .
For half so boldely can ther no man
Sweire and lie as a wōmman can
I sey not this by wyffes that bene wyse
A wyse wyffe . if that she . conne her goode .
Shal bere hym on hond . the cowe is woode .
And take wyttenesse . of hir owne . mayde .
Off hir assent but herken how I seide .
Sir olde caynard is this thyn aray
Why is my neighebours wyf so gay
She is honoured oủer al wher she goth
I sitte at home . I haue no thrifty cloth
What doste þoᵘ at my neighbours hous
Is she so faire . art þᵘ amerous
What rowne ȝe . with ȝoᵘur maiden bndicite .
Sir olde lechour lette thi Iapes be .
And ȝiff I haue . a gosshep or a frende .
With outen gilt ȝe . chiden as a fende .
Ȝiff that I walke . or pley vn to his hous
Þoᵘ comest home as dronken as a mous
And prechest on thi bench wᵗith euyl preve .
Thow saist to me . it is a grete . myschefe .
To wedde a poure wōmman for costage .
And ȝif she be riche . for grete parage .
Than saist þᵘ that it is a turmentrie
To suffren hir pride . and hir malencolie
And ȝif she be faire . þᵘ verrey knaue .
Þᵘ saiste . that euery holoure wole hir haue .
She may no while in chastite abide .
Thou saiste . som folke . desire . vs for richesse .
Some for oure shappe . ⁊and some for oure fairnesse .
And some for she . can either syng or daunce .
And some . for gentilnes of daliaunce .
Some for hir handes ⁊and hir armez smale .
Thus goth al to the . deuel . by thi tale .
Thou saist men may not kepe a castel walle .
Hit may so long assailed be oủer alle
And ȝif she be foule . þᵘ saist that she .
Couetith euery man that she may se .
For as a spaynal she wole on hym lepe .
Til that she fynde . some man hir to chepe
Ne none so gray goose goth in the lake
As þᵘ saiste þᵗat wole ben with outen make .
And saiste it is an harde thing for to holde .
A thing that no man his thankes wolde
Thou saist thus brothel whan þᵘ gost to bedde .
And that no wise wōmman hath no nede to wedde .
Ne no man that entendeth in to heuen .
With wilde thounder dynt and fyrye leuene .
Mote thi wikked nekke be to broke .
Þᵘ saist that droppyng houses ⁊and eke smoke
And chidyng wyffes make men to flee
Oute of hir owne . houses a bndicite .
What eylith such a nolde . man for to chide
Þᵘ saist we wyfes wolen oure vices hide .
Til we ben faste . and than we wil hem shewe .
Wele may that be a . ꝓprouerbe . of a shrewe .
Þᵘ saist that oxen . asses . horses ⁊and houndes
Thei bene assaied . at dyuers stoundes
Bassyns lavers or than men hem bie .
Spones stoles . and such housbondrye .
And so ben pottes . clothes ⁊and such array
But folke of wiffes maketh none assay
Til thei bene wedded olde dotarde shrewe
And than saist þᵘ we wolen oure vices shewe .
Þᵘ seist also . that displeseth me .
But ȝif that þᵘ wille preyse my beaute .
And but þᵘ pore al wey in my face .
And clepe me fair dame . in euery place
And but þᵘ make a feste thilk day
That I was borne and make me Fressh ⁊and gay
And but þᵘ do to my norice honoure
And to my chamber wᵗith in my boure
And to my faders folke . ⁊and to his alies .
Thou saist þᵘ olde . barel ful of lies .
And ȝit of oure pntys Iankyn .
For his crispit heire . shynyng as gold so fyne .
For he squyerth me both vp ⁊and doun
Ȝet hast þᵘ caght a fals suspiciou
I wil hym not yf þᵘ were deid to morowe .
But telle me this why doste þᵘ with sorowe .
Thi keyes of thi cheste . away fro me .
Hit is my goode . as wele as thin ꝑparde .
What wenyst þᵘ to maken an ydiote of our dame .
Now by that lorde . that called is seint Iame .
Thou shalt not both þogh þᵘ were . woode .
Be maist̉er both oủer my body ⁊and oủer my goode .
That one þᵘ shalte . forgone mavgre thin eyen .
What nedith it me . for to enqueren or spyen .
I trowe þᵘ woldest lokke me in thin cheste .
Thou shuldest say wiffe go where the leste
Take youre disporte I nyl leve . no tales
I knowe yow . for a trewe wyfe . dame alys
We loueth no man that taketh kepe or charge
Where that we go we wole bene at oure . large .
Of al men he blissed mote he . be .
The . wise astrologien . dan ꝓprotholome .
That saith this ꝓprouerbe . in his almageste .
Of alle men his wisdome is hieste .
That rekketh noȝt who hath this worlde īn honde .
By this ꝓprouerbe . thou shalt vnderstonde .
Haue þᵘ ynogh what dar the rekke or care .
How meryly that other folkes fare
For certes olde dotardes by youre . leve .
Ȝe shal haue queynte right ynogh at eve
He is to grete a nygard that wil werne .
A man to lighten . a candel at his lanterne .
He shal haue . neuer lesse light ꝑparde .
Haue þᵘ ynogh darst þᵘ not pleyne the .
Thou saist also . ȝif we make . vs gay
With clothyng and wᵗith pcious array
That it is ꝑparil of oure chastite .
And ȝit with sorowe þᵘ most enforce the
And sey these wordes in the apostles name
In habit made in chastite . and shame
Ȝe wōmmen shulde . apperel ȝoᵘ qdhe .
And not in tresses of here . ⁊and rich perre
As perels ne with golde . ne clothes riche .
After the text ne after rubrich
I wil not worche as moche as a gnat
Thou saist this that I was like . a cat
But who so wolde sengy a cattes skyn
Than wolde the cat wele dwellyn īm his In
And ȝif the cattis skyn be slyke ⁊and gay
She wole not duellen in hous half a day
But forth she wole or any day be dawed .
To shewed hir eke . and go a caturwrawed .
This is to seyn ȝif I be gay ʆsir shrewe .
I wil renne out my berel for to shewe .
Sir olde foole . what helpith the to aspyen
Þogh þᵘ pᵃy argus wᵗith his hundred eyen
To be my wardecours as he may best
In faith he shal not kepe . me but me lest
Ȝet couth I maken his berde . so mote I the .
Thou seist eke . that ther bene . thinges thre .
The whiche thinges troubulen al the erth
And no wight may not endure the ferth
O leue ʆsir shrewe seynt Iohn short thi lyffe .
Ȝet prechist þou and seist an hateful wyffe .
Yrekened is for one of this meschaunces
Bene non other there . resemblaunces
That ȝe may likene . ȝoure ꝑparabole . to .
But a sely wyffe be one of tho .
Thou likenest eke . wōmmānnes loue . to helle .
To baren lond there . water may not duelle .
Thou likenest eke hit to a wildfyre
The more it brenneth the more . it hath desire
To consume eủery thing that brent wil be
Thou seist right as wormes shenden atre .
Right so awiffe . distroyeth hir housbond .
This knowe thei that bene . to wiffes bounde .
Lordynges right as ȝe . haue vnderstounde
I bare stiffely myn olde housbondes an honde .
That thus thei seiden in her drunkennesse .
And alle was fals but that I toke wittenesse
On Iankyn and on my nece also .
O lorde the peyn I did hym and the woo .
Ful giltles by goddes swete pyne .
For as an hors I couth bite and whyne .
I couth pleyn and I was in the gilte .
Or ellis ofte tymes I had ben spilte .
Who so first cometh to the mylle . first grynt
I pleyned eủer first so was oure werre ystynt
Thei weren ful glad to excusen hem blyve
Of thing of whiche thei neuer agilt hir lyve
Of wenches wolde I beren . hem . on honde .
Whan thei for seke myghte vnnetthes stonde .
Hit tikeled in his hert for that he .
Wende that I hadde had . of hem so gte cherte
I swore that alle my walkyng oute by nyght
Was for to aspien wenches that he dight
Vnder that coloure . hadde I . many a myrthe .
For al such witte . was ȝiffe vs in oure . birthe
Disceyt wepyng spynnyng god hath ȝiffe .
To wymen kyndely while that we may lyffe
And thus of oo thing I avaunte me
At the ende I hadde the better in ich degre
By sleyght or fors or by some maner thing
As by continuale murmur and grutchyng
Namely abedde . hadde thei meschaunce .
There wolde I chide . and done hem no plesaunce .
I wolde no lenger in the bedde . abyde .
Ȝif I felde his arme oủer my side .
Til he . had made his raunsou vn to me .
Than wolde y suffren hym to don his nycite .
And therfore . euery man this tale . I telle .
Wynne who so may for alle is to selle .
With empty hond men may nōn haukes lure .
For wynnyng wold I al his lust endure .
And make me a feynt appetite .
And ȝet in bacon had I neủer delyte .
That made me that eủer I wolde . hym chide
For þogh the pope . hadde sitten hem beside .
I nolde noȝt spare . hem at hir owne borde .
For by my trouth I quytte hym worde for worde .
As helpe me verrey god omnipotent
Thogh I right nowe shulde . make my testamēnt
I ne owe hem noȝt oo worde that is not quytte .
I broght it so aboute . by my wytte .
That thei moste ȝif hit vp . as for the best
Or ellys hadde . neuer be at reste .
For thogh he lokid . as wode as a lyo
Ȝet shulde he fallen on this conclusione
Than wolde I say good leef take kepe .
How mekely loken wilken our shepe
Come nere my spouse . ⁊and lete me ba thi cheke
Ȝe shullen bene al pacient and meke .
And haue a swete spiced conscience .
Sith ȝe so pche . of iob pacience .
Sufferith alwey syn ȝe so wele can pche .
And but ȝe do certayn I shal ȝoᵘ teche .
That it is fair to haue a wiffe in pees
One of vs two most bowen douteles
And sith a man is more . resonable .
Than a wōmman is ȝe most be sufferable .
What eilith ȝow to grutche thus ⁊and grone .
Hit is for ȝe wolde . haue my queynte . allone .
Loo take . it al lo haue it euerydele .
Petir I shrewe ȝoᵘ but ȝe loue it wele .
For ȝif I wolde selle my bele chose .
I couth walke . as fressh as a rose .
But I wole kepe . it for youre . toth
Ȝe bene to blame . by god I say ȝoᵘ soth
Such maner wordes had we on honde .
Now wil I speke of my ferth housbond .
My ferth housbond was a reueloure
This is to sayn he had a ꝑparamoure .
And I was yong ⁊and ful of ragerye .
Stiborn ⁊and strong and ioly as a pye .
How couth I daunce to anharpe . smale .
And syng I wis as any nyghtyngale .
Whan I had dronken a draght of swete wyne .
Metellius the foule cherle the swyne
That with a staffe by refte his wyfe hir lyffe
For she drank wyne . thogh I had bene his wyffe .
Ne shuld daunced me fro . that drynke
For alle so siker as colde engenderith haile .
A licorus mouthe most haue . a licorus taile
In wymen vinolent is no . defense .
This knowen licherous by exꝑperience .
But lord crist whan hit remembreth me .
Vppon my ȝouth ⁊and my iolyte .
Hit telleth me aboute myn hert roote .
Vn to this day hit doth myn hert goode .
That I haue had the worlde . as in my tyme .
But alas that age . wil annoye me .
Haith me birafte my beaute ⁊and my pighe .
Lete go fare wele the deuel go ther with .
The floure is gone . ther nys nomore to telle .
The bran as I best can now most I selle
But ȝit to be riȝt mery ȝet wil I founde .
Now forth to tellen on my ferth housbonde .
I say in herte I had grete dispite .
That he of any other had delyte .
But he was quytte by god and by seynt Ioos
I made hym of the same wodde a croos
Now of my body in no foule manere .
But c̉ertanly I made folk such cher
That in his owne grese . I made hym frie .
For angry and for verray ielousie .
By god on erth I was his purgatory
For which I hope his soule be in glory
For god hit wote he satte ful ofte ⁊and song
Whan that his sho wele bitterly hym wrong
Ther was no . wight safe god . ⁊and he hit wyst
In many wyse . how sorily I hym twyste .
He deid whan I cam fro Ierusale
And lith gᵃue vnder the rode . beeme .
Al is his tombe noȝt so curious
As was the sepulcre . of kyng darius
Which that appellus wroȝte so solempnely
Hit is but wast to burien hym pciously
Late hym fare wele god ȝif his soule gode rest
He is now in his gᵃue and in his cheste .
Now of my fifte housbond wole I telle .
God lete his . soule neủer come in helle .
And ȝet was he to me . the moste shrewe .
That fele I on my ribbes al by rewe .
And eủer shal in to myn endyng day
But in oure bedde he was so fressh ⁊and gay
And therwith al wele . couthe he me glose .
Whan that he wolde . haue my bele chose .
That þogh he had me beten eủery bone .
He couthe wynne my love agayn anoone .
I trow I love hym best for that he .
Was of his loue daungerous to me .
We wymen . haue ȝif I shal noȝt lye .
In this mater a queynte fantasie .
Wayte what thing I may not lightly haue .
Ther after wille we crie . al day ⁊and crave .
Forbede vs thing and that desyren we .
Prese . vn hus fast ⁊and than wil we flee .
With daunger outrey we al oure . chaffare .
Derthe gret at marchaunt makez dere owhar
And grete chepe is holden . at litel . pryse .
This knowith euery man that is wyse .
My fifte housbond god his blisse .
Whiche that I toke . for love ⁊and no richesse .
He some tyme . was a clerke of Oxenforde .
And had lefte . scole ⁊and went at home to bord
With my gossib . dwellyng in oure toun
God haue hir soule . hir name was Alisou
She knewe my hert and eke my pⁱriuetye .
Bett̉er than oure parissh prest also mote I the
To hir I wreyed my councele alle .
For had my housbond pissed on a walle .
Or don a thing that shuld haue . lost his lyffe .
To hir and to an other worthy wyffe .
And to my nece . whiche I loued wele .
I wolde haue tolde his councele . euerydele .
And so I dede . ful oft god hit wote .
That made his face . ofte rede . ⁊and hote
For verrey shame . and blamed hym self for he .
Hadde tolde me so . myche . of his pryuete .
And so bifel that onys in a lente .
So ofte tymes my gossib . wente .
For eủery ȝet I loued to be gay
And for to walken in marche . apⁱrile ⁊and may
Fro hous to hous to her sundre . talys
That Iankyn ⁊and my gossib . dame Alis
And I my self in to the feldes wente
Myn housbond was at londou al the lente
I had the better layser for to pleye .
And for to see . and for to eke . preye .
I lusty foole what wist I wher my gᵃce
Was schapen for to be . or in what place .
Therfore I made . my visitaciouns
To vigilies and to ꝓprocessiouns
To prechings eke . and to thes pilgrimages
To playes of myracles ⁊and of mariages
And weryd vppon my gay scarlet gites
These wormes . ne these moghtes ne thes myte
vppon my ꝑperel fret hem neủer adele .
And wost þᵘ why for thei weren vsed wele .
Now . wil I telle . forth what happed me
I sey that in the feldes walked we .
Til truly we hadden such daliaunce .
This clerke ⁊and I that of my purveaunce .
I spake to hym and seide how . that he .
If I were . wydowe . he shuld wedde me .
For certanly I saide . for no bobaunce .
Ȝet was I neuer with outen purveaunce .
Of mariage . ne of other thinges eke
I holde a mowse . hert noȝt worth a leke
That hath but one hole to stert to
And ȝif that faile than is al ydo
But sir lete me se . what shal I sayn .
Abide goode I haue my tale agayn
Whan my ferthe housbonde . was on bere
I wept algate . and made sory chere
As wyffes moten for it is hir vsage .
And with my kerchefe couered my visage .
But for that I was purveid of a make
I wepid but smale . and that I vnderstake .
To chirche . was myn housbond borne a morwe
With neighborus that for hym made sorwe .
And Iankyn oure clerk was one of tho .
And helpe me god whan I saw hym go .
After the bere me thoght he had a payre
Of legges and of feet so clene ⁊and faire .
That al myn herte I ȝaf to his holde .
He was I trowe . twenty wynter olde .
And I was fourty ȝif I shal sey soth
But ȝet I had . alwey a coltes tot
Gat tooth I was and that bycame . me wele .
I had a prynte . of seint venus sele .
As help . me god . I was a lusty oone
And faire ⁊and rich ⁊and yong and wele bygon
And truly as my housbond . tolde me .
I had the best queynte . that myȝte be .
Myn ascendent was taur9 and mars þ̉er In
Alas alas that euer loue was syn
I folowed alwey myn Inclinacion
By vertu of my constellaciou
That made me . I couth noȝt wᵗith drawe .
My chambre . of Venus from a goode felawe .
What shal I say but at monethes ende .
This ioly clerke that was so hende .
Hath wedded me with grete solempnite .
And to hym ȝaf al the lond ⁊and fee .
That euer ther was ȝif me before .
But afterward repentid me ful sore .
He nolde suffre no thing of my luste .
By god he smote me ones aȝein the brest
For that I rente oute of his book alefe .
That of that strooke my eren waxe al defe .
Stobborne . I was as any lionesse .
And of myn age a verrey Iangleresse .
And walke I wolde as I had don biforne .
Fro hous to hous . al þogh he had hit sworne
For swich ofte tymes wolde he prech
And me olde Romayn gestes tech
How he simplicius gallus loft his wiffe
And hir forsoke for terme of al his lyfe .
Noȝt but openheed he hir say
Lokyng oute . at his dore . vppon a day
An other romayn tolde he me by name
That for his wyffe . was at a somer game
With outen his wittyng he forsoke hir eke
And wolde for hir vppon his bible seke
That ilke ꝓprouerbe . of ecclesiast
Where he forbedith and cōmmaundeth fast
Men shal not suffre his wiffe to roile aboute .
Than wolde he sayn wᵗith outen doute .
Who so bildeth al his hous of salewes
And pⁱriketh his blynd hors oủer the falowes
And suffereth his wyffe . go seken halowes
Is worthy to be hanged . on the galowes
But al for noȝt I set not an hawe .
Of his ꝓprouerbes no of his olde sawe .
Neither of hym I wolde correctyd be .
I hate hym that my vices telleth me .
Lorde so doth moo god wote than I
This made hym wode . al witterly
I nolde forbere hym in this caas
Now wil I . say to ȝoᵘ by seint Thoᵃs
Why that rent oute . of his booke . alefe .
For whiche he smote me that I . was defe .
He had a boke that gladly nyght ⁊and day
For his disport he wolde rede alwey
He clepid hit valerie . ⁊and theofraste .
And with that booke . he loghe alway wele fast
And eke ther was su tyme a clerk at Rome .
A cardinale . that hight seynt Ierome .
That made a boke . aȝayns Iouynyane
In which boke . eke was ther Terculane .
Crisippus trotula . and helowys
That was Abbes not ferre . for parys
And eke the . ꝑparabolis of Salamon
Ovidis art and bokis many oone
And al these wer bonden in one volume
And euery nyȝt and day was his costume
Whan tyme was of vacaciou
For other worldely occupaciou
To reden in his booke of wikked wyfes
He knewe of hem mo legende ⁊and lyfes
Than bene of goode wyfes in the bible
For truste wele . it is . an Impossible .
That eny clerk wil speke any goode of wyfes
But ȝif it be . of any seintꝭes lyfes
Ne of other wōmman neủer the mo .
Who peyntyth the leon telle me who .
By god ȝif wōmmen had writen stories
As clerkes han with hir oratories
Thei wolde haue writen of men mor wikkydnes
Than al the marke of Adam may redresse
The children of mcurye . and of venus
Bene in hir werchyng wele contrarious
M̉ercurie loueth wisdom ⁊and science .
And venus loueth riot ⁊and dispence .
And for hir dyuerse disposicione
Ich faillez in other exaltacione .
And thus god wote . mcurie . is desolate
And pisses wher venus is exaltate .
And venus faillez þ̉er mcurie is reisid .
Therfore no wōmman of no clerke is pysid
The clerke whan he is olde ⁊and may not do .
Of venus werkes not worthe his olde sho .
Than sitteth he dou ⁊and writeth in his dotage
That wōmmen can noȝt kepe hir mariage
But now to purpose . why I tolde the .
That I was beten for a boke ꝑparde
Vpon a nyght Iankyn that was our sire
Redde on his booke as he sit by the fire
Of Eua first for hir wikkednesse
Tho redde he how sampson lost his heris
Slepyng his lemman kutte hem wᵗith hir sheris
Thurgh whiche lost he bothe his eyen
Tho redde he me . ȝif I shuld not lyen
Of Hercules . and of Dianyre
That causid hym to sette hym self a fire .
Noȝt forȝate . he the care . and the woo .
That Socrates hadde with his wyfes two .
How pancipia . caste pisse . vpon his hede .
This sely man satte stille as he wer dede
He wyped his heede nomor durst he . sayn
But after a grete thunder cometh a rayn
Of Pasipha that was the quene of grece .
For shrewednesse . hym thoght the tale swete
Fy speke nomore . it is a gryssely thing
Of horrible lust and hir likynge .
Of clitermistra for hir lechery
That falsely made hir housbond for to deye .
That one for loue that other was for hate .
Lyuia hir housbond on an euen late .
Empoysonyd for that she was his foo .
Lucia licorous louyd hir housbond soo .
That for he shuld alway vpon hir thynk
She ȝaf suche . a maner loue . drynk
That he was dede . or hit was by þe morowe .
And thus algatis housbondes . hadden sorowe .
Than tolde he me . how one . latunyus
Compleyned to his felaw Arryus
That in his garden growed such a tree .
On which he seyd his wyffes three .
Hangid hem self for hir dispitous
O leue brother qd this Arrius
Ȝif me a plante of that blissed tre
And in myn garden plantyd shal it be
Of latter dedis of wyfes hath he redde
That some han hir housbondes in hir bedde
And laten hir lechoure diȝten hir wᵗith al the nyght
While the cors lay in þe floure vp right
And some haue dryven nayles in her brayn
While thei slept and thus thei haue hem slayn
Som haue ȝif hem poyson . in hir drynke
He spake more harme than hert may bythynk
And therwith he knew mo ꝓprouerbes
Than on this worlde grove gresse or herbes
Bet is qd he thyne habitacione
Be with lione or foule dᵃgone
Than with a wōmman vsant for to . chide .
Bet is qd he hie in the roofe . to abide .
Than with wykked wōmman doun i the hous
Thei bene so wikked and contᵃrious
Thei haten that hir housbondes loueth ay
He said a wōmman casteth hir shame away
Whan she cast of hir smoke . ⁊and furthermo .
A fair wōmman but she be chaste also .
Is like a gold ryng in a sowis nose .
Who wolde wene . or who wole suppose
The woo that in my herte was and pyne .
And whan I sawe . he wold neủer fyne .
To reden in his cursed booke . al nyght
And sodenly the leves haue I plight
Oute of his booke right as he redde . ⁊and eke .
I with my fust so toke . by the cheke
That in oure fire . he felle . bakward anoone
And he stert vp . as doth a woode lyon
And with his fust he smote me on the heede
That in the floure . I lay as I wer dede .
And whan he saw how styffe that I lay
He was agaste . and wolde haue . fledde away
Til at the last oute of my sowe I brayde .
O hast þᵘ slayn me . fals thefe I sayde .
And for my loue thus hast þᵘ murdrede me .
Or I be dede ȝet wille I kissen the .
And ner he come and knelyd faire a doun
And seid der sust̉er Alison
As help . me god I shal the neủer smyte .
That I haue . doun hit is thi selfe to wyte .
Forȝef hit me . and that I the besech
And ȝit eft sones I smote hem on the cheke .
And seid thefe thus moche I me awreke .
Now wil I dey . I may no leng speke .
But at the last with muche care ⁊and woo
We fel wele acorded bytwene vs twoo .
He ȝaf me . al the bridel in myn honde .
To haue the goủernaunce . of hous ⁊and londe
And of his tong ⁊and his hond also .
And made hym brenne his booke . anone right so .
And whan I had geten hym to me
By maistrey al the . soueraynite .
And that he . said myn owne trewe wyffe .

Kepe honoure and kepe myn estat
After that day we had neuer debate
God help me so I was to hym as kynde .
As any wyffe . fro denmarke in to ynde .
And also trewe . also was he to me
I pᵃy to god that sitteth in magest
The frere laught / when he hade herde all this .
Now dame quod he / so haue I ioye ⁊and blisse .
This is a longe preamble of a tale .
And when þᵉ Sompnour herde þᵉ frere gale /
Lo / quod þᵉ Sompnour / for goddes armys two /
A frere wyll entermitte hym euer mo .
Lo good men / a flye and eek a frere
Wolle falle in euery mannys dissh ⁊and matere .
What spekest þᵘ of preambulation ;
What ambyll or trot ; goo pysse or syt doun .
Thou lettest our disport in this matere .
Ye / wolt þᵘ so syr Sompnour quod þᵉ frere ;
Now by my faith I shall / or þᵗat I goo /
Tell of a Sompnour such a tale or two /

Now ellis frere I be shrewe þⁱ face /
Quod this Sompnour / and I be shrewe me
But if I telle talis two or thre

for welle I wote þⁱ patience is gone .
Oure cryd oste cryed / peece and þᵗat a none .
And said / let þᵉ woman telle her tale .

All redy syr quod she / ryght as you liste .

And as he badde riȝt so was doun̄ þe dede ·
And in a batħ þei gan̄ hir faste shetyn
A nyȝt ⁊and a day grete fuyre · þei maden
Al þe long nyȝt and eke the day also ·
For aƚƚ þe fyre · and eke þe bathes hete ·
She satte · aƚƚ colde and felt of hit no woo ·
But made hir a drope · nouȝt for to swete ·
But in that batħ hur lyfe she most lete ·
For he almachie with fuƚƚ wikked enten
To sleen hir in that batħ his sonde sent
Three strokes in þe nekke · he smote hire þoo
The tourmentoᵘur but for no man̉er chaunce ·
He myght not smyten · aƚƚ hur nekke a twoo ·
And for þ̉ere was þat tyme an ordinance ·
That no man̄ shuld do man̄ sucħ penance ·
The fourte stroke to smyten̄ softe or sore ·
This tormentoᵘur ne durste no mor͗e
But half dede wᵗith hir nekke y coruen̄ þere ·
He laft hir lye · and in his wey he went
The cristen̄ folke · whicħ abowten hir wer͗e
With shetys home fuƚƚ faire · hir hent
Thre daies levyng she was in this tourmēnt
And neủer cesud hem þe feitħ to tecħ
That she had fostred hem she gan̄ to p̉reche ·
And hem she ȝaf hur meobles ⁊and hir thing
And to þe pope vrbane betoke hem þoo ·
And said thus I aske this of heuen kyng
To han̄ respit thre daies ⁊and no moo
To recōmmᵃaunde to ȝoᵘ or þᵗat I · goo ·
These soules loo þᵗat I myght to wirche ·
Here of my hous · ꝑperpetuely a chirche
Seint vrban̄ wᵗith his deakenes pⁱriuely
The body fette · ⁊and buried hit by nyght
Among his other seintes honestly
Hur hous the churcħ of seint cecilie hyght
Seint vrban̄ halowyd hit as he wele myght
In the whicħ in to this day in noble wyse
Men̄ don̄ to cⁱriste and to his seintꝭes ʆseruice ·

Or we fully had riden fyfe myle
At boghton̄ vnder þe blee vs gan̄ a tale ·
A man̄ that clothed was in blake
And vnder that he had a white surplis
His hakenay þᵗat was a pomeƚƚ grys
So swete that it was wonder to see ·
Hit semyd he had pⁱriked myles three ·
The horse eke þᵗat his ȝōmmān roode vppon ·
So swette þᵗat vnneitħ myght he goon̄
Aboute þe pettreƚƚ stoode þe foome fuƚƚ hye
He was of Fome · as flekked as a pye ·
A mayle tweyfold on̄ his croꝑper lay
Hit semed þat he caried liteƚƚ array
Aƚƚ light for som̉er roode this worthy man̄
And in myn hert wondren I began̄
What that I · was til þᵗat I · vnderstode ·
How that his cloke was sewed to his hoode ·
For whicħ whan̄ I longe · had avysed me
I · demyd hym som chanon̄ for to be
Hit had hong at his bake doun̄ by alas
For he had rydde more þan trot or pas
He had priked lyke as he were woode
A cloote leefe he had vnder his hoode
For swoote and for to kepe his hede from hote
But hit wax ioy for to seen̄ hym swete
His forhede dropped as a stillatorie
Were fuƚƚ of plantane and of perytorie
And whan̄ þᵗat he come he gan̄ to crye
God saf quod he · þis ioly companye ·
Fast haue I pⁱriked qduod he for your͗e sake
Becaus that I wolde ȝoᵘ ouertake

His yōmman̄ eke was fuƚƚ of curtesie ·

div.l: For his desporte he loueth daliaunce ·
Frend for þi warnyng god ȝif þe good chaıı̄unce ·
Saide our ooste · certis hit wolde seme ·
Thi lorde · were wys ⁊and so I may wele deme ·
He is fuƚƚ iocunde · also dar · I · lay
Kan̄ he oghte telle a mery tale or tway
With whicħ he glade may this cōmpanye ·
Who sir my lord ȝee ȝee · wᵗith outēn lye ·
He can̄ of mertħ and eke of iolyte ·
Not but ynogħ also sir trustetħ me ·
And ȝe hym knew as wele as do I ·
Ȝe wolde wonder how wele ⁊and trustely
He coutħ werke · ⁊and þᵗat in sondry wyse ·
He haitħ take on hym many sundry apryse
Whicħ were fuƚƚ harde for any that is here ·
To bryng aboute · þei of hym it lere ·
As homely as he ritte amonges þow ·
Ȝif ȝe hym knewe hit wolde be þoure prowe
Ȝe nolde not for gone his acqueyntance ·
For moche goode · I dar ley in balance
Aƚƚ þᵗat I · haue in my possession ·
He is a man̄ of highe discrecion̄
I · warne ȝoᵘ wele · he is a passyng man̄
Wele qduod our ooste · I pᵃray þe telle me þan̄
Is he clerk or noone · telle what he is
Nay he is grett̉er þan̄ a clerk y wys
Sayde the yōmman · ⁊and in wordis fewe ·
Oofte and of his crafte · somwhat I wole þow shewe ·
I · say my lorde · can sucħ a sotelte
But aƚƚ his craft ȝe may not wytte of me
And somwhat helpe I ȝet to his werchyng
That aƚƚ þis grounde whicħ þᵗat we bene on̄ rydeng
Tiƚƚ þᵗat we come to caunt̉erbury toun
He coutħ as clene turne vp so doun̄
And paue hit aƚƚ of siluer and of golde
And whan̄ this yōmman had þus y tolde
Vn to our͗e ooste he said bēnedicite
This thing is vonder m̉ervelous to me
Syns þᵗat thy lorde is of so highe prudence
By caus of whicħ men̄ shuld hym rev̉erence
That of his worship rekketħ he so lyte
His oủer sloppe nys not worth a myte
As in effecte to hym so mote I go
Hit is aƚƚ bavdy and to tore also
Why is thy lorde so sluttyssħ I þe prey
And is of power bett̉er clothes to bey
ȜIf þᵗat his dede acorde with thy specħ
Telle me that ⁊and þat I þe besecħ
Why qduod this yōmman wherto aske ȝeme
God helpe me so for he shaƚƚ neủer ythe
But I wole not avowe þat I say
And þ̉erfore kepe it secre I ȝoᵘ pray
He is to wyse in faitħ as I beleve
That þᵗat is oủer doun̄ it nyl not preve
And riȝt as clerkis seyn it is a vice
Wherfore in that I holde hym levde ⁊and nyce
For whan̄ a man̄ hatħ oủer grete a wytte
Fuƚƚ often̄ hit happeth to mysvsen hit
So dotħ my lorde ⁊and þᵗat me greuetħ sore

div.l: Lurkyng in hirnes ⁊and in lanes blynde 200
Where thes robbers and theses by kynde
Holden her pⁱriuey ferefuƚƚ residence
And thei that dur not shewen hir p̉resence
So fare we yf I shaƚƚ say þe sothe
Ȝit qduod oure ooste let me telle to the
Why art þᵘ discolored on̄ þi face
Petir qduod he god ȝif hym herd gᵃrace
I am so vsed in þe fire to blowe
That hit hattħ chaunged my colour͗e I trowe
I am not wonte in no myrrour͗e to pry
But swynke sore and lerne to multiplie
We bloundren̄ eủer and pouren in þe fire
And for aƚƚ þat we failen of our͗e desire
For eủer we lakken oure conclusioıı̄un
To moche folk we bene but Illusioıı̄un
And borowe gold be hit a pound or two
Or ten or twelfe or mony sōmmes moo
And make hem wene at þe lest weye
That of a pound we couthe make tweye
Ȝit is hit fals and ay we han goode hope
Hit for to done and after hit we grope
But ᵗat science is so fer vs beforne
We mow not aƚƚ þogh we had hit sworne
Hit oủertake hit slyt away so faste
Hit wole hus make beggers at laste
Whilest þis yōmman was þus in this talkyng
This chanoune drowe hym neer͗e ⁊and herde aƚƚ thing
Whicħ that this yōmman spake for suspecyoıı̄un
Of mēnnes speche eủer had this chanoıı̄un
For caton seith he þᵗat gilty is
Demetħ aƚƚ thyng be spoke of hym ywys
By y caus of that he can̄ so nyegħ draw
His yōmman that herd aƚƚ his sawe
And þus he seid vn to his yōmman thoo
Holde now thy pees ⁊and speke wordes no moo
For ȝif þᵘ doo þᵘ shalt hit der͗e abye
Thou sclanderest þᵗat þᵘ shuldest hyde
Ȝei qduod oure oost telle on what so betyde
Of aƚƚ thretyng recche ye not a myte
In faith qduod he nomor͗e do I but a lyte
And whan̄ this chanon sawe hit wold notbe
But his yōmman wold telle his pⁱriuety
He fledde away for verray sorw ⁊and shame
A qduod the ȝōmman here shaƚƚ aryse a game
Aƚƚ þᵗat I can̄ anoone wole I telle
Syns he is gone þe foule fende hȳm quelle /
For neủer her after wole I wᵗith hym mete
For peny ne for Pounde I· hym behete
He þᵗat me broght ferst vn to þe game
Er þᵗat he dey sorwe haue he ⁊and shame
For it is ernest to me by my faitħ
That fele I wele what so any man saitħ
And ȝit for aƚƚ my smert ⁊and aƚƚ my greefe
For aƚƚ my sorwe ⁊and laboure and myschefe
I coutħ neủer leve hit in no wysse
Now wolde god my wytte wolde suffice
To tellen aƚƚ that longetħ to þᵗat arte
But natheles ȝit wole I telle ȝow ꝑparte
Syns þᵗat my lorde is goone I wiƚƚ not spare
Suche thyng as I· knowe I wiƚƚ declare
Wyth this chanoıı̄un duellid haue I seuēn ȝer͗e
And of his science am I neủer þe nere
Aƚƚ þᵗat I had I lost þ̉errby
And god wote so haue many moo þan̄ I
There I was wont to be ryȝt fressħ ⁊and ga

Now may I were an hose vpon myn hede
And where my colour was botħ fressħ ⁊and reede
Now is hit wan and of lewde hewe
Who so it vsetħ sore shaƚƚ hit rewe
And of my swynk ȝit bleryd is myn̄ eye
Loo whicħ auauntage it is to multiplye
That slydyng science hatħ me made so bare

And ȝit I am endettyd so þ̉er by
Of gold þᵗat ·I· haue borowed trwly
That while I· love I shaƚƚ hit quyte neủer
Late eủery man̄ be ware by me for eủer
What man̉er man̄ þᵗat casteth him þ̉erto
Ȝif he cōntynue I holde his thryfte y doo
For so help me god þ̉er by shaƚƚ he not wynne

div.l: That owhere is wherfore as for þe boste 203
Of aƚƚ þe names now wole I me reste
For as I trowe I haue ȝoᵘ tolde ynogħ
To reysen̄ a feende loke he neủer so rogħ
A nay late be þi philosophres stone
Elexir clepid we sechen fast echoıı̄un
For hadde we hym þan̄ were we siker ynogħ
But vn to god of heuen I make avow
For aƚƚ oure craft whan̄ we han aƚƚ y doo
Aƚƚ oure sleight he wole not come vs too
He hath vs made spend mocħ goode
For sorwe of whicħ almost we wexen woode
Bot þᵗat goode hope crepitħ in oure herte
Supposyng eủer þogħ we sore smert
To be relevid by hym aft̉erwarde
Supposyng eủer and hope is sharp ⁊and herd
I warne ȝoᵘ wele it is to seke euer
That future temps hatħ made men̄ disseủere
In trust þer of from aƚƚ þᵗat eủer þei hadde
Ȝet of þᵗatat arte þei coutħ not wex sadde
For vn to hem it is a bitter swete
So semetħ it for ne hadde þei but a shete
Whicħ þei myȝte wrappe in a nyȝt
And a bak to walken in by day lyght
Thei wolde hem self sellen̄ ⁊and spenden̄ on þˡˢ cᵃrafte
Thei can̄ not stynt tiƚƚ no thyng be lafte
And eủer more where þᵗat eủer þei goone

For aƚƚ þe worlde þei stynken̄ as a goote
Here sauoure is so Rāmmyssħ and so hoote

And ȝif a man̄ wole aske hem pⁱriuely

And wete ȝe how fuƚƚ ofte hit happetħ soo

Ȝet is there here þogh we haue not aƚƚlle
And þogħ this þing mysh apped hath as now
A nother tyme it may be wele ynowȝ
Vs most put our͗e good in auenture
A m̉erchant ꝑparde may not ay endure
Trustneȝ me wele it is ꝓprosꝑperite
Some tyme is drowned in þe see
And sūmtyme cometħ it safe vn to þe lande
Pees qduod my lord þe next tyme I wole fonde
To bryng oure cᵃrafte aƚƚ in anoth̉er plyte
And but I do sirs late me haue the wyte
There was defaute in sūmwhat wele I wote
An oþ̉er syde the fyr͗e was oủer hoote
But be hit hote or colde I dar say this
That we concluden eủer more amys
We failen of þᵗat whicħ þᵗat we wolde haue We faylen of the
And in oure madnesse eủer more we rave
And whan̄ we bene to geder eủerychon̄
Eủery man semetħ as wyse as salomon̄
But al thing whicħ þᵗat semetħ as þe gold
Is not gold as I haue herd y tolde
Ne eủery appuƚƚ þᵗat is faire at eye
Ne is not goode what so eủermen̄ clappe or crye
Right so loo faritħ it among vs
He þᵗat semeth þe wysest by iħsihesu
Is moost foole whan̄ it cōmmeth to þe preefe
And he þᵗat semetħ trewist is a theefe
That shuƚƚ ȝe knowe or þᵗat I from ȝoᵘ wende
Be þᵗat I of my tale haue made an ende
Ther is a chanoıı̄un of Religioıı̄un
Amonges vs wold enfecte aƚƚ þe toun̄
Thogħ it as grete were as was Niniue
Rome Alisandre troye ⁊and oth̉re thre
His sleightes and his infinite falsenes
Ther couth no man̄ writen̄ as I gesse
Þogħ þᵗat he myȝt leven̄ a þousand ȝeer͗e
In aƚƚ this worlde of falsnes nys his peer͗e
For in his termes he wole hym so wynde
And speke his wordes in so sleȝ a kynde
Whan̄ he cōmunne shaƚƚ wᵗith any wight
What he mᵃke hym doute anon̄ right
But if the fende be as hym self is
Ful mony man̄ hatħ he begyled or this
And wiƚƚ ȝif þᵗat he may lyve a while
And ȝit men̄ riden̄ ⁊and goone ful mony a myle
Hym for to seke and haue aqueyntance
Not knowyng of his fals gouernaunce
And ȝif the lust to ȝif me audience
I wole it tellen̄ here in your͗e p̉ersenc
div.fw: The tale of þᵉ Chanons yemān
div.l: But worshipfuƚƚ Chanoıı̄un religeous 205
Ne demetħ not þat I sclaundre your͗e hous
Al þogħ my tale of a chanon be
Of euery ordre some shrew is parde
And god forbede þᵗat aƚƚ a companye
Sholde rewe a syngler͗e mannes folye
To sclaundre ȝoᵘ is not myn̄ entent
But to correcten þat is mys I went
This tale was onely not told for ȝoᵘur
But eke for other mo ȝe wote wele how
That amonges cristes Apostles twelfe
Ther was no traytour but Iudas hym self
Than why shuld þe remanent aƚƚ haue blame
That giltles were by ȝoᵘ say I þe same
Saf onely þis ȝif ȝe wiƚƚ herken me
Ȝif any Iudas in ȝoure couent be
Remevetħ hym by tyme I ȝoᵘ rede
ȜIf shame or losse may causen any drede
And beth no thing displesyd I· ȝoᵘ pᵃray
But in this caas herkeneȝ what I say
In londoıı̄un was a p̉reste an annuelere
That þ̉er in had duellyd many a ȝeere
Whicħ was so plesant ⁊and so seruiciable
Vn to the wyfe as he was at table
That she wold suffre hym no thing for to pay
For borde ne clothyng went he neủer so gay
And spendyng siluer had he right ynowe
Ther of no force I wole ꝓprocede as nowe
And telle fortħ my tale of the chano ıı̄un
That broght this preste to confusyoıı̄un
This false chano ıı̄un come vpon a day
Vn to prestes chambre þere he lay
Besechyng hym to lene hym a certayn
Of gold and he wolde quyte hym agay
Lene me a marke quod he but daies thre
And at my day I woƚƚ hit quyte þe
And it so fynde be ȝe fynde me fals
A noþ̉er day hang me by the hals
This preest hym toke a marke as swytħ
And this chanoıı̄un hym þanked ofte sitħ
And toke his leve ⁊and went fortħ his wey
And at þe thrid day brought his money
And to þe prest he told his gold agayne
Ther of this prest was glad ⁊and fayne
Certes quod he no thyng anoyeth me
To lene a man̄ a noble or two or thre
Or what thing wer͗e in my possessioıı̄un
Whan̄ he so trew is of condicioıı̄un
That in no wyse he broke wole his day
To sucħ a man̄ I can̄ neủer say nay
What qduod this chanoıı̄un shuld I be vntrwe
Nay þat were thing fallen̄ aƚƚ of the newe
Trewth is a thing þᵗat I wiƚƚ eủer kepe
Vnto þe day in whicħ þᵗat I shaƚƚ crepe
In to my grave and ellis god forbede
Bylevith this as siker as is ȝour͗e crede
God þank I and in goode tyme be hit sayde
That þ̉er was neủer man̄ ȝit euyl apayde
For gold ne silủer þᵗat he to me lent
Ne neủer falshede myn̄ herte I ment
And sir qduod he now of my pⁱriuete
Syns ȝe so goodelicħ haue bene to me
And kythed to me so gret gēntilnesse
Somwhat to quyten̄ wᵗith your͗e kyndenesse
I wiƚƚ ȝoᵘ shewe ⁊and ȝif yow lust to lere
I shaƚƚ hit shewe to ȝoᵘ anone ryȝt her͗e
How I can̄ worchen̄ in philophie
div.fw: The tale of þᵉ Chanons yemān
div.l: Taketħ goode hede ȝe shullen seyn at eyȝe 206
That I wole do a maistry or I goo
Ȝee qduod the prest ȝe sir ⁊and wole ȝe soo
Mary þ̉er of I pᵃray ȝoᵘur hertly
At ȝoure cōmmandement sir truly
Quod the chanoıı̄un ⁊and elles god forbede

Loo how this these coutħ his ʆseruice bede The tale of þᵉ Chanons
yemān
Ful sotħ it is þat sucħ ꝓprofred ʆseruice
Stynketħ as wittnesse this olde wyse
And þᵗat fuƚƚ sone I wiƚƚ hit verifie
In this chanoıı̄un is Rote of aƚƚ trecherie
That eủer more delite hatħ ⁊and gladnes
Sucħ feendly þoghtes in his hert emp̉resse
How cristes peple he may to myschefe bryng
God kepe hus frome his fals dissimilyng
What wiste this prest wᵗith whome þᵗat he delt
Ne of his harme cōmmyng no thing he felt
O sely preest O sely innocent
Wᵗith couetyse anone þᵘ shalt be blent
O graceles fuƚƚ blynd is þui conceit
No þing art þᵘ ware of thy deceit
Whicħ that this fox shapen̄ hatħ to þe
His wyly wrenches þᵘ maist not flee
Wherfor to go to þe conclusioıı̄un
That referretħ to þi confusioıı̄un
Vnhappy man̄ anone I wiƚƚ me hye
To telle thyn vnwytte ⁊and þi folye
And eke the falsenes of þat other wrecche
As fer fortħ as my connynge wole strecche
This chanoıı̄un was my lorde ȝe wolde wene
Sir oofte in faitħ ⁊and by þe heuen̄ quene
It was a nother chanoıı̄un and not he
That can̄ an hundretħ fold mor͗e subtilite
He hath betrayed folk mony a tyme
Of hit falsenesse it dulletħ me to ryme
Euer whan̄ I speke of his falshede
For shame of hym my chekes wexen reede
Algates þei be gonne for to glowe
For reednes haue I noone ryȝt wele I knowe
In my visage for fumes dyuerse
Of metals whycħ ȝe haue herde me reherse
Consumed ⁊and wasted him myn̄ reednesse
Now take hede of this chanoıı̄un cursidnesse
Sir qduod he to þe preste late ȝour͗e man̄ goone
And late hym bryng vnces two or three
And whan̄ he cometħ as fast shuƚƚ ȝe see
A wonder þinge whicħ ȝe neủer see ar this
Sir qduod the preest it shaƚƚ be doone y wys
He bad his ʆseruaunt fetchen hem his thyng
And he al redy was at his byddyng
And went hym fortħ ⁊and came anoone agayn
With this quyksilủer shortly for to sayn
And toke þese vnces thre to the chanoıı̄un
And he hit layde faire ⁊and wele adoune
And bad þe ʆseruaunt coles for to brynge
That he anoone myȝt go to his worchyng
The coles ryȝt anoone weren̄ yfette
And this chanoıı̄un toke oute a crosselette
Of his bosom and shewyd hit þe preste
This Instrument qduod he whicħ þᵗat þᵘ seest
Take in þin honde ⁊and put þi self þ̉er in
Of this quyksilủer an vnce ⁊and here begynne
In the name of criste to wex a Philosophr͗e
Ther͗e bene fuƚƚ fewe whiche ᵗat I wiƚƚ ꝓprofre
To shewe hem thus moche of my science
For ȝe shullen seen̄ by exꝑperience
That this quyksilủer I wole mortefie
Right in ȝoure sight anoone with outen̄ ly
div.fw: The tale of þᵉ Chanons yemān
div.l: And make it as goode silủer ⁊and as fyne 207
As þ̉er is any in ȝour͗e purse or myne
Or ellis where and make hit mallyable
And elles holde me fals ⁊and vnable
Amonges folke euer to apere
I haue a powdre her͗e þat cost me der͗e
Shaƚƚ make aƚƚ goode for hit caus of aƚƚlle
My cōmmynge whiche þat I ȝow shewe shaƚƚlle
Whydeth ȝoure man̄ and late hym be þ̉er oute
And shete þe doore whiles we bene aboute
Oure pⁱriuetye þat no man̄ hus aspie
Whiles we werken̄ in this philophie
Aƚƚ as he bad fulfilled was in dede
This ilke ʆseruaunt anoon̄ riȝt oute ȝede
And his mayster shitte þe door͗e anone
And to hur laboure spedely þei goone
The prest at þis cursyd chanons byddyng
Vpon þe fire anoone sette þis thyng
And blewe þe fire ⁊and besyed him fuƚƚ faste
And this chanoıı̄un in to the crosselet caste
A powder noote I wherof þat it was
Y made other of chalke other of glas
Or somwhat elles was not wortħ a flye
To blynde wᵗith þe prest and bad hym hye
These coles for to cowchen aƚƚ a bove
The crosselet for in token̄ þat I þe love
Quod this chanoıı̄un thyn hondes two
Shuƚƚ worche al thinge whicħ as shaƚƚ be doo
Gram̉ercy qduod the prest ⁊and was fuƚƚ gladde
And covched coles as the chanoıı̄un bad
And whiles he besy was this feendly wreccħ
This fals chanoıı̄un þe foule feend hym fecche
Out of his bosome toke a beche cole
In whiche fuƚƚ sotelly was made an hole
And þ̉er in was putte was silủer lymaile
An vnce and stoppyd was wᵗithoute fayle
This hole with wexe to kepe þe lymaile In
And vnderstondetħ þat þis fals gyn
Was not made þere but hit ware made byfore
And other thinges I shaƚƚ telle more
Here afterwarde whicħ that he wᵗith hym broght
Or he came þere to begile hym he thoght
And so dide ar þei went a twynne
Tiƚƚ he had turned hym coutħ he not blynne
It dulletħ me whan þat I of hym speke
On his falshede fayn wolde I me awreke
Ȝif I wyste how but he is here ⁊and þere
He is so variaunt he byde nowhere
But takeȝ hede now sirs for goddes love
He toke his cole of whicħ I spake above
And in his honde he bare hit pⁱiruely
And whiles þe prest covched besyly
The coles as I tolde ȝow or this
This chanoıı̄un sayd frend ȝe doıı̄un a mys
This is not couchyd as it oughte to be
But sone I shaƚƚ amende it qduod he
Now lat me medle þerwitħ but a while
For of ȝoᵘ haue I pyte by seint Gyle
Ȝe bene riȜt hoote I see wele how ȝe swete
Haue here a clotħ and wype awey þe wete
And whiles þe prest hym wyped haas
This chanoıı̄un toke his cole I shrewe his faas
And leyde hit vpon̄ abouen̄ þe mydward
Of þe crosselet and blewe wele afterwarde
Tiƚƚ þat þe coles gonne fast brenne
Now ȝif hus drynke qduod þe chanoıı̄un þenne
As swythe aƚƚ shaƚƚ be wele I vndertake
Sytte vs a doun̄ and lette vs merry mak
div.fw: The tale of þᵉ Chanons yemān
div.l: And whan þe chanoıı̄un bechen̄ cole 208
Was brent al the lymaile oute of þe hole
In to the crosselet anon̄ fil a doun̄
And so it most nedes by resoun̄
Sythens it so euen̄ above couched was
But þ̉er of wyst no thing þe prest alas
He demede al þe coles lyche gode
For of þe sleight nothing he vnderstode
And whan̄ þis alkamystre say his tyme
Riseth vp sir prest and stondeȝ byme
And for I wote wele Ingot haue ȝe noone
Gotħ walketħ fortħ and bryng a chalke stone
For I wole make hit of þe shame shape
That is a Ingot ȝif I may haue happe
And bryng with ȝow a bolle or a panne
Fuƚƚ of water and ȝe shuƚƚ see þanne
How þat oure besynesse shaƚƚ happe ⁊and preve
And ȝet for ȝe shaƚƚ haue no mys byleve
Ne wrong conceyt of me in ȝour͗e absence
I wole not bene oute of ȝour͗e presence
But goo with ȝoᵘ and come with ȝoʷ agayn
The chambre dore shortly to sayn
Thei oppened ⁊and shette ⁊and went fortħ hir weye
And fortħ with hem þei caried þe keye
And cōmmen ageyn witħ outen̄ any delay
What shuld I tarye al þe long day
He toke þe chalk ⁊and shope it in þe wyse
Of an Ingot as I shaƚƚ ȝoᵘ deuyse
I say he toke out of his oue slefe
A tyne of silủer euel mote he chefe
Whicħ þat was but an vnce of weight
And taketħ hede now of his cursed sleigħ
He shope his Ingot in lengħ ⁊and in brede
Of þe theyne witħ outen̄ any drede
So sleghly þat þe prest it not aspyed
And in his slefe agayn he gan̄ it hyde
And from þe fire toke vp his mater
And in to þe Ingot it pytte wᵗith mery chere
And in to þe watir vesseƚƚ he it caste
Whan̄ þat hym lyste and bad þe prest as faste
Loke what þ̉er is put in thy honde ⁊and grope
Thou shalt þ̉ere in fynde silủer as I hope
What devel of helle shuld it ellys be
Shauynge of silủer silủer is parde
He put in his honde ⁊and toke vp a teyne
Of silủer fyne ⁊and gladde in eủery veyne
Was this prest whan̄ þᵗat he sawe þat it was so
Goddes blessyng ⁊and his moders also
And al halowes haue ȝe sir chanoıı̄un
Seide þe preste and I here malysoun̄
But and ȝe vouche saue to teche me
This noble cᵃraft and þis sotelte
I wole be your͗e in al þat euer I may
Quod the chanoıı̄un ȝet wole I make assay
The secunde tyme þᵗat ȝe may take hede
And bene exꝑperte of this ⁊and in ȝour͗e nede
An oþ̉er day in myne absence
This disciplyne ⁊and this cᵃrafty science
Late take a noþ̉er vnce qduod he þoo
Of quyksilủer wᵗithoute wordes mo
And þo þ̉erwith as ȝe han̄ doıı̄un ar þis
With that other whicħ þᵗat now silủer is
This prest hym besecħ in aƚƚ ᵗat he can̄
To done as this chanoıı̄un this cursid man̄
Cōmaundeth hym ⁊and fast blewe þe fire
For to come to þe effecte of his desire
And this chanoıı̄un right in þe mene whil
div.fw: The tale of þᵉ Chanons yemān
div.l: Al redy was this prest eft to begile 209
And for a contenaunce in his hond bare
An holwe stikke take hede ⁊and be ware
In þe ende of whicħ an vnce ⁊and no more
Of siluer ⁊and no more lymaile put was al befor͗e
As was in his coole ⁊and stopped wᵗith wex wele
For to kepe in his lymaile euery dele
And whiles þis prest was in his besynesse
This chanoıı̄un with his stikke gan̄ hym dresse
To hym anone ⁊and his poudre cast in
As he dede ere þe deuel oute of his skynne
Hym torne I prey to god for his falshede
For he was euery fals in otħ ⁊and dede
And with his styke above the crosselet
That was ordened wᵗith that fals gette
He stereth þe cooles til relent gan
The wax ageyn þe fire as eủery man̄
But hit a foole be wote wele ⁊and mote nede
And al þᵗat in þe hole was oute ȝede
And in to þe crosselet hastily it felle
The prest supposid no thing but wele
But besyed hym wele ⁊and was wonder fayn
Supposyng noght but trought sotħ to sayn
He was so glad I can̄ not expresse
In no maner͗e his mertħ ⁊and his gladnes
And the chanoıı̄un he profred eft sone
Body ⁊and goode ȝee qduod the chanoıı̄un sone
Þogħ I pore be crafty þᵘ shalt me fynde
I warne the ȝit is þere more behynde
Is there any cooper here in said he
Ȝee sir qduod the prest I trowe þ̉ere be
Elles go bye som ⁊and þᵗat as switħ
Now ʆser go fortħ þi wey ⁊and hithe
And wente his way ⁊and with this cooꝑper he cam
And this chanoıı̄un in his hand it nam
And of that cooꝑper weyde out but an vnce
Al to symple is my tonge to ꝓpronounce
His moustre and his wytte þe doublenesse
Of this chanoıı̄un roote of cursednesse
He semed frendly to hem þᵗat knew hȳm noght
But he was fendly botħ in werke and thoght
It werieth me to telle of his falsnes
And natheles ȝit wole I expresse
To þat entent þat men̄ may be war͗e þ̉er by
And for non̄ other caus trewely
He pitte this vnce of cooꝑper in to þe cᵒrosselet
And on̄ þe fire as switħ he hattħ it sette
And kest in poudre and made þe p̉reste to blowe
And in his werchyng for to stowpe lowe
As he dyd erst and aƚƚ nas but a Iape
Right as hym luste þe prest he made his ape
And afterward in to þe Ingot he it cast
And in his panne put hit at laste
Of water ⁊and in he put his owne hand
And in his sleef as ȝe before hand
Herd me telle he had a silủer teyne
He sliely toke it out þis cursed heyne
Vnwyttyng his prest of his false cᵃrafte
And in the pānnes bothom he hatħ it laft
And in þe water romblitħ to ⁊and froo
And wonderly pⁱriuely tooke hit vp also
The couꝑper þene not knowynge þis prest
And hidde it ⁊and hent hym by þe brest
And to hym spake ⁊and thus seid to hym īn his game
Stowpetħ a doun̄ by god ȝe bene to blame
Helpetħ me now as I ded ȝoᵘ whyle er͗
Put in ȝoure hond and loketħ what her͗e is 210
This preest toke vp this silv̉er þen̄ anoone
And þan seid the chanoıı̄un lete vs goone
With this thre teynes whicħ þᵗat we haue wroght
To some goldsmyth ⁊and wyt ȝif hit be oght
For by my faith I nold for myn̄ hoode
But ȝif thei were silủer fyne ⁊and goode
And þᵗat as switħ proved shaƚƚ hit be
Vnto this goldsmytħ wᵗith this teynes thre
Thei went ⁊and putte þese teynes īn assay
To fire ⁊and hamer myȝt no man̄ say nay
But thei were as thei ought to be
This sottyd preste who was gladder þan̄ he
Was þ̉er neuer bridde gladder aȝens þe day
Ne nyȝtingale in the seson̄ of may
Was þer neủer none þat lust bett̉er to syng
Ne lady lustier in carolynge
And for to speke of love ⁊and of wōmmanhede
Ne knyȝt in armes doone any hardy dede
To stonden in grace of his lady dere
Than̄ had this prest þis cᵃraft to lere
And to þe chanoıı̄un þus he spake ⁊and seid
For þe loue of god þᵗat for vs aƚƚ deide
And as I may deserue it to ȝoᵘ
What shaƚƚ this receit coste now
By oure lady qduod the chanoıı̄un it is der͗e
I warne ȝoᵘ for safe I ⁊and an Frere
In englond þ̉er can no man it make
No forse qduod he now sir for goddes sake
What shaƚƚ I pay tel me I þe pᵃray
I wys qduod he it is fuƚƚ dere I say
Sir at oo worde ȝif þᵗat ȝe lust it haue
Ȝe shaƚƚ pay fourty pounde so god me sav
And ne were þe frendship þᵗat ȝe did er this
To me ȝe shuld pay more y wys
This prest þe sōmme of fourty pound anoone
Of nobles fette ⁊and toke hym eủerychon̄
To this chanoıı̄un for thise ilke receit
Al his worchynge was fraude ⁊and deceit
Sir p̉rest he said I kepes for to haue no loose
Of my cᵃraft for I wolde it were y kept cloos
And as ȝe louetħ me kepetħ it secrete
For and men̄ knew al my sotelte
By god men̄ wold haue so gret envye
To me by caus of my philosophie
I shuld be dede þer wer͗e non̄ other weye
God it forbede qduod the priest what ȝe seye
Ȝet had I lever spenden̄ aƚƚ þe goode
Whicħ þat I haue ⁊and ellis wexe I woode
Than̄ þat ȝe shuld fallen̄ in sucħ myschefe
For ȝoure goode as wele as haue I ryȝt goode p̉refe
Quod the chanoıı̄un ⁊and sir wel gᵃraunt mercy
He went his wey ⁊and neủer the prest hym sey
Aft̉er þᵗat day ⁊and whan̄ þᵗat this prest shuld
maken̄ assay at sucħ tyme as he wolde
Of his receit fare wele it wolde not be
Loo thus be iaped ⁊and begyled was he
Thus makeȝ he his introduccioıı̄un
To bringe folk to hur destruccioıı̄un
Consideretħ sirs how þᵗat in icħ astate
Bytuyx men̄ ⁊and gold þer is debate
So ferfortħ þat vnnethes þer is oone
This multiplying blendetħ so many oone
That in goode feitħ I trowe þᵗat it be
The caus grettest of this grete scarsyte
This philosophres speken̄ so mystel
In this cᵃraft þᵗat men̄ can̄ not come þ̉erby 211 Richard
For any wyt þᵗat men̄ han now an daies
Thei may wele chitre ⁊and iangle as doon þese Iaies
And in her termes sette lust ⁊and peyne
But to her purpos shul þei neủer atteyne
And a man̄ may lightlicħ lerne ȝif he have oght
To multiplie and bryng his goode to noght
Loo sucħ a lucre is in þis lusty game
A mānnes myretħ it wil turne aƚƚ to grame
And empty also grete ⁊and hevy purses
And make folke to purchasen curses
Of hem þᵗat han þ̉er to hire goode y lent
O fy for shame þei that haue be brent
Alas kan þei not fle þe fires hete
Ȝe that it vsen I rede ȝe it lete
Leest ȝe lese for bete þan neủer is late
Neuer to thryfe were to long a date
Þogħ ȝe prolle ay ȝe shuƚƚ it neủer fynde
Ȝe bene as bolde as is bayarde þe blynde
That blundrith fortħ and ꝑperile casteȝ he none
He is as bolde to renne agayn a stone
As for to go bysedes in the wey
So fare ȝe þᵗat multiplie y seye
Ȝif þᵗat oure eyn can̄ not seen a right
Loketħ þᵗat ȝoure mynd lakke noght his sight
For þogħ ȝe loke neủer so brode ⁊and stare
Ȝe shullen not wynne a myte in þᵗat chaffare
But wasten aƚƚ þᵗat ȝe may Rappe and renne
With drawe þe fire lest it so fast brenne
Medeletħ nomor͗e wᵗith þᵗat arte y mene
For Ȝif ȝe doone ȝoure thrift is gone so clene
And riȜt as switħ I wole ȝoᵘ telle here
What þᵗat þe philosophres seyen in this mater
Loo þus seitħ arnold of þe town̄
As his Rosarie makeȝ mencioıı̄un
He seith riȝt thus wᵗith outen̄ any lye
Ther may no man̄ m̉ercurie mortefye
But ȝif hit be with his brotheris knowlechyng
How þat he with that ferst seid þis thyng
Of philophres fader was hermes
He seith how þe dragon douteles
Ne deitħ not but ȝif he be slayn
With his brother ⁊and þat is for to sayn
By þe dragon m̉ercurie and non̄ other
He vnderstode þᵗat bremston̄ wer͗e his brother
That oute of sol ⁊and luna wer͗e y drawe
And þ̉erfore saide he tak hede to my sawe
Late no man̄ besye hym in this arte for to seche
But he þᵗat intencione and þe speche
Of philophres vnderstond can̄
And ȝif he doo he is a lewyd man̄
For this science ⁊and this connynge qduod he
Is of the secre of secrees parde
Also þ̉er was a disciple of Plato
That one a tyme said his maist̉er to
As his booke somer wiƚƚ ber͗e wittenes
And this was his demaunde in sothfastenes
Telle me þe name of the pⁱriuey stone
And plato answerde to hym anone
Take þe stone that titanos men̄ name
Whicħ is that qduod he magnasia þe name
His disciple seid ȝee sir ⁊and is it thus
This is ignotūm ꝑper ignocius
What is magnasia goode sir I ȝoᵘ pray
It is a water þᵗat is made I say
Of elementis foure quod plat
Telle me þe roche goode ʆser qduod he tho 213
Of that water ȝif it be your͗e wille
Nay nay qduod plato c̉erten þat I nylle
The philophres were sworne echon
That þei shuld discoủere it to no man̄
Ne in no booke it write in no maner͗e
For vn to crist it is so leef a der͗e
That he wiƚƚ not þᵗat it discouerd be
But where it lyketh to his deite
Man̄ to enspire and eke to defende
Whan̄ þat hym lyketħ loo this is þe ende
Than conclude I þus syns þᵗat god of heuen
Ne wole not þat philosophres neuene
How þᵗat a man shaƚƚ come vn to þis stone
I reede as for þe best late it gone
For who so maketħ god his aduersarie
As for to worche eny thyng in contrarie
Vn to his wille certes neủer shaƚƚ he thryfe
Þogħ he multiplie terme of his lyfe
And there apoynte for endyd is my tale
God send euery trwe man̄ bote of his bale

Whan that this yōmman his tale endyd hadde The pro
loge
Of this fals chanon whicħ þᵗat was so badde
Oure ooste gan say truly ⁊and c̉ertayn
This prest was begiled sothely for to sayn
He wenynge for to be a philosophre
Til he right no gold left in his cofre
And sothly þis prest had a lyther Iape
This cursyd chanon put in his hoode an ape
But aƚƚ this passe I oủer as now
Sir doctour of phisyke I pᵃray ȝow
Telle vs a tale of som honest mater
Hit shaƚƚ bedone ȝif þᵗat ȝe wole hit her
Saide this doctor ⁊and his tale bygan anone
Now gode men duod he herkeneȝ euerychone
Ther was as telletħ vs tytus Lyueus
A knyght þᵗat clepid was Virgineus
Fulfilled of honoures ⁊and worthynes
And strong of frendes ⁊and of richesse
A doghter he hadde by his wyfe
And neủer had he mo in aƚƚ his lyfe
Fayre was this mayde in excellent beaute
Abouen euery wight that man̄ may see
For nature hatħ witħ soủerayne diligence
Formyd hir in so grete excellence
As þogħ she wolde say loo I nature
Thus can I forme ⁊and peynte a creature
Whan þat me list who can me contrefeite
Pigmalion noght þougħ he alwey forge ⁊and bete
Or grave or peynte for I dar wele sayn
Apellus zepherus shuld worche in vayn
To grave or peynte or forge or bete
Ȝif thei p̉resumed me for to contrefete
For he that is the formoᵘur principale
Hatħ made me his vicar generale
To fourme ⁊and peynte icħ erthly creature
Right as me lust for aƚƚ thing is in myn cure
Vnder the moone þᵗat may wane ⁊and waxe
And for my werke no thyng wole I axe
My lorde and I bene fully at acorde
I made hur to þe worship of my lorde
So do aƚƚ myn other creatures
Of what coloure þei be or what figures
Thus semeth me þᵗat nature wolde say
This mayde was of age xij ȝer͗e ⁊and tway
In whicħ that natur͗e hath suche delyt
For whiche as she can̄ peynt as lilie whyte 213
And redy as rose riȝt wᵗith sucħ paynture
She paynted hath this noble creature
Er she was borne vpon hir lȳmmes free
Were also bryȝt sucħ colours shuld be
And Phebus dyed had hyr tresses grete
Lyke to þe stremes of hys bornyd hete
And ȝif that excellent she was hir beaute
A þousand folde more vertuos was she
In hir ne lakketħ no condicione
That is to preys as by discrecione
As wele in body as gost chaste was she
For whicħ she floured in virginite
With aƚƚ humilite and abstinence
With aƚƚ attemꝑperaunce ⁊and pacience
With mesure eke and beryng of array
Discrete she was in answeryng alway
Þogħ she was wyse as pallas dar I sayne
Hir facounde eke fuƚƚ wōmmanly ⁊and playne
None cont̉refetyd termes had she
To seme wyse but after hur degre
She spake ⁊and alle hur wordes more ⁊and lesse
Sownyng in vertu and in gentilnes
Shamefast she was a maydenes shame fastenes
Constant in hert and eủer in besynes
To dryfe hir oute of hir slogardie
Bachus had of hir moutħ no maistrie
For wille ⁊and thoght done Venus encrece
As men in fire wole casten oyle or greese
And of hir owne vertu vnconstreyned
She hath fuƚƚ ofte tyme hir seke feyned
For þat she wolde fle þe companye
Where lykly was to treten of foly
As is at festes revelles and daunces
That bene occasions of daliaunces
Sucħ thinges maken children for to be
To sone rype ⁊and bolde as men̄ may see
Whiche is fuƚƚ ꝑperilous and hatħ bene ȝore
For al to sone may she lerne lore
Of boldenesse whan she is a wyfe
And ȝe maistres in your͗e olde lyfe
That lordes doughtres han in goủernance
Ne takeȝ of my word no displesaunce
Thinges þat ye bene sette in goủernance
Of lordes doghters oonly for ij thynges
Outher for ȝe han kept your honeste
Outher ellys ȝe han falle in frealte
And wele knowen y noght þe olde daunce
And kan forsake fully meschaunce
For eủer more þ̉erfortħ for cristes sake
Kepetħ wele þo þat ȝe vndertake
A theefe of venyson that hatħ forlaft
His licorousnesse and aƚƚ his theses crafte
Kan kepe a foreste beste of any man̄
Now kepetħ hem wel for and ȝe wil ȝe kan̄
Lokeȝ wele to no vice þᵗat ȝe assent
Leest ȝe be dampned for youre euel entent
For who so dotħ a traytour is c̉ertayn
And taketħ of þat þᵗat I shaƚƚ sayne
Of aƚƚ tresoun̄ souerayn pestilence
Is whan a wight betrayetħ Innocence
Ȝe fadres and modres also
Þogħ ȝe han children be it oone or moo
Youre is the charge of alle her sufferance
Whiles thei bene vnder goủernance
Beth ware þat be ensample of your͗e levyng
Outher be negligence in chastisinge 214
That thei ne peryssħ for I dar wele seye
Ȝif þat þei done þei shuƚƚ fuƚƚ dore abeye
Vnder a sheparde softe and necligent
The wolfe hatħ many a sheepe ⁊and lamb to rent
Suffisetħ one ensample now as here
For I mote turne aȝen to my matere
This mayde of whicħ I telle my tale exp̉resse
She kept hir self hir nedid no maistresse
For in hir levyng maidens myȝt rede
As in a boke eủery good worde ⁊and dede
That longetħ to a maiden vertuous
She was so prudent ⁊and so bountevous
For whicħ oute sprang on eủer syde
Botħ of hir beaute ⁊and of hir bounte wyde
That louyd vertu saf envy allone
That sory is of other mennes wele
And glad is of his sorwe ⁊and vnhele
The doctour makeȝ this discⁱripcion
This mayde went on̄ a day in to þe toun̄
Toward þe temple witħ hir moder dere
As is of yong maidens the manere
Now was ther a Iustice in the toun̄
That goủernour was of that regioun̄
And so byfeƚƚ this Iuge his eyen̄ cast
Vpon̄ this maide avyseng hir fuƚƚ fast
As she cam fortħ by þer þe Iuge stoode
Anone his hert chaungetħ ⁊and his moode
So was he caught witħ beaute of this mayde
And to hym self fuƚƚ pⁱriuely he seyde
This mayde shaƚƚ be myn for ony man
Anone þe feend in to his hert roone
And taght hym sodenly by what sleygh

div.l: (base) This mayden to his purpos wynne myghte
(base) For certes by no force ne by no meede
(base) Hym thoughte he was nat able for to speede
(base) For she was strong of freendes and eek she
(base) Confermed was in swich souerayn bountee
(base) That wel he wiste he myghte hir neuere wynne
(base) As for to make hire with hir body synne
(base) For which by greet deliberacioun
(base) He sente after a cherl was in the town
(base) Which that he knew for subtil and for bold
(base) This Iuge vnto this cherl his tale hath told
(base) In secree wise and made hym to ensure
(base) He sholde telle it to no creature
(base) And if he dide he sholde lese his heed
(base) Whan that assented was this cursed reed
(base) Glad was this Iuge and maked hym gret cheere
(base) And yaf hym yiftes preciouse and deere
(base) ¶ Whan shapen was al hir conspiracie
(base) Fro point to point how that his lecherie
(base) Parfourned sholde been ful subtilly
(base) As ye shul heere it after openly
(base) ¶ Hom goth the cherl that highte Claudius
(base) This false Iuge that highte Apius
(base) So was his name for this is no fable
(base) But knowen for historial thyng notable
(base) The sentence of it sooth is out of doute
(base) This false Iuge gooth now faste aboute
(base) To hasten his delit al that he may
(base) And so bifel soone after on a day
(base) This false Iuge as telleth vs the storie
(base) As we fine writen in olde storie
(base) As he was wont sat in his Consistorie
(base) And yaf his domes vpon sondry cas
(base) ¶ This false cherl cam forth a ful gret pas
(base) And seyde lord if that it be youre will
