div.l: (base) As dooth me right vpon this pitous bille
(base) In which I pleyne vpon Virginius
(base) And if that he wol seyn it is nat thus
(base) I wol it preue and fynde good witnesse
(base) That sooth is that my bille wol expresse
(base) ¶ This Iuge answerde of this in his absence
(base) I may nat yeue diffynytif sentence
(base) Lat do hym calle and I wol gladly heere
(base) Thow shalt haue al right and no wrong heere
(base) ¶ Virginius cam to wite the Iuges wille
(base) And right anon was rad this cursed bille
(base) The sentence of it was as ye shul heere
(base) ¶ To yow my lord sire Apius so deere
(base) Sheweth youre poure seruant Claudius
(base) How that a knyght called Virginius
(base) Agayns the lawe agayn al equitee
(base) Holdeth expres agayn the wyl of me
(base) My seruant which that is my thral by right
(base) Which fro myn hous was stole vpon a nyght
(base) Whil that she was ful yong this wol I preue
(base) By witnesse lord so that it nat yow greue
(base) She nys his doghter nat what so he seye
(base) Wher to yow my lord the Iuge I preye
(base) Yeld me my thral if that it be youre wille
(base) Lo this was al the sentence of his bille
(base) ¶ Virginius gan vpon the cherl biholde
(base) But hastily er he his tale tolde
(base) And wolde haue proued it as sholde a knyght
(base) And eek by witnessynge of many a wight
(base) That it was fals that seyde his Aduersarie
(base) This cursed Iuge wolde no thyng tarie
(base) Ne here a word moore of Virginius
But ȝaf his iuggement and seid thus
I deme anone this cherk his ʆseruaunt haue
Thou shalt no lenger in thy hous hir safe
Go bryng hir fortħ ⁊and put hir in our͗e warde
This cherk shaƚƚ hane his thraƚƚ thus I awarde
And whan̄ this worthy knyȝt virgineus
Þurgħ the assent of þe Iuge apius
Most by force his dere doght̉er ȝeven
Vnto þe Iuge in lecherie to leven
He goth hym home ⁊and set hym in his halle
And lete anone his doghter calle
And wᵗith a face deed as asshen colde
Vpon̄ hir humble face he gan byholde
With faders pyte stykeng þurgħ his hert
Al wolde he not frome his purpos nat cōnuerte
Doghter qduod he virginea by þe name
Ther bene two weyes other detħ or shame
That þᵘ most suffre alas þᵗat I was bore
For neuer þou deseruest wherfor͗e
To dyen witħ a swerd or wᵗith a knyfe
O dere doght̉er ender of my lyfe
Whicħ I haue fostred vp wᵗith sucħ plesaunce
That þᵘ ne were out of my remembᵃraıı̄unce
O doughter whicħ þᵗat arte my last woo
And in my lyfe my last ioy also
O gēmme of chastite in pacience
Take þᵘ thy detħ for this is my sentēnce
For loue ⁊and not for hate þᵘ most be dede
My pitous hond mote smyte of þin hede
Alas þᵗat eủer Apius þe say
Thus hath he falsely Iugged þe to day
And told hir alle the caas as ȝe bifor͗e
Han herd nat nedetħ not to telle hit nomore M̉ercy der
Mercy dere fader quod this mayde 216
And witħ that worde she botħ her armes layde
Aboute his necke as she wonte to do
The terys brasten oute of hir eyen two
And said good fader shaƚƚ I dye
Is there no gᵃrace is there no remedye
No certes dere doughter myn qduod he
Than ȝif me lefe fader myn qduod he
My detħ to complene a litel space
For parde ieffa ȝaf his doghter gᵃrace
For to complene or he hir slougħ alas
And god hit wote no thing was hir t̉respas
But þᵗat she ran hir fader ferst to see
To welcome hym wᵗith grete solempnite
And witħ that worde she felle on̄ swoun̄ anoone
And after whan̄ hir swonyng was goone
She risetħ vp and to hir fader sayde
Blessed be god þᵗat I shaƚƚ dye a mayde
Ȝif me my detħ er þᵗat I haue a shame
Do witħ youre child ȝoure wylle a goddes name
And with þat worde she p̉reyetħ fuƚƚ ofte
That witħ his swerd he shuld smyte hir softe
And with that worde on̄ swoun̄ doun̄ she felle
Hir fader with that fuƚƚ sorufuƚƚ hert ⁊and felle
Hir heede of smote and by þe top it hente
And to þe Iuge he ȝaf it to p̉resente
As he sat in his dome in consistorye
Whan the Iuge it saw as seith þe storye
He bad take hym and honge hym also faste
But riȝt anone aƚƚ þe peple in thraste
To save the knyȝt for revtħ and for pyte
For knowen̄ was þe folys iniquite
The peple anone had suspecte in þis thin
By maner of this cherkis chalengynge
That it was by thassent of Apius
Thei wiste wele that he was lecherous
For whicħ vn to this apius þei gone
And kesten hym in a pⁱrison̄ riȝt anone
Wher͗e he slouȝ hym self and claudius
That ʆseruant was vn to this apius
Was demed for to honge vpon a tre
But virgineus of his grete pyte
Praied for hym that he was exiled
And ellis c̉ertes he had bene begiled
The remanent wer͗e honged mor͗e ⁊and lesse
That consentid wer͗e to his cursidnes
Here may men̄ see how synne hath his meryte
Be ware for no man̄ wote how god wil smyte
In no degree ne in whicħ man̉er wyse
The worme of conscience wiƚƚ aryse
Of wikked lyfe þougħ it so p̉reuy be
That no man̄ wote of it but god ⁊and he
Whethir he be lewyd man̄ or lernyd
He not how sone at he may bene aferyd
Therfor͗e I rede ȝoᵘ this councele take
For saketh synne or synne ȝoᵘ forsake
Owr͗e oste gan swere as he wer͗e woode
Harrow qduod he by nailes ⁊and by bloode
This was a cursed thefe a fals Iustice
As shamefuƚƚ detħ as herte am devyse
So falle vpon his body and his bonys

The deuel I be take hym aƚƚ at ones The Pardoners
prologe
Alas to dere bought she hir beaute
Wherfore I say that aƚƚ men̄ may see
That ȝiftes of fortune or of nature
Beth cause of detħ of many a creatur
Hir beaute was hir detħ I dar wele sayn 217
Allas so pitously as she was slayn
As botħ ȝiftes as I speke of now
Men han ful ofte more harme þan̄ prowe
But truly myn owne maister dere
This is a pitous tale for to here
But natheles passe oủer is no force
I pᵃray to god so save þi gēntil corpe
And thyn vrinales and thi Iurdens
Thyn ypocᵃras and eke þin galions
And euery box fuƚƚ of lectuary
God blesse hem ⁊and our͗e lady seint mary
So mote I the þou arte a ꝓpropr͗e man̄
And ylyke a prelate by seint marie
Save þᵗat I can not wele speke wele in terme
But wel I wote þᵘ dost myn hert erme
That I·haue almost caught a cardinacle
By corpꝰus bones but I haue triacle
Or ellys a draught of moist or corny ale
Or but I here anone a mery tale
Myn hert is lost for pite of this maide
Thou bell amy Iohn̄ ꝐPardoner he saide
Teƚƚ vs sūm mertħ or Iapes riȝt anone
Hit shaƚƚ be do qduod he by seint Rynione
But first qduod he here at þe next ale stake
I wole drynke and ete of a cake
But riȝt anone this gēntiles gonne to crie
Nay lete him teƚƚ hus of no ribaudie
Teƚƚ vs som morale thing þᵗat we may lere
Som wytte and than wiƚƚ we gladly here
I graunte ywys qduod he but I most thynke
Vppon̄ som honest thing while þᵗat I drynke

l.hi: And on þis maner͗e bygan̄ his tale

div.l: Lordynges qduod he in chircħ whan I p̉reche
I peyne me to haue an hawten specħ
I rynge it of as rounde as gotħ a belle
For I can aƚƚ by rotte þat I telle
My teme is alway one and eủer was
Radix oıı̄ıı̄mnium malorꝝrum est cupiditas
Firste I· ꝓpronounce whens þᵗat I· come
And than my bulles shell aƚƚ ⁊and sōmme
Oure liege lordes seale on my patent
That shew I first my body to warent
That no man̄ be so bolde prest ne clerk
Me to disturble of cristes holy werk
And after that telle I fortħ my tales
Bulles of popes and of cardinales
Of patriakes and bisshopes I shewe
And in latyn I speke wordes a fewe
To saver with my p̉redicacioıı̄un
And for to stir men to deuocion

And thus acordyd ben this shrewes tweyne .
To sle the thridde . as ȝe herd me seyne .
This yongest which þat went to þe toun
Ful ofte in his hert it wolowyd vp ⁊and doun
The beaute . of þese florayns faire ⁊and briȝt
O lorde quod he . ȝif it so were I myght
Haue alle this tresour to my self allone .
Ther is no man þat leuyth vnder trone .
Of gold þat shuld lyve . as mery as I
And at þe last þe feend our enmye .
Put in his þought þat he shuld poysou bye .
With which he myght sleen his felawes twye .
For why the fend fond hym in such lyuyng
That he had leue hym to sorwe . bryng
For this was outerly his entent
To sleen . hem bothe ⁊and neủer to repent
And forth he goth no lenger wold he tarye .
In to þe toun vn to apotecarye .
And preyde . hym þat he hym wold selle .
Som poysome . þat he myȝt his rattes kille .
And eke ther was a polkate . in his hawe .
That as he said his capons had slowe .
And seide he wolde . wreke hym ȝif he myght
Of vermyn þat distroied hym by nyght
The apotecarie . ansuerd þou shalt haue .
A thing that as god my sowle save .
In all this worlde . þ̉er nys no creature .
That ete or drynke of this confectur
Noght but þe montance . of a corne of whete .
That he ne shall his life . anone for lete .
Ȝe sterve he shall and þat in lasse while .
Þan þou wolte gone . a paas not but a myle .
This poysou þat is so herd . and violent .
This cursyd man haith in his hond it hent
This poyson in a box and sithens he ran
In to þe nexte strete vn to a man .
And borowyd hym larges botellis three .
To his felawes aȝen reparith he .
The thryd he kept clene . for his drynke .
For all þe nyght he shapped hym to swynke
In caryeng of þat gold . oute of þat place .
And whan this ryatour with sory gᵃce
Had filled with hym his grete botellis thre .
To his felawes repareth aȝen he
What nedith it to serven therof more
For right as þei had cast his deth afore .
Right so þei han hym slayn ⁊and þat anone
And whan þat þis was done þan spake þᵗat one
Now late hus sitte ⁊and drynk ⁊and make hus mery
And afterward we wole his body bery
And after þᵗat hit happed hem ꝑpar caas
To taken a botel . þer in þe poyson was
And drank ⁊and ȝaf his felaw drynk also .
Þurgh whiche anone þei sterven both two
But certes I suppose . þat auicen .
Wrote neủer in none canou ne īn no Fen .
Mo wondre sorwes of emposonyng
Than had these . wretches to her endyng
Thus endyng bene thes homicides two .
And eke this fals empoysoner also .
O cursed synne . ful of all cursednes
O traytoures homicides o wikkidnesse
O glotonye . luxurie ⁊and hasardye .
Thou blasphemor of crist with velanye
And othes grete . of vsage . ⁊and of pryde
Alas mankynd how may hit be tyde .
That thi creatoure . whiche þᵗat þe wroght
And with his pcious blode . þe boght
Thou art so fals ⁊and so vnkynd alas
Now good men god for ȝif ȝoᵘ ȝoᵘur trespas
And kepe ȝoᵘ fro synne of auarice .
My holy ꝑpardon . may ȝoᵘ al warissh
So þat ȝe offre nobles or sterlynges
Other ellis silủer spones broches or rynges
Bowith ȝoure hede . vndir this bulle .
Cometh vp . ȝe wifes offreth ȝoᵘur wolle .
Ȝour name I entre . here īn my rolle anone .
In to þe blis of heuen shull ȝe all gone .
I ȝow assoile . by my hye power
Ȝe þᵗat wolen . offren . as clene . ⁊and eke as cler
As ȝe wer borne . ⁊and lo sirs þus I . pche .
And Ihu crist þat is oure soules leche .
So grant ȝow his ꝑpardone to receve .
For þᵗat is best I wole ȝoᵘ not disceve .
But sirs oo lorde . forgate I in my tale
I haue relikes and ꝑpardoıı̄un in my male .
As faire as any man in Englond
Which þᵗat were ȝif me . by þe popes honde
Ȝif any of ȝow . wil of deuocione .
Offren and han my absolucione
Cometh forth anone ⁊and knelith her adoun
That ȝe may haue ꝑparte of my pardoıı̄un
Or ellis takez ꝑpardone as ȝe wende .
All new ⁊and fressh at euery townes ende .
So þat ȝe offren . al way new ⁊and newe .
Nobles ⁊and pans which þat bene goode ⁊and trewe
Hit is an honour to euery þat bene here
That ȝe may haue . a sufficeant ꝑpardoner
To assoile ȝow in countre . as ȝe ryde .
For auentures which þat may be tyde
For ꝑparauenture . þer may falle one or two
Doun of his horse ⁊and breke his nekke a two
Looke such a surety it is to ȝoᵘ alle
That I . am in ȝour felaschip y falle .
That may assoile . ȝoᵘ both mor ⁊and lasse
Whan þat þe sowle shall fro þe body passe
I reede þat our ooste shall be gynne .
For he is most envolupte of synne
Come forth sir ooste ⁊and offre . first anone .
And þou shalt kysse . þe relykes eủerychon
Ȝe for a grote vnbokel . anone þi . purs
Nay nay qd he . þan haue I . cristis curs
Lete be quod it shall not be . so theche .
Þou woldest make . me kyssen . þin olde brech
And swere . it wer þe relyke of a seint
Þough it were . þi foundamēnt with depeynt
But by þe . croys which þᵗat seint Eleyne fond
I wolde I . had thy coliones in my hond
In stede . of relykes of seint wary
Lete cut hem of and I . wole help . hem carye .
Þei shuld be shryned in an hogges torde
This ꝑpardoner ansuerd not a worde
So wroth he was he wold no worde say
Now qd oure ooste I will no lenger play
With the . ne with none . other angry man
But riȝt anone . þe worthy knyght by gan .
Whan þᵗat he . saw . þᵗat all þe peple . lowhe .
Nomore of this for it is riȝt y nowhe .
Sir ꝑpardoner be mery ⁊and glad of chere .
And ȝe sir ooste þat be to me so dere .
I pᵃy ȝow þat ȝe kysse . þe ꝑpardonere
And ꝑpardoner I . pᵃy ȝow . draw ȝoᵘ nere .
And as we did lete vs lawh and play
And anone þei kissed and ryden forth her way
NOW frondes sayde oure oost so dere
How liketh ȝoᵘ by Iohn̄ ꝑpardoner͗e
For he hath vnbokeld wele þe male
He hath hus tolde riȝt a thryfty tale
As touching of mys goủernaunce
I pᵃray to god ȝif hym good chaunce
As ȝe haue herd of þise ryotours thre
Now gentil maryner hertly I pᵃray the
Telle vs a goode tale ⁊and þat riȝt anone
Hit shall be don̄e by god ⁊and by seint Iohn̄
Seid this maryner as wele as eủer I. can
And riȝt anone his tale he bygan
A merchant whilom duellyd at Seint Denys
That rich was for which men held wyse
A wyfe he had of excellent beaute
And companable ⁊and reuelent was she
Whiche is a thyng þᵗat causeth more dispence
Þan worth is all þe chier and reủerence
That men hem don̄ at festes ⁊and at daunces
Such salutacions and continance
Passeth as doth þe shadow vpon̄ a walle
But woo hym is þat payen mote for alle
The sely housbond algate he mote pay
He mote vs cloth and his arraye
Al for his owne worschip rechely
In which array we dauncen iolily
And ȝif þᵗat he may not ꝑparauenture
Or ellis lust no such dispence endure .
But thinketh þat it is wasted ⁊and y loste
Then mote a nother paien for our͗e cooste
Or leve his gold and þᵗat is ꝑperilous
This noble merchant held a noble hou
For which he had al day grete repaire
For his largenes and for his wyf was faire
That wonder it was but herkeneth to my tale
Amonges al his gestis grete ⁊and smale
Ther was a monke a fair man ⁊and a bolde
I trow a thritty wynter he was olde
That eủer in oone was drawyng to þᵗat place
This yong monk þᵗat was so faire of face
Aqueynted was so wᵗith þᵗat goode man
And eke this monk of which I began
Were both two yborned in oo village
The monke hym claymed as for cosynage
And he aȝein seith not ones nay
But was as glad þ̉erof as foole of day
For to his hert it was a grete plesance
Thus bene knyt with eterne alliance
And ilke of hem gan other assir͗e
Of bretherhode whiles þᵗat her lyf may dure Amen̄
Free was Dan Iohn̄ and namely of dispence
As in that hous and full of diligence
To do plesaunce and also grete costage
He not forȝate to ȝif þe lest page
In al þᵗat hous but after her degre
He ȝaf þe lord and sythens his meneȝe
Whan þᵗat he come some honest thyng
For which þei were as glad of his cōmmyng
As foule is fayn when þe son̄ne vp riseth
Nomore here of this now for þis suffiseth
But so byfell þis merchant on a day
Shope hym to make redy his array
Towarde þe towne of Brugges for to fare
To byen þer a porcion of ware
For which he hath to Parys send anone
A messangere and pᵃraied hath Dan Iohn̄
That he shuld come to seint denys to pleye
With hym ⁊and with his wyfe a day or tweye
Or he to Brugges wen in all wyse
This noble monke of which I. ȝoᵘ devise
Hath of his abbot as hym lust licence
By caus he was a man̄ of high prudence
An eke an officer oute for to ryde
To seen his granges ⁊and her͗e barnes wyde
And vn to seint denys he cōmmeth anoone
Who was so welcome as my lord Dan̄ Iohn
Our͗e dere cosyn full of curtosie
With hym brouȝte he a iobbe of malvesue
And eke an other full of fine vernage
As volatile as ay was his vsage
And þus I lete hem ete ⁊and drynk ⁊and playe
This m̉erchant ⁊and this monke a day or twaie
The thrid day þis m̉erchant vp aryseth
And on̄ þis nedis sadly his aviseth
And vp in to his countyng hous goth he
div.note: amen̄
div.l: To reken with him self as wele as may be
Of þilke ȝer͗e how þᵗat it wᵗith hym stode
And how he dispendid had his goode
And ȝif þᵗat he encresid wer͗e or none
His bokes ⁊and his bagges many oone
He leyeth to fore hym on̄ his countyng borde
Full riche was his tresour ⁊and his horde
For which full fast his counter dore he shette
And eke he nolde þᵗat no man shuld hym lette
Of his acounptes for þe meyne tyme
And þus he sitte til hit was passed pⁱrime
Dan̄ Iohn̄ was risen in þe morwe also
And in þe garden walked to ⁊and fro
And hath his thinges sayde full curtesl
This goode wyfe come walkyng p̉reuely
In to þe garden þer͗e he walked soft
And hym salueth as she hath done ofte
A mayden child come in hir companye
Which as hir lest she may gouerne ⁊and gye
For ȝet vnder þe ȝerd was þe mayde
O dere cosyn myn Daıı̄un Iohn̄ she saide
What eyleth ȝow so rath for to a ryse
Nece quod he it aught ynogh suffise
Fyve oures for to slepe vpon a nyȝt
But it were for an olde palled wight
As bene þese wedded men̄ þᵗat lye ⁊and dare
As in a fourme sitte a verrey hare
Were all for straight wᵗith houndes grete ⁊and smale
But dere nece why bene ȝe so pale
I trow certes þat our͗e goode man
Hath ȝoᵘ laboured sith þe nyght began
That ȝoᵘ wer͗e nede to resten hardely
And with that worde he loketh ful merily
And of his owne thoght he waxe all rede
This fair͗e wyfe gan̄ to shake hir heede
And seid þus ȝe god wote all qduod she
Nay cosyn myne it stant not so wᵗith me
For by þat god þᵗat ȝaf me soule ⁊and lyfe
In all þe Realme of Friᵃaunce is þ̉er no wyfe
Þat lasse hath lust to þᵗat sory play
For I may syngen allas and weleaway
That I was borne but to no wight qduod she
I dar not tellen how it stondeth wᵗith me
Wherfore I. thynk oute of this lond to wende
Or ellis of my self to make an ende
So full I. am of drede ⁊and eke of care
This monke bygan vpon̄ þis wyfe to star
And seid Alas nece god forbede
That ȝe for any sorwe or any drede
For to do ȝoure self but telleth me your͗e grefe
ꝐParauenture I may in your͗e myschefe
Concele or help and þerfore tellith it me
All ȝoure angurs for hit shall be secre
For on̄ my Portose I make an othe
That neuer in my lyfe for lefe ne for loth
Ne shal I. of no concele ȝoᵘ by wreye
The same aȝen to ȝoᵘ quod she I. seye
By goddes ⁊and by þis portous I sweyr͗e
Þough men me wold all in to peces teyr͗e
Ne shall I. neủer for to go to helle
Noght for cosynage ne allyaunce
But verraly for love ⁊and affiaunce
Thus be þer sworne ⁊and her͗e vpon̄ kyste
And ilke of hem told other what hem lyste
Cosyn quod she ȝif I had space
As I haue none namely in this place
Than wolde I. tellen a legent of my lyfe
What I. haue suffred syn I was a wife
Wᵗith my housbond al ȝif he be your͗e cosyn
Nay quod this monk by god ⁊and by seint M̉artyn
He nys no more cosyn vn to me
Then is this leefe þᵗat hongeth vpon̄ þe tree
I clepe hym so by seint denys in Frᵃaunce
To haue þe more caus of aqueyntance
Of ȝoᵘ ye which I haue loued specialy
Abouen al wōmmen sykerly
This swere I ȝoᵘ on̄ my ꝓprofessione
Tellith ȝoᵘ greef lest he come adoune
And hasteth ȝoᵘ and goth ȝour͗e waye anone
My dere love quod she o. daıı̄un Iohn
Full lefe me were þis councele to hyde
But oute it mote it may nomor͗e abide
Myn housbond is to me þe worste man
That euer was sith þe worlde bygan
But sith I. am a wyfe it sytte not to me
To telle no wight of our͗e p̉riuety
Nethir in bedde ne in noone other place
God shild I sholde telle it for his gᵃrace
A wyfe ne shall not say of hir housbond
But al honour͗e as I con vnderstond
Save vnto ȝoᵘ þus moch telle I shall
As helpe me god he not worth at all
In no degre þe value of a flye
But ȝit me greueth most his nygardie
And wele I wote þᵗat wōmmen naturally
Desireth thinges sixe as wele as .I.
Thei wolden þat hir housbond shuld be
Hardy and wyse. ryche ⁊and þ̉er to free
And bux̄on to his wife and fressh a bedde
But by þat ilke lorde that for hus bledde
For his honoure my self to aray
A soun̄day next I. mote pay
An hundred frankes or ellis am I. lorne
Ȝet were me lever þᵗat I. were vnborne
Than̄ me wer͗e done a sclaunder or vilanye
And ȝif my housbonde eke myght aspye
I ner͗e but lost and þ̉erfor͗e I ȝoᵘ preye
Lene me þis sōmme and ellys mote I deye
Dan Iohn̄ lene me this hundred frankes
ꝐPerde .I. will not faile þe my thankes
Ȝif þᵗat luste to do þᵗat I. ȝoᵘ pray
For a certayn day I. wole ȝow pay
And to do ȝoᵘ what plesaunce ⁊and ʆseruic
That I. may do right as ȝou luste devise
And but .I. do god take on me vengeaunce
As foule as hadde genyloıı̄un of Fraunce
This gentill Monk ansuerd in þis manere
Now truly my owne lady dere
I haue quod he on ȝou so grete a revth
That I ȝow swere and plight ȝou my trevth
That whan̄ ȝour͗e housbond is to Flandres fare
.I. will delyủer ȝou out of þis worldes care
For I wole brynge ȝou an hundred frankes
And wᵗith that caught her by þe shankes
And her embrased harde ⁊and kissed ofte
Goth now ȝour͗e weye quod he al stille ⁊and softe
And lete vs dyne as sone as ev̉er ȝe may
For by my chelindre it is P̉rime of day
Goth now ⁊and beth as trew as I. shall be
Now ellis god forbede ʆser quod he
And forth she goth as Iolous as a pye
div.note: Riots
div.l: And badde þe cokes þat þei shulden hye
So þᵗat men̄ myght dyne and þᵗat anone
Vp to hir housbond is this wyfe goone
And knokketh at his countir boldely
Que la quod he Petir it am .I.
Quod she what how longe wole ȝe faste
How long tyme wole ȝe rekene ⁊and caste
Ȝoure sōmmes ⁊and bokes and your͗e thinges
The deuel haue parte on̄ all such rekenynges
Ȝe han̄ ynogh ꝑparde of goddes sonde
Come doun̄ to day ⁊and lete youre baggez stonde
Ne be not ashamed þat Dan Iohn̄
Shall fastyng al þis day elyng gone
What lete hus here masse go we dyne
Wyfe qduod this man litel canst you deuyne
The curious besynes that we hau
For of hus chapmen so god me save
And by þᵗat lord þᵗat calledd is Seint Yve
Scarsely amonges twelue two shullen thryve
Contynuely lastynge vn to our͗e age
We may wele make chere ⁊and goode visage
And dryfe forth þe worlde as it may be
And kepen our͗e estate in pryuete
Till we be dedde or ellis þᵗat we pleye
A pilgrimage or gone oute of þe weye
And þ͗efor͗e haue I grete necessite
Vpon this queynte world to auyse me
For eủermore we mote stond in drede
Of happe ⁊and fortune in our͗e chapmanhede
To Flandres wole I. go to morwe at day
And come aȝen̄ as sone as eủer I. may
For which my dere wif I þe besech
As be to eủery wight buxum ⁊and meke
And for to kepe our͗e goode be curious
And honestly gouerne wele our͗e hous
Thou shalt not in eủery man̉er wyse
That to a thrifty housbond may suffice
The lakketh non̄ aray ne no vitaile
Of silủer in þi purs þou maist not faile
And with that worde his countir dor͗e he shette
And doun̄ he goth no leng̉er nold he lette
And hastely a masse was þ̉er saide
And spedely þe tables wer͗e yleyde
And to þe dyner faste þei hem spedde
And richely þis monk þe chapman̄ fedde
And after dyn̉er Dan Iohn̄ soburly
This chapman̄ toke a ꝑparte al p̉rively
He seid hym þus cosyn it stondeth so
That wele I see to Brugges wole ȝe g
God ⁊and Seint Austyn spede ȝou ⁊and gye
I pᵃray ȝou cosyn wysely þat ȝe ryde
Gouerneth ȝou wele also of your diete
And temꝑperaly and namely in this hete
Bwtuyx his two nedith no grete fare
Far͗e wele cosyn god shild ȝou fro care
Ȝif any thing ther by by day or be nyght
Ȝif it ligge in my power ⁊and my myght
That ȝe me wole cōmmaunde in any wyse
Hit shall be don̄ riȝt as ȝe wole deuyse
O thing or ȝe goo if þat it may be
I wolde prey ȝoᵘ for to leue me
An hundred frankes for a weke or tweye
For certane bestis þat I most bye
To store wᵗith a place þat is oures
God help me so I wold þᵗat it wer͗e ȝoures
.I. shall not faile surely of my day
Nouȝt for a þousand frankes a myle way
But lete this thing be secre I ȝou pray
And god of heuen spede ȝou in ȝoʳure way
And far͗e now wele myn̄ owne cosyn dere
Gram̉ercy of ȝour͗e cost ⁊and of your͗e chere
This noble m̉erchaunt gentily anone
Answerd ⁊and saide O cosyn Dan Iohn̄
Now sikerly this is a smale request
My gold is ȝoures whan̄ þᵗat ȝou lest
And nouȝt onely my gold but my chaffar͗e
Thake what ȝou lust god shilde ȝe spare
But o thing is ȝe knowe it wele y nogh
Of chapmen that her money is her plough
We may creaunce whiles we haue a name
But goldeles for to be it is no game
Paythe hit agayne whan̄ it lyth in ȝour͗e ees
After myn eese fayn wolde I ȝoᵘ plese
These hundreth frankes he fette forth anone
And p̉reuely he toke hem to Dan Iohn̄
No wight in al this worlde wyst of þis lone
Sauyng þis merchant ⁊and Daıı̄un Iohn̄ allone
Thei dranken ⁊and roned and pleie
Til þᵗat Daıı̄un Iohn̄ rideth to his abbey
The morne cam ⁊and forth this m̉erchant rideth
To Flaundres ward his prentys wele hym gydeth
Til he come in to Bruggez merily
Now goth þis m̉erchant fast ⁊and besyly
Aboute his nede and beieth ⁊and creaunceth
He neither pleyeth at þe dyse ne daunceth
But as a merchant shortely for to telle
He lete his lyfe and þer͗e I lete hym dwelle
The soun̄day next þe merchant was agone
To seint Denys ycōmmen is Dan̄ Iohn̄
With crowne ⁊and berde fressh ⁊and new y shave
In all þse hous þere nas so litel a knave
Ne no wight ellys þat he nas fayne
For that my lord Daıı̄un Iohn̄ was cp̄mmen agayn
And shortely to her poynt for to gone
This faire wyfe acordeth to Daıı̄un Iohn̄
And for this hundreth frankes he shuld al nyght
Haue hir in his armes bolte vp right
And this acorder ꝑparformed was in dede
In myrth al nyȝt a besy lyfe þei lede
Til it was day þᵗat Daıı̄un Iohn̄ went his way
And bad þe meneȝe fare wele haue a god day
Fornone of hem ne no wight in the toun̄
Hath of Daıı̄un Iohn̄ right no suspecioun
And forth he rideth home to his abbey
Or where hym lust nomor͗e of hym I se
Then merchaunt whan̄ that endyd was þe faire
To Seint Denys he gan̄ for to repaire
And wᵗith his wyfe he maketh fest ⁊and chere
And telleth hir þᵗat chaffar͗e is so dere
That nedith moste he make a cheueshaunce
For he bounden in a reconisance
To pay XX thousand shildes anone
For which þis m̉erchant is wont to gone
To borwe of certan̄ frendes that he had
A c̉ertane frankes ⁊and some wᵗith hym he lad
And whan̄ þᵗat he was cōmmen in to þe toun̄
For grete chierte ⁊and grete affeccioıı̄un
Vn to Daıı̄un Iohn̄ he first hegoth to pleye
Noȝt for to borwe of hym no money
But for wytte ⁊and see of his welefare
And for to tellen hym of his chaffar͗e
As frendes don̄ whan̄ þei bene mette yfere
Daun Iohn̄ hym maketh feste ⁊and mery chere
And he him tolde aȝen̄ ful specialy
How he had boght full wele ⁊and graciously
Thanked be god all hoole his marchandyse
Save that he most in all man̉er wyse
Maken̄ a cheueshance as for his best
And þen̄ he shulde be in ioy ⁊and reste
Daıı̄un Iohn̄ ansuerd certes Iam fayne
That ȝe in hele be cōmmen̄ home agayn
And ȝif þᵗat I were rich as haue .I. blisse
div.note: mysse
div.l: Of twenty þousand sheldes shuld ȝe not mysse
For ȝe so kyndely this other day
Lent me gold ⁊and as I can ⁊and may
I thanke ȝoᵘ by god ⁊and by Seint Iame
But natheles I toke vn to our͗e dame
Ȝoure wyfe at home the same gold agayn
Vppon̄ ȝoure benche she wote it wele certane
By certen̄ tokens that I can̄ her telle
Now by ȝour͗e leve I may no long̉er dwelle
Oure abbot wole oute of þis toun̄ anone
And in his compainys mote I. gone
Grete wele oure dame myn̄ owne nece swete
And far͗e wele dere cosyn til we mete
This m̉erchant with that was ful ware ⁊and wyse
Creaunsed hath and eke payed in Paryse
To certan̄ lumbardes redy in her hand
This sōmme of gold ⁊and gate of hem þe band
And home he goth mery as a popyngay
For wele he knew he stoode in such aray
That nedes moste he wynne in such a viage
A þousand frankes above all his costage
His wyfe full redy mette hym at gate
As she wonte was of olde vsage algate
And al þᵗat nyȝt in myrth þei be sette
For he was rich ⁊and clerely oute of dette
Whan̄ it was day þis merchant gan enbrace
His wyf al new ⁊and kissed hir on̄ her face
And vp he goth ⁊and maketh it wonder tough
Nomore qduod she by god ȝe haue ynough
And wantonly with hym she pleyde
Til at þe last þᵗat þis m̉erchant seyde
By god qduod he I am a litell wrothe
With ȝou my wife as if it be me loth
And wote ȝe why by god as þᵗat I. gesse
For ȝe haue made a man̉er a straungenes
Betuyx me ⁊and my cosyn Dan̄ Iohn̄
Ȝe shuld haue warned me or .I. had gone
That ȝe had ȝou an hundred frankes payde
By redy tokens ⁊and he hym held yvele apayd
For þᵗat .I. to hym spake of cheuyshaunce
Me semyd so as by his contenaunce
But natheles by god heuen kyng
I thoght nought to axe hym no thyng
.I. pray þe wyfe ne do no mor͗e soo
Telle me alwey er þᵗat fro þe goo
Ȝif any dettoure hath in my absence
Ypaied þe lest thurgh thyn negligēnce
.I. myght hym axe a thyng þᵗat he hath payed
This wyfe nas noght aferde ne affraied
But boldely she said ⁊and þᵗat anone
Marie I. defye þat fals monke Dan̄ Iohn̄
I kepe nought of his tokenes neủer a dele
He toke me certayne gold this wote I wele
What evil thedam on̄ þis monkes snowte
For god hit wote I wende wᵗith outen̄ doute
That he hadde ȝeve it me by caus of yow
To do þ̉er with myn honour ⁊and my prowe
For cosynage and eke for bele chere
That he hadde had full often̄ tyme her͗e
But sethyn .I. see .I stonde in such disiounte
I wole answer͗e ȝou shortely to þe poynte
Ȝe haue mo slakker dettours þan̄ am .I.
For I wole pay ȝou wele ⁊and redily
Fro day to day ⁊and ȝif so be I. faile
I. am ȝour͗e wif score it on̄ my taile
And I shall pay ȝou as sone as eủer I may
For by my trouth I haue on̄ myn array
And noght on wast bystowed euery dele
And for I haue be stowed hit so wele
To ȝour͗e honour͗e for goddes sakke I. say
As be not wrothe but lete vs laugh ⁊and playe
Ȝe shull my ioly body haue to wedd
By god I nyl not paye ȝoᵘ but in bedde
For ȝif it me myn̄ owne spouse der͗e
Turne hiderward and make bett̉re chere
This merchant saw þᵗat þ̉er was no remedie
And for to chide hit nere but folie
Sethyns þat þe thing may not amēnded be
Now wif he seid and I forȝif it the
But by thi lyfe ne be nomor͗e so large
Kepe bet my good þis ȝif I the in charge
Thus endeþ now my taile ⁊and god vs sende
Talynge ynogh vn to oure lyfes ende
WEle seid by corpꝰus d̄omine qduod our͗e ooste
Now lang mote þou saile by þe cost
div.note: Verba hospitis.
div.l: Sir gēntil maister gēntil maryner͗e
God ȝif the monk a þousand laste quade ȝer͗e
A hay felawes beth ware of such a Iape
The monk put in the mānnes hoode a Iape
And in his wifes eke by Seint Austine
Drawith no monkes more in to ȝour͗e In
But now passe oủer and lete hus seke aboute
Who shall now telle ferste of all þis route
A nother tale ⁊and wᵗith þat worde he saide
As curtesly as it had bene a maide
My lady Prioures by your͗e leve
So þᵗat I. wiste I shuld ȝou not greve
I wold deme þat ȝe telle shulde
A tale nexto ȝif so were þat ȝe wolde
Now wole ȝe voche saue my lady dere
Gladly qduod she and said in þis maner͗e
O lord our͗e lord thyn name how m̉ervelous
Is in this large worlde .I spred qduod she
For noght onely thyn hand p̉recious
ꝐPar forned is by men̄ of dignite
div.note: The Prioresse prologe

div.l: But by þs movth of children̄ þin bounte
ꝐParformed is for on̄ our͗e brest sovkynge
Som tyme shewen̄ thei thin heryenge
Wherfore in laude as I can̄ best or may
Of the ⁊and of the white lilie floure
Which that the bare and is a maide alwey
To telle a story .I. will done my labour͗e
Noght þᵗat I. may encrece her honour͗e
For she her self is honour͗e ⁊and þ̉er to rote
Of bounte next her sone and soules bote
O moder maide O maide moder free
O bussh vnbrent brennyng in moises sight
That rauyssh doun̄ fro þe deite
Thurgh thin humbles þe gost þᵗat in the a light
Of whose vertu when̄ he in thin hert alight
Conceyued was þe fadres sapience
Helpe me to telle hit in thyn reủerence
Lady thyn bounte ⁊and thin magnificēnce
Thin vertu ⁊and thin grete humilite
Ther may no tonge exp̉resse in no science
For som tyme lady or men̄ pᵃray to the
Thou goste beforne of thin benignite
And getest hus vn to thin sone so cler͗e
My connyng is to wayke .o blissfull quene
For to declar͗e thin grete worthines
That I ne may the weight not sustene
But as a childe of Xij moneth olde or lesse
That can̄ vnnethees any word exp̉resse
Right so fare .I. and therfore I. ȝoᵘ preye
Gideth my song þᵗat I. shall of ȝoᵘ seye
There was in asie in a gret cite
Amonges cristen̄ folke ⁊and Iewerie
Sustened by a lorde of that countre
For foule vsure and lucre of vilany
Hatfull to criste and to his companye
And thurgh þe strete men myght ride or wende
For hit was fre and open at ẻery ende
A litel scole of cristen folk ther stoode
Doun̄ at þe ferther ende in which þ̉er were
Children̄ anhepe I come of cristen blode
That lerned in that scole ȝere by ȝere
Such man̉er doctrine as men̄ vsed there
This is to sey syngen ⁊and to rede
As smale children don̄ in hir childhede
Among this childhede was a widow sone
A litel clergeon̄ Vij ȝer͗e of age
That day by day to scole was he wone
And eke also wher͗e he sawh þe ymage
Of cristes moder hadde he in vsage
As him was taught to knele adoun̄ ⁊and seye
His Aue maria as he goth by þe weie
Thus hath this wedow her litel taught
Oure blisfull lady cristes moder dere
To worsship ay and he forgate hit nought
For sely childe wole al day sone ler͗e
But ay whan̄ I. remēmbr͗e me on̄ this mater͗e
Seint Nicholas stant eủer in my p̉resence
For he so yong to crist did reủerence
This child his litell boke lernynge
As he satte in the scole at his primer
He Alma redemptoris herd singe
As children̄ lerned her antiphoner
And as he durste he drowe him ner͗e ⁊and nere
And herkneth ay þe wordes ⁊and þe note
Til he þe ferst vers couth all by rote
Noght wiste he what þe latyne was to seye
For he so yonge ⁊and tendr͗e was of ag
But on a day his felawe gan to preye
To expounden hym þis song in his langage
Or tellen hym why this song was in vsage
Thus preide he hym to construe ⁊and declare
Full ofte tymes vpon̄ his knees bare
His felawe whiche elder was than̄ he
Ansuerd hym thus þis song I haue herd seye
Was maked of our͗e lady blisful ⁊and free
Hir to salwe and eke hir to preye
To ben our͗e help ⁊and socour͗e whan̄ we deye
I can no more expoune in this matere
I lerne song I. can but smale gramere
And is songe made in reủerence
Of cristes moder saide this Innocēnt
Now certes I. wole do my diligence
To con hit er cristenmasse be went
Thogh þat I. for my prymer shall be shent
And shall be betyn thries in an hour͗e
I wole hit can oure lady for to honour͗e
His felaw taughte hym pryvely
Fro day to day til he couth hit by rote
And than̄ne he song hit wele ⁊and boldely
Froward toward acordyng to þe note
Thries on̄ a day hit passed thurgh his throte
To scoleward and homewarde whan̄ he wente
On cristes moder sette was his entent
As I haue seid thurgh oute the Iewerye
This litell childe as he cam to ⁊and froo
Full meryly than̄ wolde he syng ⁊and crye
On alma redemptoris euermo
The swetnes hath his herte ꝑperced so
Of cristes moder that to hur to preye
He can not stynt of syngyng by þe wey
Oure firste foo the serpēnt sathanas
That hath in Iewes his waspes neste
Vp swalle ⁊and said o. ebrayke peple alas
Is this a thing to ȝoᵘ that is honeste
That such a body shall walken as hem leste
In ȝour͗e dispite ⁊and syngen of such sentence
Which is aȝen̄ ȝour͗e lawes reủerence
Fro thens forth þe Iewes hym conspired
This innocent oute of this worlde to chace
In homycide þere to han þei huried
That in an Aley had a pⁱriuey place
And as the child gan̄ forby for to pace
This cursed Iewe him hent ⁊and held faste
And cut his throte ⁊and in a pitte him caste
I say þᵗat in a wardrobe ther him threwe
Where as the Iewes purgen entraille
O cursed folke of herawdes al newe
What may ȝour͗e euyl tent ȝoᵘ availe
More wole out certen hit wole not faile
And namely þ̉er honoure of god shuld sprede
The bloode out crieth on̄ ȝour͗e cursed dede
O martir souded to virginite
Now maist þᵘ singen folowyng eủer in one
The white lambe celestiale qduod she
Of which þe grete euᵃaungelist seint Iohn̄
In pathmos wrote which seith that þei þᵗat gone
By for͗e this lambe ⁊and syng a song al newe
That neủer flesshly wōmmen þei knewe
This pore wydowe waiteth all þᵗat nyght
Aft̉er this litel child but home came noght
From whome as sone as hit was daies light
With face pale for drede ⁊and besy thoght
She hath at scole ⁊and ellis where hym sogh
Till fynallye she can̄ so fer aspie
That he was seyn last in þe Iewerie
With modres pite in hir hert enclosed
She goth as þogh she were half oute of mynde
To euery place wher͗e she hath supposed
By likkely hede her child to fynde
And eủer on̄ cristes moder meke ⁊and kynde
She cried ⁊and at þe laste thus she wroght
Amonge the cursed Iewes she hym soght
She freyneth ⁊and she preith pitously
To euery Iewe þᵗat dwelt in thilk place
To telle hir ȝif hir child went hem by
Thei seydeen nay but IħsIhesu of his gᵃrace
Ȝaf in hir thoght in wᵗith a litel space
That in þᵗat place after hir sone she cried
Ther͗e he was cast in a pitte be side
O grete god þat ꝑparformed thyn laude
By mouth of Innocence lo her͗e thy myght
This gēmme of chastite this Emerawde
And eke of martirdome the rubye bright
Ther͗e he wᵗith throte ycorve lay vp right
He Alma redemptoris gan to singe
So longe that alle þe place gan to rynge
The cristen folke þat thurgh þe strete went
In cōomen for to wondren of this thinge
And hastely þei for þe provost sende
He come anone wᵗith oute any taryinge
And herith crist þᵗat is of heuen kyng
And eek his moder honour͗e of mankynde
And after that þe Iewes lete he bynde
This child with pitous lamentacioun̄
Vp taken syngyng his song alway
And with honoure ⁊and grete ꝓprocession
Thei caryen hym to þe next Abbey
His moder swownyng by the bere ley
Vnnetthes myght þe peple that was þere
This now rachell bryng from his bere
With turment ⁊and wᵗith shameful deth ilkone
This prouost doth this Iewes for to sterve
That of this moder wist ⁊and that anone
He nolde noon̄ such cursednes obserue
Euel shall haue that euel wole deserue
Therfore with wilde horses he ded hym drawe
And after þᵗat he hyng hem by þe lawe
Vpon this bere ay lieth this innocent
Biforne the chefe Auter whiles masse last
And after þᵗat þe abbot with his couent
Had spedde hem for to burye hym fast
And whan̄ þei haly water on̄ hym cast
Ȝet spake the child was the haly water
And sang O alma redemptoris mater
This abbot which þᵗat was an̄ holy man̄
As monkes be or ellis oughten to be
This yong child to cōniure he by gan
And said o. dere child I. cōniure the
By vertu of þe holy trinite
Telle me what is þi caus for to synge
Sethyns þᵗat þi throte is cut to my semyng
My throte is cut vn to my nekke bone
Saide this child and as by wey of kynde
I shuld haue deyed ȝe tyme agone
But IħuIhesu crist as ȝe in bokes fynde
Wole that his glorie last ⁊and be in mynde
And for the worschip of his moder dere
Yet may .I. syng O Alma lowde ⁊and clere
This welle of m̉ercy cristes moder swet
I. loued alwey as after my connynge
And whan̄ þat I my lyfe shulde lete
To me she cam and bad me for to syng
This antem veryly in my mynd deyng
As ȝe haue herd ⁊and what þat I haue song
Me thought she leyd a greyn vpon̄ my tong
Wherfore I. synge ⁊and syng mote certeyn
In honoure of þe blisfull martir free
Til fro my tong of taken is the greyn
And after þat seid she thus to me
My litel child now wole I. fetche þe
Whan̄ that thi greyn is fro þi tong y take
Be nough agast I. wole þe noght forsake
This holy monk this abbot hym mene .I.
His tong out caught ⁊and toke awey þe greyn
And vp he ȝaf þe gost full softely
And when þe abbot had this wonder seyn
His salt terys striked doun̄ as reyn
And groffe he fell al plat to þe grounde
And still he lay as he had bene ybounde
The couent eke lay vpon̄ the payuemēnt
Wepyng ⁊and herynig cristes moder dere
And after þat þe ryse ⁊and forth be went
And toke alwey þis martir fro his bere
And in a tombe of marble stones clere
Enclosen̄ þer litel body swete
There he is now god leue vs for to mete
O ȝong hew of lincoln̄ slayn also
With cursed Iewes as it is notable
For it nys but a litel while ago
Prey eke for vs we synfull folk vnstable
That of his mercy god so mercyable
On hus his grete m̉ercy multiplie
For reuerence of his moder mary
WHan̄ ended was this tale of eủery man̄
As sobre was þat wonder it was to se
Til þat our͗e oste yapen̄ to began̄
And than̄ at erst he loked vpon̄ me
And seid thus what man̄ art þou qduod he
Thou lokest as þough you woldest fynde an hare
For eủer vpon þe grounde I se þe stare
Apꝓproche nere and loke vp meryly
Now ware ȝe sirs ⁊and lete this man̄ haue place
He in þe waste is shapen̄ as wele as .I.
This were a popet in armes to enbrace
For any wōmman smale ⁊and fair͗e of face
He semeth elvessh by his countenaunce
For vn to no wight doth he dalyaunce
Say now sūmwhat sethyns other folke han̄ saide
Telle vs a tale of myrthe and þᵗat anone
Ooste qduod he ne be not euyl apayde
For other tales certes can̄ I. none
But of a ryme I lernyd long agone
Ȝe þat is goode quod he now shul we her͗e
Som deynte thing me think by his chere
LEsteneth lordes in goode entent Ryme of Syr Topas
And I will telle verrament
Of merth and of solace
Al of a knyȝt was fair͗e ⁊and gent
In bataile and in tournament
His name was sir Thopas
Yborne he was in ferre countre
In flaundres all by ȝonde þe see
At Poperynge in the place
His fader was a man̄ full free
And lorde he was of þat countre
As hit was goddes grac
Sir thopas was a doghty knyȝt swayne
White was his face and payndemayne
His lippes rede as Rose
His rode is lyke scarlet in greyne
As I ȝoᵘ telle in goode certayne
He hadde a semely nose
His here his berde was lyke safroıı̄un
To his girdell it raughte adoun̄
His shone of cordewayne
Of Brugges wer͗e his hosen̄ broıı̄un
His robe was of ciclatoun̄
That coste many a Iane
He couthe hunte at þe wilde der͗e
And ride on̄ hankynge fro the ryver
With gray gosshauke on̄ hande
Ther͗e to he was a goode archer͗e
To wrastelyng was þ̉er none his per͗e
Ther͗e any man̄ shuld stonde
Full many a maide bright in bour͗e
Thei morne for his ꝑparamour͗e
Whan̄ thei wer͗e bette to slepe
But he was chast ⁊and no lechour͗e
And swete as is the brembel flour͗e
That berith þe rede heppe
And so bifell vppon̄ a day
For soth as I. ȝow tell may
Sir Thopas wolde oute ryde
He worth vppon̄ his stede gray
And in his hande a launce gay
A longe swerde by his syde
He priketh þurgh a fair͗e foreste
Ther in̄ne is many a wilde beste
Ȝe boke both and har
And he priked north ⁊and est
I telle ȝow hym had almeste
Betydde a sory care
There spryngen herbes grene ⁊and smale
The lycorice ⁊and þe seduale
And mony a clowe gillofre
And nottemygges to put in ale
Whethir it be moiste or stale
Or to for to leye in cofre
The briddes syng it is no nay
The sꝑparhauke and the popyngay
That ioy it was to here
The thrustilcok made eek his lay
The woddowe vpon̄ þe spray
She sang full lovde ⁊and clere
Sir Thopas felle in love longynge
And whan̄ he herd þe þrustele synge
And priked as he were woode
His faire stede in his prikynge
So swette þat men̄ myȝt hym wryng
His sydes weren alle bloode
Sir Thopas eke so wery was
For prykynge on̄ þe softe grasse
So fers was his corage
That doun̄ he leyde hym in þᵗat place
To maken̄ his stede some solace
For he was so sauage
O Seint Marie b̄endicite
What eylith this love at me
To bynde me so sore
Me dremed al this nyȝt ꝑparde
An elfe quene shall my lēmman be
And slepe vnder my gore
An elf quene wole .I. loue ywy
For in this worlde no wōmman is
Worthy to be my make in towne
Al other wōmmen I forsake
And to an elf quene I. me betake
By dales ⁊and eke by downe
In to his sadell he cam anone
And priked oủer stele and stone
An elf quene for to aspie
Til he so long hath reden ⁊and gone
That he fonde in a pryve wone
The contre of fair eyȝe so wilde
For in þᵗat countre was ther none
Neither wyfe ne child
Til hym þere come a ioly geaunt
His name was clepyd sir Olepant
A ꝑperilous man̄ of dede
He seid child by tyrmagant
But ȝif þᵘou pryke out of my hant
Anone I. sle thi stede with mace
Here is the quene of faireyȝe
With harpe ⁊and pipe ⁊and symphonye
Dwellyng in this place
The child seid so mote I the
To morw will .I. meten the
Whan .I. haue myne Armur͗e
And ȝit I hope ꝑparma fay
That þou shalt with this launcegay
Abyen hit full sore yurgh thy mawe
Shal .I. ꝑperce ȝif I. may
Or hit be fully pryme of day
For here þou shat be slawe
Sir Thopas drowe a bake full faste
This graunte hym stones caste
Oute of a fell staffe slyng
But faire escapeth child Thopace
And all it was þurgh goddes grace
And thurgh his faire beryng
Ȝet lesteneth lordes to my tale
Murier þan the nyȝtengale
For now I wole ȝow rowne
How ʆser Thopas with sydes smale
Prikyng oủer downe ⁊and dale
